PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of privilege arising out of a communication sent by the Communication Workers Union to a number of members of this House and action taken by that union consequent upon that communication. The effect of it is to place an indefinite ban on the delivery—and I understand in many cases the dispatch—of mail articles in and out of members' offices.

PARA.TAB: This seems to me to be a very clear breach of privilege. I have been able to establish that questions of privilege have been raised in this House on two previous occasions: once in 1978 by the former member for Maranoa relating to a general ban, and on a second occasion in May 1985 the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) raised a question of privilege in relation to the banning of express Courier Mail articles to Queensland. On that occasion Madam Speaker Childs declined to grant the matter priority on the grounds that the ban affected members of the public generally and was not specifically directed towards members of parliament.

On this occasion the ban clearly falls into the latter category. Members of parliament are being singled out for the purposes of the ban and it does seem that it is a breach of the privileges of members of both sides of this House. Mr Speaker, I therefore ask you to take the action which is appropriate under the standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is normal practice, I will look at the issue which has been raised by the honourable member and I might just inform him that I have also received communication from the Leader of the National Party on the same issue. I will report back to the House a little later.
—I inform the House that the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, Gordon Bilney, will be absent from question time this week.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you running a raffle? Mr Bilney is away on government business. In his absence questions should be addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Alan Griffiths.

Andrew Theophanous has resumed his duties as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Servies and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that at the weekend the chief executives of 15 major Australian mining companies described the Mabo legislation as `extraordinarily complex' and `unworkable' and said that the continuing uncertainty generated by it would `jeopardise development, diminish and delay investment and reduce economic growth and employment opportunities'. Why is the government trying to railroad this legislation through parliament this year when so many Australians have such deep concerns about its impact?

—It is a fact that such advertisements did appear in the national press. There is nothing new about that, of course; there have been campaigns in the past by the mining industry with respect to land rights and Aboriginal affairs, and this is yet another one of them. This argument that somehow the native title legislation can be simple—a one-page bill that some people have proposed—is absolutely ridiculous. Native title affects land management in this country. There is a wide raft of legislation across the states and the federal arena dealing with land management, from real property acts, conveyancing acts, mining legislation, crown land legislation, the law of trusts—endless provisions. In New South Wales alone, some 4,000 pages of legislation deal with land management. We cannot pass an act relating to a new title that impacts upon all aspects of land management without drafting fairly long and complex legislation.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons why the Commonwealth reached this decision was that, in the many negotiations we had with state governments, it was the state governments that put high on the agenda many of the provisions that now appear in our legislation. A great deal of the length and complexity of the legislation is based on agreements we reached with state governments because they felt that this sort of legislation was necessary.Those who take a simplistic attitude about this and say that it can be pushed away in a document of a page, 10 pages or even 47 pages are completely wrong. They have no understanding whatsoever about what land management is in this country. It is a very complex area of the law. No more detailed area of the law exists than land management, and native title impacts upon that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it more time.

—`Give us more time' is the call today from the opposition. Twelve months ago, opposition members were demanding immediate legislation. They were urging the government to rush into the parliament. The Northern Territory government passed legislation. All the state Premiers demanded immediate legislation. Now opposition members want more time. The fact of the matter is that no issue in the history of politics of the Commonwealth government has been given more ministerial time and more time for debate—we have spent more than a year debating this at great length—and the time has come for the uncertainty that relates to mining titles in this country to be cleared up and for justice to be given to Aboriginal people.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has his attention been drawn to recent employment statistics for the Australian economy? Can he say whether these statistics indicate a stronger economic expansion? What action does he believe appropriate for the economy at this time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we last met, we have had further confirmation that the Australian economy is strengthening and that employment and output are increasing in a well-balanced way. Last week we had confirmation that over the last three months to November there has been the creation of 100,000 jobs in the economy. We saw last week GDP for the year recorded at 3.4 per cent—a rise of 0.4 per cent in the September quarter—with contributions to growth coming from the private sector, including a strong performance from business investment in plant and equipment. In fact, business investment grew by 3.4 per cent in the September quarter and nearly 11 per cent over the year. If we disaggregate that for plant and equipment, we find that plant and equipment rose by 14.4 per cent over the year.

PARA.TAB: Looking at exports, the current account numbers for October show continuing gains in exports and, in fact, the current account deficit this year is actually running lower than the current account deficit for the same period in the last financial year.

I turn now to profits. In the corporate sector, profits rose strongly in the September quarter to levels not seen since the late 1980s. You might remember, Mr Speaker, that the levels in the late 1980s were above any historical experience for Australia—above the so-called golden years of the 1960s to levels which were unprecedented. The profit levels in the economy today are at levels not seen since the late 1980s.

I might also add that private sector surveys confirm the trend. The BCA survey reported today, and the ACCI survey into investor confidence and the Westpac-Melbourne Institute leading index tell the same stories. We see it reflected in this week's Economist magazine. Its poll of forecasters in Europe, the United States and Japan shows Australia at the top of the growth table in 1993 among 13 OECD economies surveyed. It predicts we will grow even faster next year and it shows we are doing it with one of the lowest inflation rates in the world.

We are seeing a stronger expansion in the economy and one that is flowing right into employment and jobs. I think the moral of the tale is simply this: if the Australian community wishes to keep the expansion going it does so by sticking with the policies of this government, which have been vehemently attacked at every step along the way by the federal opposition. I remind the House that back in February of this year—not that long ago in economic forecasting terms—the Leader of the Opposition was warning of a double dip recession:

ANSWER.PARA: `The Australian economy may double dip' warns Hewson.
So much for his judgments or his frighteners about the economy. Then he said:
If we get a quick recovery as a result of some stimulatory package—
it will be a disaster for this country because we will go back to the old boom-bust cycle and have an exchange rate crisis before the end of the year.
That was, of course, 1992. There was no boom-bust; no exchange rate crisis before the end of the year. He continued:

One Nation spends about $23 billion, which is unfunded. It will blow this country out of the water if it is successful in the sense of actually stimulating economic activity. It will precipitate both an exchange rate crisis and acceleration of inflation. I find it hard to believe that inflation will not again accelerate to at least the five per cent level that Chris Murphy has identified. Depending on the pace at which such things pick up in the context of the balance of payments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—The Leader of the Opposition. He went on:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we could well have inflation much higher if there is a period of downward pressure on the exchange rate which flows back into the price series.
The fact is that, when one looks at the predictions of the Leader of the Opposition, one sees: 28 January 1992, an exchange rate crisis and a balance of payments crisis; 22 May 1992—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much longer is he going to waste our time, Mr Speaker?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—He said that One Nation would precipitate an exchange rate crisis. On 2 July 1992, he said there was a very real risk of a double dip recession. On 28 August 1992, he precipitated a rise in official interest rates; and again on 1 September. On 12 November 1992, he said that Australia was drifting dangerously towards a depression. Then in February he said that we were going to go back into a double dip recession.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I think that ought to be evidence of the fact that in these things the Leader of the Opposition has no credibility in making judgments about the economic pick-up, its sustainability, the influence on inflation and the current account deficit. The Liberal Party may well take note—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody believes you.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor!
—It is the policies of the government which have induced this recovery, now leading any in the OECD area, and which have done so with an attendant pick-up in employment and lower inflation.
—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer stand by his total opposition, and that of his department, to a jobs levy on the basis that it will cost more jobs than it will create?

—The qualification at the end of the statement by the Leader of the Opposition was his own, not mine or my department's. I have said in this place and elsewhere that proposals have been put forward in the context of preparing the green paper on employment opportunities that extra revenue should be raised in order to fund some of the initiatives proposed in those submissions. The green paper is to be released this week. The reason that the government has proceeded on the basis of a green paper preparatory to determining its own policy is precisely to allow for public debate about these questions. I do not intend to pre-empt the debate which may ensue following the release of that report.

PARA.TAB: The point I have made is that those people who propose that additional revenue should be imposed in order to fund additional expenditure initiatives need to persuade the community of the efficacy of those initiatives and, therefore, the desirability of raising revenue. That is something which stands before those who make these propositions. But beyond that, I think it would be a contradiction of the approach the government has taken, that is, to have a wide-ranging debate involving the community about this central issue of employment, for me to pre-empt that debate now.

However, I should make the point that it rings a little hollow for the Leader of the Opposition to be making statements like this about the plight of the unemployed. Of course, he has never been concerned about these people. He has never been concerned about the need to address the issue of those people who have been affected by change within the Australian community. I mentioned in a speech last week that it was necessary for us, as we proceed with the necessary structural change in Australia, to take account of the consequences for ordinary people and to have sensitive policy approaches to take into account their particular circumstances. This, of course, is something which the Leader of the Opposition pays no attention to and takes no heed of whatsoever.

What the government is on about is focusing attention on unemployment as being a major issue, a major policy challenge, one which needs to be addressed in the context of an economy which is growing and becoming daily more competitive and more productive. In that context we have to ensure that the circumstances of those people who have been affected by change and by the recent period of inadequate growth in the economy—the recent recession, if you like—should be taken into account in terms of the policy response which the government makes. I think the government has perfect credentials to address the wide scope of this debate about improving employment opportunities, both from the point of view of improving the performance of the economy and in responding to the very real social dimension of this question. We have the credentials to deal with that issue; frankly, the Leader of the Opposition does not.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: State Bank of New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —I also direct my question to the Treasurer. He will be aware that the New South Wales government announced on 25 November that it would sell the State Bank of New South Wales via a `public trade sale'. Can the Treasurer explain to the House what requirements this public trade sale will need to meet in order for the Commonwealth government to approve the transfer of ownership of the State Bank?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, in which he noted the fact that the New South Wales government has announced its intention to sell the State Bank of New South Wales and asked what we would do in that context. We will, of course, apply the same principles in the case of the State Bank of New South Wales as we would apply in the case of any proposed change of ownership of an Australian bank. These principles rest on two fundamental concerns: firstly, the need for the maintenance of confidence in the banking system; and, secondly, the need to maintain effective competition within the banking system.

PARA.TAB: In a policy statement on 18 June, I set out the major elements which would underpin the way in which we would try to achieve those two joint objectives. I do not intend to repeat those, except to mention some of them which are relevant to this consideration. In the first instance, the trade sale approach, which is being taken by the New South Wales government, implies that the prospective new owner or owners would seek to have shareholdings above 10 per cent each. That means that an application would need to be made under the Banks (Shareholdings) Act. Applications under this act will continue to be considered on a case by case basis.

While each case is considered on its merit, the following broad comments should be made. Mergers between regional and smaller banks, including state banks, are in general likely to be permitted subject to the considerations spelled out in my statement. While reducing the number of players, such mergers can potentially increase competition, as a newly merged entity may well provide more effective competition against the major players. Mergers between a major bank and a state, regional or smaller bank might be permitted if this did not detract significantly from local competition.

Consistent with previously announced policy, mergers between any of the four major banks or a major life company will not be permitted. A merger between two of the major players is likely to detract more from effective competition than would be in the national interest. This is particularly the case given that such a merger would result in an institution that was far larger than the other key players and so might be expected to prompt calls for further mergers or acquisitions.

That said, the government is not opposed in principle to a non-mutual life office owning a bank, provided that the life office can demonstrate sufficient financial strength, has a diverse share register consistent with the provisions of the Banks (Shareholdings) Act and accepts supervision by the Reserve Bank of itself to the extent necessary to ensure the integrity of its subsidiary or associated bank and the stability in the overall financial system. Legislative changes may be necessary to achieve this.

Mergers in the banking industry require the approval of the Treasurer and are also subject to the competition provisions of the Trade Practices Act. From a competitive point of view, the government will not limit merger possibilities to domestic bidders. As indicated in the One Nation statement, bids by foreign banks will be considered on a case by case basis for banks other than the four big Australian banks.

The government is concerned to monitor and regulate these transfers of bank ownership. Where it is a bank that is currently under state government ownership, the relevant state government may wish to impose additional requirements of its own. That is a matter for the state government and for its parliament. As far as the proposal is concerned, we are happy to work with the government of New South Wales to ensure that the proposed change of ownership of the State Bank of New South Wales occurs in a way which is supportive of the continuing confidence in the banking system in Australia and which also maintains effective competition within the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister stand by his total opposition to people on high incomes—like him—either paying a higher Medicare levy or being required to take out private health insurance?

—I should have thought that the opposition might have learned something from the last election: that trying to shift a great dose of national income across to doctors got it a very strong rebuke in the election. Trying to pull away at the entrails of Medicare got the opposition precisely the kind of response that we believed it would get in putting those policies.

PARA.TAB: The government is about to consider the totality of that part of the health scheme, particularly as it relates to private health, and I am not, for the purposes of this question, going to disturb cabinet debate on that. I have made clear my general position on the notion that people should have to pay for private insurance and that people on high incomes cannot avail themselves of the public health system. If the argument were true, it would be just as true of education or anything else, and that would mean that high income earners could not send their kids to a public school. I do not think very many people in the House would argue that case.

Beyond that, we will be looking at the health scheme in a comprehensive way to see how we can improve it. But the fundamental point is that the basic system works. Medicare is working so well that people are leaving the private health system and joining the public health system. In fact, if anything, Medicare has been very successful in taking clientele from the private health system to the public health system. Those are the core facts.

We have a health system which has lasted just on a decade, which has held the national costs of health at about half those of the United States, which has a fee-for-service private practice system of health and which has a uniform health insurance system across the country by which people can avail themselves of health care. There is not a health system for the well-off and a philanthropic health system for the poor; there is one health system which has two characteristics—public and private. We want to see those two characteristics of the system work in harmony. That is what the review is about, and obviously that is what we will be looking at in our cabinet discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. In view of the significance of automotive manufacturing—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is easily excited. In view of the significance of automotive manufacturing to the wider Australian economy, can the minister inform the House of the recent performance of this industry?

—The Prime Minister made mention of one policy jurisdiction for which the opposition deservedly copped a massive rebuke from the people at the last election. The automotive industry is another example of a whole suite of areas where the opposition copped something similar. By comparison with the government's approach to this important industry—a phased reduction in tariff protection to 15 per cent by the year 2000; a comprehensive export facilitation scheme; and a commitment to maintaining the industry, as evidenced by a whole range of government programs—the opposition walked away from the industry at the last election campaign. That is a policy position that has not been forgotten by anyone remotely associated with the industry.

PARA.TAB: The most recent figures are cause for considerable optimism in relation to this important sector. Car sales have improved. The sales component of Australian produced cars has increased—quite dramatically increased—at a rate faster than that for the market as a whole. Indeed, in 1993 it is up almost eight per cent on last year's figures. Of the mainstream Australian produced motor vehicles, Camry is up 17 per cent; Falcon, 14 per cent; Magna, 13 per cent; and Commodore, eight per cent. This means that in 1993 the automotive sector should produce vehicles and automotive components worth $1 billion more than for the corresponding period last year. It is also worth pointing out that automotive exports, as a direct function of government policy, have also continued to supplement that market growth.

Exports are projected to increase by 15 to 20 per cent in 1993. That will take the export figures to over $1.4 billion from almost zilch when Labor came to power. One company, General Motors, has announced an accumulative profit of $303 million over the last four years. General Motors has indicated that it will invest something in the order of $550 million over the next five years. That is a mighty endorsement of government policy in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right.

—The Prime Minister interjects, `Too right', and he is absolutely right. As a corollary, one aspect that has been reported in the last little while is that GM is proposing to sell some 50,000 units per year of a customised Holden under the badge of Cadillac in the United States. That ought to be a matter of pride for every member of this House, especially the Prime Minister and his colleagues who presided over that policy.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, let me make this point: in stark contrast to the government's comprehensive approach to this industry, the shadow minister for industry indicated in the last little while his support for Labor government policy on the tariff issue. At the same time, the Leader of the Opposition is reiterating the central tenets of Fightback. It is very important for the industry that the opposition gets its act together.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Given the difficulties faced by the sugar industry in the past few years, what action has been taken to assist the sugar industry and how well is it performing?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. Recently I had the opportunity to be in the electorate of the honourable member for Herbert to announce a very important set of proposals under our infrastructure package. The infrastructure package for the sugar industry was part of the general sugar industry package that this government announced at the end of last year. It was a package that was designed to ensure that expansion and growth occurred in this important industry but recognised the fact that, if we were to get expansion and get the freeing up of some of the state regulatory environment, there needed to be infrastructure to underpin that expansion.

PARA.TAB: With this package we were able to get the state government to cooperate in some important changes to the sugar industry under its purview—namely, the narrowing of the margin in the pooling prices for sugar as well as the allocation systems for land. It was only because we were prepared to sit down with the industry and the state government that could have influence in these particular areas that we were able to develop a package that made sense to the industry. The infrastructure package involved the commitment by this government of some $19 million to the Queensland industry, which was to be matched in the first instance dollar for dollar by the state government. But the $38 million that the two governments put in has seen a total expenditure on infrastructure committed by local government, by stakeholders and by the governments of some $117 million. So the $38 million, including our initial $19 million, has significantly leveraged commitment to infrastructure expansion.

The immediate impact of this infrastructure expansion will be the creation of 1,900 jobs in Queensland for the construction phase, a beneficial impact to a third of the growers in that state, an ability to increase the production of this industry by 1 1/2 million tonnes and a commitment to expand our export earnings from this industry by $60 million per annum.

The proposals benefit both existing development, where they go to drainage and technology initiatives to improve the yield, and new expansion areas, where the money will fund irrigation and railway infrastructure. In recent months, the sugar industry has received some very welcome news: returns to growers in that industry have gone up 13 per cent over the last year; export earnings are up by 10 per cent and will move past the $1 billion mark in the next year. There will be added benefit from any breakthroughs we get through the GATT negotiations.

This infrastructure will underpin the expansion. It comes about because of a commitment by this government to work with the industry in the development of a pro-active strategy. Those on the other side argue that they had a package for the sugar industry, but they would not even have thought about it if we had not announced ours. We are committed to working with industry to develop the growth strategy and secure the growth path. This is another very important example of our not only undertaking the activity of identifying opportunity, but also delivering on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, again, is to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Does the minister deny that she, or her office, destroyed or withheld from the Auditor-General any records relating to the community, cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program? Does she deny that the fax to the Minister for Finance of 20 February 1992 was destroyed or withheld? I seek leave to table a copy of that facsimile.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said on many occasions in this House, I deny that I destroyed any single document associated with this issue. The Auditor-General clearly had access to documents.
—What about withholding?
—I did not withhold; the Auditor-General had access to the information that was available in my department. He had total access to it. I did not destroy any documents.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can he inform the House of the implications of the November labour force figures, especially as they are related to the outlook for employment? Are all commentators agreed on the outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Employment now, on the job figures released last week, is 2.3 per cent higher than it was a year ago. That is the largest one-year gain in employment for the last three years. I am sure all honourable members welcome that news. Trend employment has now increased every month since February. Full-time employment rose by 16,300. That is the third consecutive monthly increase. Full-time employment is now at its highest level since October 1991. Trend full-time employment has risen in every month, except one, since October 1992. There have been a few comments on that. Chris Caton, the chief economist for Bankers Trust Australia, said:

ANSWER.PARA: What can you say about three months in succession of growing employment? Only that it's the best labour market news that we've had since before the recession began.
The unemployment rate has passed its peak.
Ross Gittins, the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald said:
The news on the economy keeps getting better. There's now little doubt that the labour market is on the mend.

The Leader of the Opposition, on Radio MMM in Western Australia, said, `This data is confirming our worst fears'. That is, if Western Australia had the participation rates of New South Wales, unemployment would be about three per cent. While the data might be confirming the worst fears of the Leader of the Opposition, fortunately, those are not the country's worst fears. The country has every reason to be pleased by these trends.

PARA.TAB: The growth in employment is expected to continue, given the four-digit indicators provided by a number of job vacancy series. The ANZ vacancies are up 29 per cent since May. That figure rose by 4.5 per cent in November, the sixth consecutive monthly increase. The Australian Bureau of Statistics vacancies are up almost 40 per cent in a year and DEET skilled vacancies are up 45 per cent in a year.

That positive outlook is also reflected in a series of business surveys. The latest evidence is contained in the half yearly survey of current business conditions of the Business Council of Australia. Almost half the respondents, the biggest companies in Australia, plan to increase employment over the next six months. Forty-seven per cent expected higher staff numbers, up from 33 per cent in the last survey in April this year. The BCA said that this was the most favourable jobs outlook since its October 1990 survey.
There have been a few comments on that. Allan Handberg, the ACM National Chief Executive, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Improvement in manufacturing confidence is now spread fairly evenly across all States.
Increased optimism "across a very broad front of indicators."
Ian Salmon, Chairman of the BCA economic panel, said:
A broadly-based private sector recovery appears to be under way.

On 25 November 1993, Dr Michael Wooldridge, Deputy Leader of the Opposition, put out a press release entitled `Business expectations negative on employment'. So evidently we have the same descriptive capabilities in regard to the two leaders of the opposition as we have their analytical capabilities as dealt with by the Prime Minister a bit earlier. As usual, they are like shags on a rock on these issues—diminished in their joy of life every time they see a decent statistic, hoping like heck that it all turns round some time over the next couple of years to give them a half way chance of getting re-elected because they know, as these changes come through, that they have no chance.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to make a brief statement to the House pursuant to the matter I raised in a personal explanation on 16 November.
—Please proceed.

—Firstly, I wish to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his statement on Saturday welcoming me back to my position as parliamentary secretary. I also wish to thank all my colleagues on both sides of the House for their expressions of goodwill and support over this very difficult period.

PARA.TAB: Not all honourable members would be aware that, less than 72 hours after I voluntarily stood down from my position, the person alleged to have made the statements totally disowned the newspaper article and categorically denied any impropriety on my part. In addition, the entire executive of the Chinese students human rights organisation swore statutory declarations confirming no impropriety existed and declaring their support for me. Despite this, I insisted that the Federal Police inquiry be completed, and I am delighted that it has cleared me of any wrongdoing.

Nevertheless, I believe that this episode raises serious issues about the vulnerability of members of parliament to scurrilous and unfounded attacks. This is especially the case when such attacks occur not in the mainstream national media but in small journals which do not take seriously their responsibilities with respect to the laws of defamation. I believe that honourable members need protection from this kind of attack on their character and reputation. I shall be writing to you, Mr Speaker, and the Chairman of the Privileges Committee to ask for an examination of this general issue.
Finally, I have been very heartened by the hundreds of letters and phone calls that I have received from Chinese students. I believe their cause is a just one, and I shall continue to support it.
