DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we proceed to the matter of public importance, could I respond to an issue raised during the last sittings. On 24 November the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Howard) asked me to adjudicate on certain remarks made by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). I understand that the Leader of the House did in fact make the remarks and they were reported in Hansard. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) made a personal explanation in relation to those remarks, which was the appropriate way of responding.

PARA.TAB: The role of the Speaker in such matters is to ensure that unparliamentary remarks are withdrawn. Members themselves must take responsibility for what they say in proceedings and it is not for the chair to adjudicate on the validity or otherwise of those remarks. I do not propose to intervene in any way in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) clearly alleged that certain statements were made by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) which had not been made. A careful examination of Hansard the following day clearly demonstrated that the Leader of the House had falsely attributed quite detrimental remarks to the honourable member for Higgins. Those detrimental remarks allegedly made by the honourable member for Higgins were given quite wide publicity the following day in the press. That caused a great deal of concern, not only to the honourable member for Higgins, but to others on this side the House.

PARA.TAB: It is one thing to falsely allege something about an opposite number, for that to be denied and the matter to pass without reporting; but the claim by the Leader of the House that the honourable member for Higgins had made a sexist remark got a lot of press. It strikes us as particularly unreasonable and unfair that somebody can get up, make a statement alleging something that was not said, or not even remotely alluded to, get a big run out of it and then just sit there in a satisfied Pontius Pilate fashion as though nothing has happened.

I again invite the Leader of the House to withdraw even at this belated stage. I have said in the past that he is a man who is not without honour and decency. I hope that he would match that high regard I have for him and withdraw those remarks. They were unworthy of him as the statement was not uttered. He deliberately misrepresented what the honourable member for Higgins had said, and that is beyond argument when one looks at the Hansard. He ought to demonstrate that he is a decent bloke and withdraw the remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my prepared statement, if people in this place do make comments—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—His father would have withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —When those on my left have finished! From time to time there are things said in this place for which honourable members must ultimately take responsibility. If other honourable members believe that they have been misrepresented in some way, they have an opportunity through personal explanations, or whatever, to take a different view of that and in their minds set the record straight. As I have indicated in this particular case, that was the way this matter was dealt with.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's confusion and division on health policy.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is about health or, more correctly, the government's response to the health of Australia. Its confusion and division on health policy are going to reach their climax this week when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) meet each other in a battle of will over the future of Medicare, private health insurance and Australia's health care system. The crisis in Medicare has at long last been recognised by the man the Prime Minister chose to be the Minister for Health. Last week, he is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We're going to reach crisis point, I think, in health care fairly soon. We are not going to be able to sustain things.

That crisis involves long public hospital waiting lists—estimated by some to be around 100,000 Australians—a massive imbalance between public and private health systems, and a continuing decline in the number of Australians with private health care cover. The Prime Minister seems to be the lone figure who recognises the magnitude of the health problem facing this country and in his usual arrogant fashion has pitted himself against his own health minister. We heard this in question time today. The Prime Minister commented that the system works well; it works so well that in fact people are leaving the private health insurance system. I will comment on that later.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is no newcomer to the politicising of health at the expense of needy Australians. He turned the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Mr Howe), who is at the table, into a lame duck health minister by thwarting his moves to fix Medicare with a co-payment system. In those days that was his ticket to the prime ministership. Today it is political self-interest and an insatiable need to get his own way, even at the expense of the community at large. Whatever the merits or otherwise of Senator Richardson's proposal, it seems that the Prime Minister will put his own self-interest first. It will be that self-interest that will undoubtedly torpedo any move to restructure the system so that it can provide for the health needs of all Australians.

We have a worrying set of problems in health in Australia. The first is that we have an ageing population. A hundred years ago we had a million people, with an average age of 20 years. Today it is 17,000,000 people, with an average age of 31 years. In 10 years it will be 20,000,000 people, with an average age of 36 years. By the year 2000 it is estimated that two in every seven Australians will be over 50 years of age. For the year I turn 65, in 2021, the aged population in Australia will peak. Two-thirds of our health care dollars are spent on people over 60 years of age. One-quarter of all our health care is spent on less than four per cent of the population over 75 years of age. Even without changes that have been mooted by Senator Richardson, health care costs of Australians are going to rise dramatically.

This is where we are with health today in Australia. There has been static expenditure on health for the last 13 years. Australia failed to keep pace on national health care compared to other OECD countries. We once had a system that it could realistically be said was second to none. With ceilings put on it for over 13 years, it is straining. We have a greater number of people requiring health care services and the standards very much depend on finance available. The greatest con is that the Medicare levy covers the health system—it covers about one-quarter of it. The result is that public health is under-funded, overcrowded and private hospital resources are under-utilised. We have waiting lists. Privately insured patients use public hospital beds. In 1989, a quarter of all acute bed days were private patients in public hospitals.

The cost of private health insurance has gone up 72 per cent over the last three years. The Prime Minister would not know this, of course, because he does not have it. The numbers have fallen from 60 per cent to under 40 per cent over the last 10 years. The paradox for us is that, for every one per cent which opts out of private health insurance, it costs the public sector an extra $80 million a year. Recent reports warn that, unless there is a substantial increase in private health insurance by the year 2000, Australia's health care bill will increase by $2 billion a year.

Why are we in this situation? It is fairly simple and it can all be traced back directly to decisions made by the Labor Party, the first of which was the reinsurance pool. This was introduced in the late 1970s to share the cost of elderly Australians and of chronically ill Australians. It was over $100 million in 1983 and it kept the cost of private health insurance down.

That was easy money. It was targeted. It was abolished, and so the community rating principle could not survive when there was no equalisation of the costs of elderly Australians or those who were chronically ill. That means that today for every dollar put into private health care by people over 65 years of age, they take out something like $1.50. That is not a bad bet. But for every dollar put into private health care by people aged 25 years, they take out about 12c. Young Australians are leaving private insurance in droves and why would they not? They would be stupid to do anything else.

So what is Senator Richardson trying to do? He is trying to introduce a two tier system of Medicare with an additional levy for the rich to force them to take out private health insurance. We have nothing against an extra levy per se provided it is used to render low and middle income earners able to take out private health insurance. If the government does not do that—if it just slugs the rich an extra tax—it means there will be one system for the rich and one for the poor.

Senator Richardson has two other proposals: making funds more viable by amalgamating them, which seems curious; and making doctors employees of hospitals, which seems even more curious. Yet Senator Richardson is at least trying to do something, even if we do not fundamentally agree with what he is doing.At the end of November in the Australian he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think my plan will stand up to analysis and I'll still be trying to get up at the end.
That was very interesting because the Prime Minister's response to that in the Age had been:
Well, he's going to need a lot of . . . courage.
The Prime Minister thinks about health insurance this way:
I'm now paying much more, say, than someone on a low income and that's been the principle of Medicare. Now I think the government would need a lot of convincing to move away from that.
Richardson's reply was made to the Australian Health Insurance Association when he said:
While you may not believe that I am an expert at any of this, I am a world expert on power.

That is what this is all about. It is about power; it is about two big egos in one cabinet room full of a lot of big egos, and it will be interesting to see the result. The criticisms of Senator Richardson's proposals are basically these: there is no incentive whatsoever for low to middle income earners to get into private health insurance. They are currently virtually denied access to it and neither the Minister for Health nor the Prime Minister acknowledge or care to do anything about it.

PARA.TAB: Thirteen per cent of pensioners choose to take out private health insurance. That is a struggle. A million Australians earning $40,000 or less are choosing to be privately insured. That is not much of a choice when the price has gone up 72 per cent in the last three years. If the government leaves these people out in the cold, public hospital waiting lists will continue to grow. Senator Richardson understands this. In recent times he has made the following comments:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, we cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that it has in the past years because this does increase the strains on the public system.
Absolutely. He is also quoted as saying recently:

The trouble is that when people on higher incomes drop out of private insurance, they do elbow the old pensioner out of the queue because if you are on one hundred grand ($100,000) a year, you do know how to work the systems.

That is the essence of our problem. In fact, there are three fundamental problems. The first is: Medicare simply does not have the capacity to provide what it claims to provide. I remember very well that in 1984 when Medicare came in the then Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, had a headline article in the Melbourne Sun entitled `Medicare is all you need'. Today Mick Young might have a look at the public hospital system and how it is attempting to transfer costs from state governments to the federal government to cope with its under financing and over demand. This has been going on for years and no minister on the other side has had the guts to do anything about it. We have only to talk to any doctor at the coalface in the public hospital system to realise that there is a massive shift of funds from state to federal in an attempt to cope—even in spite of the fact that it is distinctly against the Commonwealth-State health agreement.

PARA.TAB: It is done in three areas. The first is pharmacy. Ten years ago patients could go home from a public hospital with an adequate supply of pharmaceuticals. Today they are lucky to get away with two to three days before they have to send someone down to the pharmacy to get a script paid for by the federal government. Another area is procedures, particularly gastroenterology. I remember as a junior doctor being surprised to find that there were no gastroscopes being done in a certain hospital in Melbourne. They had all been shuffled off to one of the private clinics nearby.

I remember asking the registrar, `How on earth do they get the referrals?'. He was surprised and said, `Gee, I don't know'. After a couple of seconds he looked shocked and said, `Yes, I do know where they get the referrals from. It is actually from me. That is what I've been signing in recent times'. It is cost shifting. It is taking those procedures out of the public hospital system, whacking the cost on to the federal government and, again, the federal government has been powerless to do anything about it.

Most recently, we have had the farce of so-called privatisation of outpatient clinics. This is really a complete misnomer. I rang a GP in Melbourne today when we put forward this MPI to ask him how he was faring with so-called privatised outpatient services. He told me a story of one of his patients last week who needed a neurology referral and who had to go to a so-called privatised clinic. In fact, that patient was waiting for just as long as would have been the case in the old public hospital outpatients department. The fact is the costs are being shifted across to the feds and the feds are incapable of doing anything about it. That person could have a referral within 48 hours if he or she were a private patient. This is acknowledged by the head of the Victorian Department of Health and Community Services, John Paterson. The article in the Age states:

"We all work away quietly doing a bit of cost shifting in our own favour if we can get away with it, while the Commonwealth automatically tries to play the states off against each other, partly for financial reasons but substantially for hegemonic ones" he said.

"All this would be fine if the sole objective was to keep politicians and officials entertained. The long suffering public remains deluded that their wellbeing is central. If that were really so we would immediately play a different and much simpler game.

SPEECH.PARA: He continued:
But Medicare was a "major element of Australia's tragic farce of a national health and welfare financing system". . .

That was said by one of the guys who has been doing it. The government has been incapable of addressing it for a decade. We are also seeing an increase in services. That is why it is costing so much. That is where the pressure is coming from. It is increasing by seven to nine per cent a year. A co-payment would have done something about that, but that was not allowed to happen. Anyone who works in the system knows about it. I know about it. I have a very active medical practice in this House for which I am paid absolutely nothing. About 60 per cent of the members of the House come to see me—that is, 60 per cent who sit on one side of the House—because I think I am now the only medico in the House of Representatives. I am always delighted to see them. But in the majority of cases they whip out their Medicare card in order to pay me. I am absolutely entitled to take that. I choose not to because I cannot see why, on a full-time salary, I should hit the government for another expense. But a lot of doctors do; they are entitled to do it and it pushes up the cost of the system.

PARA.TAB: We are seeing waiting lists. I phoned a neurosurgeon in Melbourne this morning to ask him whether any, or many, of his patients had to pay for their own treatment. In the last 12 months six people waiting for spinal surgery, waiting in pain, waiting terrified about what the future might hold, took out bank loans and paid for their own services—and that was from this one doctor.

The fact is that if none of these proposals which are going to cabinet gains any acceptance, the government has to ask what it is going to do to ensure an accessible and affordable quality health care system. I can predict what the minister who is at the table is going to say. He is going to talk about two million Australians being uninsured before Medicare. This is the Goebbels principle; this is the big lie. This is a case of thinking that if one repeats something often enough, people will believe it.

I have looked at the ABS survey on private health insurance. The majority of those two million people came from Queensland where they got free health care. A lot of others were pensioners who had access to health care and others were veterans who had access to health care. So the figure is a complete lie; it is a complete fabrication. In the end, the government is going to be faced with either a massive infusion of money to stop the haemorrhaging or it is going to have to face up to the real question: how are we going to pay for the health care of the nation? We should be looking at these issues, not the farcical issue of who is more powerful: the Prime Minister or the Minister for Health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard it as rather extraordinary that the coalition should schedule an MPI on the topic of confusion and division on health policy. It is extraordinary because there is simply no area of coalition policy that has been so unsuccessful and divisive over the past decade. The coalition has had seven spokespeople on health since 1983. Five have left the parliament, or are leaving, as in the case of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). Only the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) remains in this chamber and the present incumbent, Senator Newman, remains in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The coalition seems to have had a self-destruct button when it comes to health policy. Who can forget the sad saga of Peter Shack and his disastrous attempt to introduce a new health policy in 1989? By his own account, he prepared a comprehensive plan, which he described as simple and easy to understand. Yet the coalition went to the 1990 election without a health policy. It was one of the great mysteries of that March 24 election: where was the opposition's much vaunted health policy? The hapless Mr Shack was left to carry the blame when it was clear that the Liberal leadership group itself abandoned the package because it feared it would harm its vote.

After the 1990 election, a member of that leadership group and then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), described his party's health scheme as a political disaster. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There were not many people reading them and not many people understanding them. I think we are also being pretty honest to say some of our policies we need to take back to the drawing board.

So back to the drawing board the coalition went, and Dr Bob Woods came on board as the health spokesperson. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) clearly could not repeat the mistake of 1990 and not have a health policy. So in the preparation of Fightback he went for a radical option which he claimed would strengthen Medicare. That plan, put simply, was to abolish bulkbilling for 13 million Australians; to make Australians pay $32 up front for each GP visit; to slash the Medicare rebate by 10 per cent; and to cut $1.3 billion a year in funding for public hospitals.

PARA.TAB: The people of Australia have considerable regard for Medicare. It has a higher approval rating now than it has ever had. It entitles everyone universally to health care. It allows Australians to choose whether they want to be treated in the public system or in the private system. Medicare, then, is about certainty. It is also about being able to afford to go to the doctor.

By contrast, the recipe of the Leader of the Opposition was for uncertainty and more expensive health. The people of Australia understood the threat to Medicare represented by the coalition. When they voted for this Labor government, they were voting for Medicare and for a health system they could rely on. So strong was the feeling that the coalition's health spokesman Dr Woods lost his seat of Lowe. Quite simply, he had been given the task of defending the indefensible.

After 13 March the coalition went through another of the soul-searching exercises that it has become so accustomed to after five successive losses. It is interesting to note that once again health was seen as an Achilles heel. The new health spokesperson, Senator Newman, admitted in an interview with the Australian on 10 April that the coalition's health policy had harmed its poll chances. She claimed that the Australian people did not understand the policy. She wished that the policy had been different because it had left the coalition open to what she described as a damaging scare campaign. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent, well I would have wished it was different. I didn't say the policy was wrong. It just simply left us open to a fear campaign.

The people of Australia know that they cannot trust the coalition with Medicare. Senator Newman has not ruled out the worst aspects of the policy the coalition took to the election with the abolition of bulkbilling for 13 million Australians. The coalition spokesperson on social security, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), admitted as recently as last month that the coalition had no real idea about where it was going with its social security and welfare policy. He said in a speech that, although eight months had passed since the election, it was not timely for him to outline any new initiatives. If there is any confusion or any division, it is not on this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: Labor introduced Medicare in 1984 to provide every Australian with access to health care. We will continue to develop and build on that policy because it has been very successful. It has been successful because, unlike the scheme in the United States, it has enabled us to control health costs and to sustain expenditure in health at around eight per cent of GDP throughout the decade that has been operating. Medicare has been a sound policy because, effectively, in visiting primary general practitioners, the question of cost does not arise; people are able to make that decision on health grounds. Medicare means that people have access to the primary point of the health system.

We have heard comments from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) to the effect that the public hospital system in this country has not been able to cope. When we look at the facts of the case, we know that that is not true; that throughout the 1980s the health system has coped with an increased number of hospital visits and an increased number of procedures—and coped very well.

The outstanding characteristic of the public hospital system in this country, and also perhaps the larger private hospitals, has been the dramatic increases in productivity. Each year there has been growth in the number of patients treated. Essentially, that has occurred because of improvements in technology and quality of care. Those improvements have meant reduced stays for people in public hospitals, with the result that the hospital system has been able to cope with more patients.

During the 1980s, we also saw the introduction of day surgery on a much wider scale. Day surgery has meant that more and more patients have been able to receive top treatment with stays in hospital of only a few hours. It is those improvements in technology and in the organisation and productivity of the health system that have enabled us to sustain higher levels of in-hospital treatment than almost any other country in the developed world. At the same time, the overall level of expenditure has been around eight per cent of GDP.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that quite recently we ensured funding for the public hospital system for the next five years through the negotiation of Medicare agreements. Part of those agreements related to the question of waiting times. For the first time, through the Institute of Health and Welfare, we will be getting a feeling for waiting lists and waiting times on a national basis. We will also establish a state charter of patients rights which will give patients access to much better information about the way that waiting lists are managed. We will then move to the situation where waiting lists are managed more by hospitals and hospital administrators than by individual doctors who often have a pecuniary interest in how patients are classified and when and how they are treated. Reform in those areas will be extremely important.

The honourable member opposite has referred to the question of trends in relation to private health insurance. It would have been extraordinary had there not been some change in that area, given the reintroduction of Medicare in 1984. That change occurred and, as a result of universal health insurance, after a sharp initial decline, there has been a gradual decline in private health insurance. Where private health insurance is likely to settle is a matter for question and debate.

Given that the government's policy is that people should have a choice between public and private health insurance, it would be surprising if there were not sustainable levels of private health insurance in this country in the longer term. That choice is open. In the long run, one would expect, just as increasing numbers of patients are being treated in private hospitals, there to continue to be an increase in the supplementary insurance levels. So Medicare clearly means a shift in the balance between public and private funding—between those who are covered through Medicare and those who choose to be covered by private insurance.

It is interesting to note that the best indicator of whether or not people have private insurance is clearly not people's age but effectively people's income. Private health insurance has always been carried by those on very high incomes. Only a small proportion of those on incomes over $50,000 do not take out private health insurance. So private health insurance has been an option for those on higher incomes and an option that the vast majority of them have chosen to take up. Private health insurance clearly has a place, just as the private hospital system has a place within the overall health system in Australia. The private hospital system has in fact been expanding throughout the 1980s and, of course, has been increasing in that patients are being treated more rapidly than in the public sector. So the government is committed to that dual system.

During the negotiations on Medicare, there has been experimentation with a new approach to pricing within the health system, particularly the public hospital system. That experimentation centres around the concept of DRGs—diagnostic related groups—or casemix. Over the next five years, under the current Medicare agreements, casemix will be introduced universally within the public hospital system in Australia. The Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) recognises the applicability and relevance of casemix to the private hospital sector and is looking at options to introduce casemix more rapidly to the private hospital system and the implications of that move in terms of the costs and availability of private health insurance.

In contrast to the opposition, which has been so divided and has failed to develop over a long period policies that were sufficiently sustainable even to get it through an election period or to enable it to defend its policies publicly during that time, the government goes on quietly developing policy. That policy is being developed on a basis that will allow consultation with those who are most affected and that will allow us to think through the issues that are involved. This will ensure in the longer term that we have a health system in this country that continues to be sustainable, that continues to use the best technology available, that continues to be affordable in price, that continues to be based on principles of universality as we have had in the Medicare system and that ensures people have a choice between the public and private sector. We will go on debating with the coalition for as long as it wants to abolish bulk-billing, for as long as it wants to rip the heart out of Medicare, for as long as it wants to defend the interests of doctors over and against other interests and for as long as it does not put the health of Australians as its prime consideration. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a certain irony that the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Mr Howe) should be leading the debate for the government in this chamber, not the least because he is no longer the Minister for Health. But he was the Minister for Health who brought to this country the mess that the present Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) is trying to clear up.

PARA.TAB: The present Minister for Health is very open about the problem. He puts on record quite regularly the figures that contrast strongly to the story that the minister for community services tried to give us when he tried yet again to return to the lying propaganda against the opposition's medical and health policies of the last election campaign. I will not take up time on that today because that election campaign has been won and lost and there will be another election campaign. Clearly, government members think that, by repeating the lying propaganda of the last election campaign that was directed by the Australian Labor Party towards the coalition, they might win some votes for the next election. Like so many things, that is only a smokescreen to take people's attention away from the present problems.

As I said, the present problems are in no small measure due to the previous Minister for Health, the one who spoke to us here just a minute ago. It is rather ironic that he was the minister when the 1991 budget attempted to introduce a co-payment into the health system. That attempted introduction of the co-payment was a major factor in the downfall of the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, which certainly led to Senator Crowley's becoming very vocal in her support of the present incumbent's bid for the prime ministership—a huge irony, because it is now the choice of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of Senator Richardson as the Minister for Health, who is trying to rewrite the health story in Australia. This week we will see how successful he is.

The Minister for Health has made it very clear that he is very patient: he knows how to talk and he knows how to do numbers. He said that he will not go into cabinet and have a confrontation with the Prime Minister; he will make sure he has the numbers before he gets that far. He said that he will go into cabinet having persuaded a sufficient number of people of the rightness of his proposed policy.
During the last election, the Prime Minister had a lot to say about the health system that is now in such desperate need of repair. Only last February, in a press release, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a simple, affordable system of universal health care. It means no-one is denied medical treatment because they can't afford to pay.
Daily, that is denied by his present Minister for Health. On 25 February, the Prime Minister said:
We've got half a percentage problem in hospital admittance for elective surgery, therefore we should wreck Medicare and put in basically a private health insurance system.
Of course, he was being sarcastic. The Prime Minister continued:
I mean, it would be an absurdity.

The then Minister for Health—now the minister for community services—also spent a lot of time during the election campaign saying that all this talk about waiting lists was just so much propaganda put out by enemies of the government. So, pre-election, there was a denial of the problem, but now there is an admission of the crisis. For example, only last week at the Harkness Health Conference here in Canberra, the Minister for Health said:

There are a lot of people in Australia who wait in pain and discomfort for procedures that they need. To them the definition `elective' means nothing. Now when I look at them I don't want to go to the lady that waits three years for a hip in Perth and tell her it was all part of the plan. I want a better plan than that, much better.
That is the plan he is now trying to bring in which is causing the great crisis and division within the party. Also, on that occasion, the minister said:

And it is going to come to a crunch point for those low income people who are in private health insurance very soon. It just isn't far away. We can all sit back and let it happen and say it doesn't matter. The argument I've heard proffered is, it doesn't really matter if private medicine is not there, we've still got a public system.
Presumably, this is the argument the minister is hearing in caucus. He went on:
But when you add millions of people into a public system which is already showing some strain in some places, you'll get problems.

The minister's words have been well documented on what will happen to low income and non-insured people if large numbers of people leave the private insurance system, as indeed they are—it will affect the battler, the person who cannot afford insurance.

PARA.TAB: Every time he opens his mouth on the subject, the minister acknowledges the importance of private insurance. Under the previous Minister for Health, the simple story of private insurance was that the percentage of the population that had private health insurance decreased by more than 20 per cent in the three-year period. Within the last week the figures from Senator Richardson's own lips were that, in September 1990, 61.5 per cent of the Australian population had some private health insurance, but it is now less than 39 per cent.

In the March-June 1993 quarter, the last quarter for which we have figures, 57,000 Australians dropped their private health insurance. It is this desertion of the private system in such numbers that has the minister so worried. The Labor propaganda no longer holds up. Those opposite cannot say that the Medicare system is adequate for Australians or does the job. They can only say that if there are enough Australians privately insured who are not using the public system. But when people can no longer afford insurance because costs are going up in the private sector and because no incentives are given to people to take out private insurance—people such as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on an income of more than $200,000 a year, will not pay the couple of grand it would cost to get the very best private insurance, and some people would say that people like him bludge on the system—that is what is putting the pressure on. This is what the minister knows must be addressed.
The minister has been very public on the importance of the private system. On 26 October, he said in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, we cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that it has in the past years because this does increase the strains on the public system.

That does sound to me suspiciously like the present Minister for Health disowning the previous Minister for Health. Senator Richardson has been one who has also recognised that it is not just high income earners for whom private health insurance has an attraction. There is enough disincentive in the public health system for even low income earners to have made the sacrifice to pay those high, unsubsidised fees to private insurance. He said in his speech to the conference last week:

. . . we must remember is that there are a lot of people in private health insurance who don't have much money. Not everyone who is privately insured is a rich guy, in fact there are a million families that earn less than $40,000 a year who have got private health insurance. Depending on who you believe somewhere being 13-20% are pensioners. . . 30% of those who have got private health insurance earn less than average weekly earnings.

PARA.TAB: They are the ones who struggle as premiums go up because people leave. People leave because in hard times (and we've had hard economic times here for some time) they find those premiums more difficult to meet, they find that discretionary expenditure more difficult to justify.

SPEECH.PARA: With every word that comes from this minister's lips he disowns the nonsense we were told a few minutes ago by the previous Minister for Health. The plan that the minister has been very up front in putting forward is a three-point plan: an increased Medicare levy for higher income earners, a single bill for in-hospital care for insured patients, and the amalgamation of insurance funds. That is the story he is trying to sell to his divided and confused back bench. The simple fact is that he has some entrenched opposition, and he has described it himself. He has said:

So I think we, as a party, ought to go back over our resolute opposition to the question of gap insurance. This always brings about shrieks of horror from those who authored the proposal and from those who defended them.
They are the ones who are making it difficult in caucus at the moment. But the minister has gone on to give this warning about his plan:

If it is rejected by the government, by the AMA, or by the people then we will all be accepting the private medicine will die, perhaps not so slowly, but an inevitable death over the course of the next decade. . .

That is the minister's prediction for the private health system, which is the only thing that enables the public health system to survive at all—a strong, healthy private system—if his plan is not accepted. He points out that there is some entrenched opposition, and that entrenched opposition is the ACTU—he has referred to that publicly, too—and the Australian Nurses Federation.

PARA.TAB: An honourable member interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Public Sector Union. The consequence of the opposition to the minister's program here is made clear. It is interesting that, in such a short period of time, the government has brought in a new minister who has moved so far away from the story that the Prime Minister and the government sold successfully to the people of Australia just last March. The people of Australia are about to discover just what were the flaws in the health system that the coalition was striving to meet and how similar the government—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) is a very nice fellow and, obviously, one of the moderates trying to achieve some changes in the Liberal Party. Nevertheless, the government is very puzzled by the fact that this matter of public importance is before us today. It is strange because it is well known that the proposals of the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) will go to cabinet probably later this week. The opposition is trying to make a political point on this matter by alleging division within the Labor Party before the proposals are presented to cabinet and caucus.

PARA.TAB: My first point is that the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) said that our support for Medicare is somehow changed by these proposals. Senator Richardson has made it very clear, time and again, that these proposals will not weaken Medicare; they will strengthen it. The suggestion that these proposals are somehow a move away from Medicare is nonsense. As the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) pointed out in his contribution to this debate, the opposition is the group that has tried to chop away at and undermine the basis of Medicare. The Labor Party has never done that, and Senator Richardson is not doing that. We are very united in our support for Medicare, so let me put that furphy out of the way to start with.

The second point that needs to be made is that, contrary to what the honourable member for Moncrieff said, we have recognised the issue of waiting lists in public hospitals. The honourable member for Moncrieff was not entirely honest in not noting that, as part of our campaign strategy, we promised $100 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is it?

—I will come to that. We promised $100 million towards meeting this problem. Senator Richardson is putting a proposal to cabinet for the use of that $100 million over three or four years. That money will be used for dealing with the issue. We were aware of the problem; we made an election promise and we will keep it. So much for that furphy from the honourable member for Moncrieff and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: What are we left with? The opposition has moved a motion against the government even before it knows what will be going forward. That is a pretty extraordinary position to take. Those opposite do not know what the proposals are, except in rough outline, yet they maintain that there is some huge division within the Labor Party on the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what the proposals are?

—Unlike the honourable member, I do. The proposals, which Senator Richardson has outlined to the media in general terms, consist of three parts. If there is any discussion, it will concern only one part. The other two parts of the proposals are very important and sensible. They will be key proposals for the balance of our health system. Why do I refer to `the balance of our health system'? The honourable member for Moncrieff suggested that the reduction in the number of people with private health insurance had something to do with Medicare. That is not so; it has to do with the way the private health system has been operating, particularly the private health insurance system.

PARA.TAB: This matter has been raised with me by people throughout Australia. Last Friday I was talking to a conference of independent retirees, most of whom have private health insurance. The fundamental problem is that people go into private health insurance and then, when they have to enter a private hospital, think that all their costs will be covered. How astounded they are at the end of the process, after they have left this private hospital—having paid Medicare and their private health insurance—when they get a fee from the hospital for $2,000 to $3,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not from the hospital.
—From the hospital or from the doctors. The reality is that they get those additional charges.
—You won't let them cover for it.

—The honourable member has had his go as a failed shadow minister in this area. Let me explain the situation, which is very clear, to the ordinary people: people want coverage if they find themselves in that position. For the first time, the minister's proposal will tackle head on the situation in which health insurance companies will have to cover all the charges in the private hospital, including the doctors' fees.
—You are going to change that. You are going to change your own law.

—What are we talking about? We are talking about reform, are we not? The reform that will come in will be directed towards the diagnostic related groups. The health insurance companies will negotiate packages for dealing with specific types of diagnostic related group situations, which will mean that there will be some capping of doctors' fees—not huge reductions in doctors' fees. There will be some capping in the cases where there are extraordinary charges; that is, where the charges are more than 100 per cent or so above the schedule fee and, in some cases, they are well over 100 per cent above the schedule fee, which is a disgraceful situation.

PARA.TAB: The vast majority of specialists and doctors will not have much to worry about in terms of their income. But there is a small minority who think that, because they are operating in a private hospital, they can charge whatever they like; therefore, health costs are increased. That matter will be dealt with and will be one of the major reforms.
Unless this matter is dealt with, private health system costs will explode. People might ask: why should the government worry about an explosion in private health system

SPEECH.PARA: costs? The reason is that there is an interrelationship between an explosion in costs in the private health system and the impact on public hospitals and on Medicare. The government simply cannot say, `That is the private system', and ignore the increased costs.

PARA.TAB: The health package put forward by the opposition before the last election would have been a bonanza for doctors. It would have encouraged them to charge much more than the schedule fee. It would have made the situation much worse and health costs in Australia would have been blown out in an enormous way. Contrary to what the honourable member for Moncrieff said, there is no doubt that the opposition has never come up with any scheme which would in any way cap doctors' fees. Because of that, the opposition has failed. The Richardson scheme is completely different from proposals that the opposition is putting forward.

Another key issue is the reduction in the number of private health insurance organisations. What is wrong with that? There is no problem with that. A reduction in the number of those organisations will lead to more efficiencies and administrative costs will be reduced. This will mean that the cost of private health insurance will be reduced or will not be increasing.With people dropping out of the private health insurance system, one of the concerns is that there will be increased costs for those who can least afford it. Those two aspects of the Richardson scheme are clearly very important and very useful and should be supported by the majority of Australians. We expect some opposition from some vested interests, from some doctors, but we do not expect opposition from most Australians who understand these matters.

As Senator Richardson has said, he will not ram through government the issue of the additional levy. He said that there will be a full-scale debate in the caucus on this issue and there will probably be a committee to examine it. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), other members of the government, as well as the caucus, will fully participate in this debate, as is the usual process within the Labor Party. Therefore, there is no case to answer. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.
—Please proceed.

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Dr Theophanous) made the statement, `The honourable member for Moncrieff spoke as though Medicare was to blame for problems with our health system'. I was very specific. The problem is the result of lack of incentives from the government for private insurance, plus economic hard times. The parliamentary secretary will search my speech in vain for his claims in relation to my speech.
—Order! The discussion has now concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, when this bill was debated in this House last month the minister accepted certain coalition amendments to it. Those amendments related to the need for a warrant for telecommunications interceptions in cases of emergency.

PARA.TAB: In the normal course of events, the act requires that a warrant be obtained before a signal may be intercepted. The bill sought to waive the warrant requirement in the case of participant monitoring in certain emergency situations. The coalition's amendments required that, where a warrant was not obtained in respect of the initiation of an interception, a warrant should be obtained as soon as practicable afterwards for the interception to be permitted to be continued.

The amendments resulted in protection of privacy rights and an increase in accountability on the part of law enforcement officers, while recognising the need for law enforcement officers to act swiftly in some cases. The amendments were passed by this House and also by the Senate. However, the Senate has made a small further amendment relating to the coalition amendments.

The normal warrant provisions under the act apply to what are defined as class 1 and class 2 offences. A law enforcement officer cannot apply for a warrant unless the suspected offence would constitute a class 1 or class 2 offence. These are the more serious categories of offences.

The difficulty perceived by the government with the coalition's amendments was the possibility that certain of the emergency situations in which a warrant would not initially be required might not constitute a class 1 or class 2 offence. The government has provided only two examples in this respect. The first is a situation in which a person threatens to kill another or others. In some jurisdictions this would constitute an offence, but would not carry a penalty of as much as seven years imprisonment or more, and would therefore not constitute a class 1 or class 2 offence. The second example is the threat to commit suicide. Attempted suicide is generally no longer an offence in Australian jurisdictions.

The government was concerned that there may be difficulty in obtaining the warrant to continue the interception as required by the opposition's amendments because the possible offence would not of itself justify the obtaining of a warrant under the normal or non-emergency warrant provisions of the act. In the limited situations where the emergency does not constitute a class 1 or class 2 offence, the government amendments deem the possible offence to constitute such an offence, but for the purpose of the retrospective warrant provisions only. Although there are alternative ways of dealing with these situations, the opposition will not oppose the further amendment. It does not vary the circumstances which constitute an emergency.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are now matters of no controversy at all. The outline that has been given by the shadow attorney-general reflects both the amendments moved originally in this House by the opposition and accepted by the government, and the small technical changes that were required in the Senate in order to deal with some matters which were oversighted in the haste with which those matters were progressed through this House. I am certain that the bill now meets the requirements of this House. I am pleased that the amendments now comprise a thorough package which will be welcomed by all those who are concerned with law enforcement and civil liberties.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill seeks to re-enact provisions of the Copyright Amendment Act 1989 in the Copyright Act 1968. The amending bill purported to impose royalties on blank recording tapes in order to recompense copyright holders for home audio taping. In addition, the amending bill introduced a number of other amendments, namely: (a) providing for statutory licence schemes for educational and other institutions to copy respectively television and radio broadcasts and print copyright works; (b) providing a range of performers' rights; (c) clarifying the relationship between the Copyright Act 1968 and the Designs Act 1906 regarding industrially applied artistic works; and (d) streamlining the statutory licence for recording musical works.

PARA.TAB: As we heard in the second reading speech on this bill, the imposition of a royalty on blank tapes was challenged in the High Court in the 1993 case of Australian Tape Manufacturers Association Ltd v. the Commonwealth. The challenge was upheld. The court decided, by majority, that the royalty was a tax. Thus, portions of the act were directly invalidated by the court pursuant to section 55 of the constitution.

The Chief General Counsel of Australia has advised the government that the invalid provisions are so inextricably linked with the valid provisions that the whole act is invalid. The effect of this bill will be to re-enact all the amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 made by the amending act, except those imposing and relating to the imposition of the blank tape royalty. The validation is retrospective, operating from the respective dates on which the various provisions of the amending act were proclaimed.

As a result of the High Court decision, there has been particular concern amongst those in industry and commerce who are affected by copyright matters that the legal and commercial arrangements put in place as a result of the 1989 amendments may now be in jeopardy. For that reason, the coalition does not oppose this bill. It is important that certainty attach to those arrangements. Those who relied upon the validity of the amending act should be protected from significant disruption to their arrangements.

I wish to comment, however, on certain amendments that were proposed by the opposition in relation to the amending act of 1988. Some of those proposals are still of relevance. When the amending bill was introduced in 1988, it was generally supported by the opposition. However, the opposition did move several amendments—some of which were adopted. Of the two bundles of proposed amendments which were not adopted, one related to the blank tape royalty provisions and is therefore no longer relevant.

The other bundle of proposed amendments related to the provisions clarifying the relationship between the Copyright Act 1968 and the Designs Act 1906. The problem these amendments sought to address was that it was thought that a number of industrial designs would slip between the Copyright Act and the Designs Act and they would not be protected. Prior to 1989, claims of copyright and manufactured three dimensional goods were commonly made. Such goods could also generally be protected under the Designs Act. In 1987 the government published a discussion paper that canvassed various options for reform and received submissions from copyright owners and industry. It was determined that copyright protection for three dimensional industrial products would be removed. It was considered that these products should be protected only under the designs legislation or other appropriate law.

The Designs Law Review Committee report on the law relating to designs had also reached this conclusion in 1973. The 1989 amendments had the general effect that artistic works are not protected by copyright if a design corresponding to the work is the subject of an application for design registration or has been applied to manufactured goods. In other words, a design applied to manufactured goods is not given simultaneous design and copyright protection, subject to certain exceptions.

The difficulty foreshadowed by the opposition in 1989 concerned the proposed section 77. It provides that where, firstly, copyright subsists in an artistic work, secondly, a corresponding design of that artistic work is applied industrially and articles to which the corresponding design has been applied are sold, and, thirdly, the corresponding design is not registered under the Designs Act, then it is not an infringement of the copyright in the artistic work to reproduce the work on or after the day on which the articles made to the corresponding design are first so sold, let for hire, or offered or exposed for sale or hire. The then shadow Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown, had advice to the effect that the result of these provisions would be to remove all protection from some industrial designs.

It is now clear that the provision has the greatest potential for injustice where the goods are sold or applied industrially overseas. The loss of Australian intellectual property protection in such a case is noted by the Australian Law Reform Commission in a discussion paper on designs released in April of this year. The commission comments:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . section 77 in effect denies copyright protection within Australia to the Australian copyright owner in the event of overseas sales or industrialisation by the foreign copyright owner in that jurisdiction.

The amendments proposed by the opposition in 1988 sought to prevent the provisions of that part of the bill from coming into operation until the government reviewed the Designs Act to prevent potential loss of protection. The coalition's concerns over the relationship between the Designs Act and the Copyright Act remain. However, in this instance the coalition has determined that it is necessary to ensure passage of this bill to protect industry and business which relied on the validity of the 1989 amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments to Australia's intellectual property laws should be pursued. The discussion paper released by the Australian Law Reform Commission, to which I referred above, seeks comment as a basis of a thorough review of our design laws. Relevant to the present discussion, it describes questions of overlap between copyright and designs protection as `among the most vexed areas of intellectual property with considerable uncertainty in several key areas'. The opposition looks forward to the Australian Law Reform Commission's report on the Designs Act and a well-considered legislative response by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Copyright Amendment (Re-enactment) Bill. As has been noted by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), the bill's provisions do not effect any change or new initiative. Our normal statement would be that this is much ado about nothing; I suspect this is nothing ado about much. The amendments are directed solely to re-enact all the amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 made by the Copyright Amendments Act 1989 except those imposing and related to the imposition of the blank audiotape royalty.

PARA.TAB: This bill has become necessary because of the decision handed down by the High Court in the case of Australian Tape Manufacturers Association Ltd v. the Commonwealth. This case was concerned with a challenge to the validity of the imposition of a royalty on blank audiotapes. The court held, by majority, that the royalty levied on vendors of blank tapes was a tax. In consequence, it was invalid by reason of non-compliance with section 55 of the constitution. So this means that this bill is purely technical in nature. The invalidity of the provisions of the act is an unexpected and unfortunate result of the High Court challenge to just one part of a raft of significant measures.

I will make a few comments about the need for copyright laws to keep pace with changes in technology. I know that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has turned his attention to these issues. There is a growing importance of intellectual property in the international economy as we move from a commodity based economy to a services based economy. It is a critical time for the copyright community, because technological change will alter the fundamental nature of copyright. We will soon be able to receive films and sound recordings down information highways via cable or satellite. This will mean many changes to the way in which we currently use CDs, videotapes, books, information and entertainment media. The government will continue to work with the copyright community to ensure that the copyright regime is capable of handling these changes, and it is committed to maintaining a copyright regime that is recognised as one of the best in the world.

The Copyright Act has already been extensively amended during the life of this government, as the honourable member for Tangney has also mentioned. The amendments reflect the active government attention to the needs of copyright owners and users. The main areas of amendments have included substantially increased piracy penalties; the introduction of performance protection; streamlining of the licences to educational institutions; and explicit extension of copyright protection to computer programs. During this year's election campaign, the government signalled that it would make further considered changes to the Copyright Act, and I understand that my ministerial colleagues have already begun the work on the implementation of those changes. The government will continue to ensure that legislation keeps pace with technological change so that intellectual property is protected. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerr) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Mr Gear:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill seeks to extend the government's One Nation development allowance to benefit the motor vehicle industry and the production side of the print media. Because investments now to qualify for the development allowance were originally excluded, this bill reopens the application period for the allowance which had closed at the end of last year.

PARA.TAB: Claimants in these industries seeking to take advantage of the reopened application process for the development allowance will have to meet competitiveness tests set for work practices and input pricing. These tests were waived under the original legislation for projects that could demonstrate a substantial commitment to completion prior to the end of last year, for reasons not unrelated to the timing of the last federal election—and I will come to that in a moment. The additional allowances provided for in this legislation will otherwise be subject to the provisions of the original development allowance legislation.

The coalition opposed the development allowance from the outset. We will continue to draw attention to its considerable shortcomings as a means of bringing about business investment in this country. In opposing the development allowance, the coalition was particularly concerned about the blatantly political way in which the allowance has been used by Labor to further its re-election prospects.

The development allowance was originally featured in the government's One Nation economic statement early last year, which became a large part of the platform on which it contested the most recent federal election. Of course, since the election, that platform has been largely ignored. I refer by way of example to the bulk of the personal income tax cuts that were promised to the Australian people in that statement. All we have left are the dregs of that pseudo-policy, such as the development allowance and the failed pooled development funds and infrastructure bonds initiatives. `Let them eat infrastructure', Labor might well say in the wake of the last election.

From the beginning, the development allowance was designed to give the Labor Party a few big ticket investment projects that it could tout during the election as false evidence of a recovery in business investment and a sign of general economic recovery. It was no accident that the deadline for the applications for the development allowance was set at the end of 1992, and that the competitiveness test in the legislation was waived for those projects that were submitted before that magic date.

The theory was to entice businesses to get their investment projects out of the top drawer where they had been sitting and into the open where the government could use them for its own short-term, politically expedient ends. Obviously, any prudent business organisation that thought it had a project that might be eligible for the allowance was obliged to rush forward with an application so that it would have the option of taking up the allowance at some time in the future.

This was the basis for the government's greatly exaggerated claims of an investment avalanche—which I am sure you will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker—uttered before and during the most recent federal election campaign. Labor touted billion dollar figures as to the supposed sum total of these mythical investment projects. All of this additional investment was supposedly attributable to the actions of the government and a meagre 10 per cent allowance for expenditure on new plant for qualifying projects. No such investment avalanche has taken place and nor would one expect even a trickle to be generated by such a meagre concession.

All that the investment allowance served to do was bring out into the open some of the forward planning of some Australian firms for larger and already conceived investment projects. Most of these projects were well advanced in conception and would have gone ahead anyway. What the development allowance enabled the government to do was take credit for investments that it really had no role in facilitating. That is all that the development allowance has so far contributed to further business investment in this country.

The politically motivated nature of the development allowance is amply revealed by the fact that, prior to the last election, the then Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and now Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was deputised to oversee the administration of the Development Allowance Authority. The man who put his signature on signs all over New South Wales when he was a minister in that state Labor government was an obvious choice for administering Labor's opportunistic development allowance.

The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was directly involved in the administration of the allowance—something that one would normally expect to be the purview of what was then the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Presumably DITAC could not be relied on to give a suitably political focus to the activities of the Development Allowance Authority. Obviously honesty and propriety in DITAC meant it could not be relied on to do Labor's bidding. It is said that the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister had a chart on his wall indicating the progress being made with the various projects that were to be the beneficiaries of the allowance—perhaps the ultimate example of the process of the government picking winners run amok.

While many of these projects are certainly worthwhile ventures, it must give cause for concern when progress is being individually tracked on the walls of a politician's office. It is hard to believe the then Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister had such a close personal interest in business investment unless it had some direct benefit to what was then Labor's principal preoccupation: winning the last federal election by hook or by crook.

There are good reasons for believing the development allowance has not made a significant impact in bringing on additional investment in this country, quite apart from the blatantly political origins of the scheme. At best, it has served to assist projects that would have gone ahead anyway. As already indicated, with the exception of investments provided for in this bill, any applications for the development allowance would have had to have been submitted sometime between February and December 1992.

It is extremely unlikely that 10 months is sufficient time to conceive and develop from taws a new $50 million plus investment project—$50 million being the minimum above which projects were to be considered for the development allowance. Instead, the development allowance promised to merely bring forward projects that would have already been well advanced in conception, if not implementation, before the One Nation statement was handed down some 20 months ago.

From Labor's point of view, this is exactly what the development allowance was designed to achieve. But if many of these projects were going to go ahead anyway, as we have every reason to believe, then all the government succeeded in doing was giving away revenue to a few select businesses, with no apparent benefit to increased business investment overall. In any event, the benefits to the companies concerned are not particularly great. A once-only tax deduction of 10 per cent of a company's expenditure on qualifying new plant works out at only 3.9c for every dollar spent, under the former company tax rate.

It is hard to believe that such a sum would be decisive in determining the viability of a new project. It would be a serious concern if such a small benefit were to be decisive in the way Labor would have us believe. Projects operating that close to the margin of viability are risky propositions. The government has tried to claim that some projects needed the development allowance to make them viable, which makes one wonder about the quality of the projects that the allowance will support.

Of all the features of the development allowance, the $50 million threshold is the aspect that has probably attracted the most criticism. The total capital cost threshold is quite arbitrary and obviously highly distortionary in its effects on investment decisions by firms that might be able to benefit from the allowance. It encourages the vertical integration of production processes for the purpose of claiming the allowance, even though such integration may not be optimal in terms of a particular production process.

Highly efficient and productive capital projects which just happen to fall below the $50 million capital cost threshold do not qualify for the allowance. Unfortunately for them, the government is only interested in the big ticket items that pump up the prospective investment statistics and look flash enough for election campaign purposes. The result is a potential misallocation of resources in favour of larger investment projects, at the expense of smaller, potentially more productive projects, and at the cost of overall economic efficiency.

The development allowance is in many ways overly restrictive if what one is trying to do is provide a significant measure of support for business investment in this country. Qualifying projects are restricted to those that are deemed by the government to be direct contributors to the traded goods sector. Investment projects in the services or tertiary sector are excluded from any consideration whatsoever. This is part of the cargo cult that has grown up around manufacturing and value adding in the traded goods sector, at the expense of other sectors of the economy.

The services sector is in many ways equally productive and it is often in this sector that our comparative advantage as a country lies. But it gets ignored under legislation such as this, largely, one suspects, because of the limited imagination of the people who think up these schemes in the first place. In order for the investment allowance to make any worthwhile contribution to increased business investment in this country, it would need to be much broader in scope, as well as higher.

The scheme would have to be extended to something like 10 years to really bring about investment projects that otherwise will not see the light of day. That is the planning horizon along which most large investment projects are determined. Most such projects are not put together in the space of 10 months and require certainty and predictability before implementation. `Now you see them, now you don't' tax concessions are not going to have a substantial impact on long-term business investment.

The development allowance would have to be increased to something like 20 per cent to have a significant impact on decisions to proceed with investment projects. If a large number of projects were to be facilitated in such a way, one would need to lower the minimum capital cost threshold to something like $30 million to have a significant impact across the broad spectrum of business investment activity. Such a development allowance, with more liberal eligibility criteria, might have had a worthwhile impact on business investment in Australia. Unfortunately, it would also have been highly distortionary, for reasons I have already indicated, and it would have implicated the government in the process of picking winners to an even greater extent than is already attempted in the relevant legislation.

The government claims that the development allowance is not about picking winners, yet the legislation has been structured in such a way that it is an inevitable consequence of its operation. The government, by its own admission, is directing investment into certain types of economic activity and into projects of a particular size and being carried out by particular firms.

The development allowance is supposedly designed to benefit projects that pass various competitiveness tests, yet these tests were waived entirely for the first round of applicants, to bring them out into the open ahead of the last election. This begs the question as to why those projects needed special tax breaks if they were already world competitive, as the government would have us believe. Such projects should not require assistance from the Commonwealth in the form of tax breaks that must ultimately be paid for by other taxpayers, who will have to bear a heavier tax burden in consequence.

However, if these projects are less than world competitive, we should be even less inclined to support them in this way. The then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, in his second reading speech to the Development Allowance Authority Bill last year, said that the development allowance could be used by firms to `negotiate progress against a broad best practice agenda', which suggests that the firms concerned are less than world competitive at the time of the granting of the allowance and still have some way to go before meeting a particular criterion.

Overall, this legislation reeks of the now thoroughly discredited practice of Labor attempting to pick winners in industry policy. The government has made it abundantly clear in its own descriptions of the operation of this legislation. In the minister's second reading speech to the original legislation he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Put simply, the development allowance rewards success and represents a conscious rejection of those policies of the past which underwrote loss and failure.

So this legislation is designed to `reward success'—the very essence of picking winners. What the minister conveniently forgot is that those policies of the past to which he referred also sought to reward success in much the same way as the development allowance. The fact that those policies of the past ended up underwriting loss and failure was an entirely unintended consequence of those policies. Governments then thought they were backing winners, just as Labor today thinks it is supporting winning projects with these measures. One can only hope that the government is more successful in picking winners this time around than some of its predecessors have been, although its own record in office gives us every reason to be pessimistic on that score.

PARA.TAB: In any event, taxpayers have no duty, at the insistence of Labor, to underwrite successful or unsuccessful businesses and projects. Successful projects and businesses simply do not need support. Unsuccessful businesses do not deserve such support and should be allowed to fail if that is to be their ultimate fate. The government cannot help attempting to pick winners through legislation such as this. The government is inevitably involved in making decisions as to exactly which projects and firms will become beneficiaries of the development allowance. In so doing, Labor's preferences and judgments will inevitably intrude into the process, so the government cannot help falling into the trap of attempting to pick winners.
The then Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister said as much last year when speaking to a Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill in this place. He said of the legislation then:

SPEECH.PARA: It is assistance not about picking winners but about rewarding and encouraging the proven winners, the people who create wealth for Australia.

PARA.TAB: But who decides according to the legislation? Who are the proven winners to be encouraged and rewarded with the likes of the development allowance? It is the government that decides. Hence the chart on the wall of the then parliamentary secretary tracking the winners, but with no apparent regard to the opportunity cost of the benefits bestowed on those so-called winners.

Labor is very fond of selective industry assistance. It is, no doubt, a belief in the effectiveness of such assistance that is partly motivating the government with the development allowance and some of the other One Nation initiatives, such as the pooled development funds and the infrastructure bonds, both of which have been something of a flop. The Industry Commission has made some important criticisms of such assistance in its 1989-90 annual report, criticisms based on the experience of east Asian countries with such assistance, including directed investment. The government could do well to take some of those criticisms into account and embrace some of the more important micro-economic reform proposals that could make a real contribution to increasing the level of business investment in this country.

If the government wants to promote investment in Australia, the way to do it is not through the selective conferral of benefits on the particular projects of particular firms. Any such benefits should be general in nature so that all potential investment projects in this country stand to benefit. In this way, there are no distortionary effects on economic activity and everyone is treated equally.
