The other thing that the government could do is get serious about taking some of the costs off business. In particular, our businesses need to be relieved of some of the burdens of government at all levels. When Australian industry is relieved of paying for the special privileges of the few industries and firms favoured by government, Australia will have that much more investment and will be that much more competitive as a result. Unfortunately, the government's most recent budget not only fails to take costs off business but also adds a few new ones just for good measure. That will be the principal legacy of its most recent budget.

Those opposite need to come to the realisation that it is not within the capacity of government to identify investments, businesses or industries that are successful, or likely to remain that way in the future. It is, therefore, not within its capacity to selectively provide assistance to such investments which is in any way going to be helpful to the Australian economy. To the extent that the government gets it wrong, as it is bound to, it will be downright unhelpful.

In considering these matters, governments and their bureaucrats have no special insights that are not available to the investors themselves. More commonly, governments are thoroughly ignorant of the marketplace and the legislated demands placed on industry. If governments have no special knowledge in these matters, they have nothing to contribute to the judgments that entrepreneurs already make in a market context on a daily basis.

For the most part, private investors themselves are unsure of the future success of a project with which they may be involved. The knowledge required to make such judgments is dispersed in the marketplace and becomes available to the investor only after the investment has been made and the product or service is marketed. Even then there is no accounting for what shifts will take place in the market, which will completely change the viability of the underlying investment.

Government has no business in underwriting or otherwise selectively contributing to investments made by the private sector. However, there are many things a government can do to help investment in this country. They largely consist of getting out of the way of business and letting it get on with the job of investing and producing. Government should feel free to grant tax concessions to investment projects, businesses and industries. But these benefits must be available across the board so that everyone is treated equally and so that the government does not become involved in directing investment into preferred areas or, even worse, to selected individual firms. The judgments government makes in this context will inevitably prove to be misplaced and will be made at great cost to the people who ultimately have to pay for those decisions.

The fact that the government is persisting with its development allowance and marginally expanding it after the election campaign is over may suggest that the government is really conducting something more than just a purely political exercise of the type that I have already described. Nevertheless, Labor is still beholden to the nostrums of selective industry assistance that have misled so many governments in the past, both here and abroad. It has not learned the lessons of the past and seems determined to repeat mistakes that have been made by this government and many of its predecessors. Unfortunately, the real costs of this legislation and measures like it will be borne only long after this government is dead and buried.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Development Allowance Authority Bill. This bill amends the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 and is intended to extend the development allowance to projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media. These amendments reopen the application period for projects in the motor vehicle industry and the print media that were previously excluded from the development allowance. The amendments reflect commitments made during the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: While extending the eligibility of the development allowance to such projects, these amendments also ensure that projects relating to these two industries meet competitiveness tests in relation to work practices and input pricing, very important matters in relation to any government policy. As the law currently stands, these tests could be waived where the project sponsor is able to show that, prior to 1 January 1993, there was substantial commitment to completion of the project. That is, these amendments would provide that, irrespective of whether there was substantial commitment to completion before 1 January, to be eligible for the development allowance projects in the motor vehicle industry and the printing production aspect of projects in the print media would have to meet the competitiveness tests.

When this bill was debated in the Senate, an opposition amendment was passed to insert a section 6 into the act, which would remove the $50 million threshold test from projects in the motor vehicle industry and the print media. The government is opposed to that amendment and will be moving an amendment to reinsert the $50 million threshold.

The opposition argued that the existing allowance discriminates against small projects in favour of large projects. This is precisely its policy intent. The allowance was introduced as part of the One Nation statement as a targeted incentive to encourage large and internationally competitive projects to help get the economy moving again. It is to that area that I want to address my remarks.

It is interesting to listen to the debate and to hear speakers from the opposition talking about governments keeping out of industry and not trying to pick winners. This government has, since 1983 with the float of the dollar, moved this economy from a very inward looking economy based behind tariff walls to one which is now looking out nationally and internationally to the world markets, an economy which for many years was dominated by the conservative parties of Australia who consistently attempted to pick winners and to develop industry and keep industry behind tariff walls. We are paying the price for that today because the restructuring of the Australian economy has certainly been a very grave issue. It has been one that has tested the abilities of the work force in this nation. It has certainly tested the abilities of the ACTU and all those in our union movement in relation to how they would adapt to the structural change that has occurred.

Nobody has responded better to this restructuring than have the working people of Australia and the trade union movement. We are watching the greatest restructure in union numbers in Australia that we have ever seen. We are going from a real craft union structure across to a very modern based ACTU with limited numbers of unions with speciality operations. That is because the policies of this government have been worked out in conjunction with the ACTU and the working people of Australia, and certainly it is not an easy job. It is certainly a very trying operation for both the government and the bureaucrats—and for the union leaders to try to explain to their members what the total packages are that are being put into place and why it is that on many occasions we are seeing thousands of jobs disappearing in one sector and slowly being developed in another sector.

The policy intent of this legislation is to attract the sorts of large investments into Australia which can and will get the economy going. This is a favourite subject of mine. I represent the electorate of McMillan. Within that electorate is the State Electricity Commission of Victoria which, either today or tomorrow, will have its name changed when the new state legislation comes into effect. The Victorian government has broken down that institution into Generation Victoria, National Electricity and Electricity Services Victoria. The changes have been dramatic and very important. Without them, I do not believe that Australia could match it with the South-East Asian economies.

We have heard members of the opposition talking about the government trying to pick winners. This government has spent 10 or 11 years trying to break down the policy structures that the opposition had in place when it was in government—a government continually trying to pick winners when it came to where industry should be established. That approach was all right in its day but it is totally wrong now when the economy is moving into international operations and when we have the opportunity and skills to sell our products on the world market.

There are other matters influencing our ability to attract the sort of investment—over $50 million and up to $500,000 million, $600,000 million and $700,000 million—that is needed for Australia to prosper, and I would like to talk about them. Our competitors in South-East Asia are attracting investment from large industries and will continue to do so because they are offering great incentives for those companies to go into those areas. Malaysia is one country which is booming because of the investment flowing into that country.

In the Latrobe Valley in my electorate the work force of the old SEC has dropped from 20,000 to 10,000, while the work force locally has gone from 10,000 to 5,000. One of the reasons we have not attracted investment is that the economy there is based on the old idea that we will go on forever behind tariff walls. We are now facing up to reality, and the reality is that, while we live in that region, we are still paying the market price for telecommunications. No industry operating in the Latrobe Valley can send a fax for the cost of a local call; we have to pay distance rates because of our distance from Melbourne. Likewise, the transport industry is affected by fuel prices, with the market reflecting the price of fuel. Cartage rates to my electorate also reflect the price of fuel. However, when we look at the reverse situation, nothing reflects. The cost of electricity to a company in my region is exactly the same as it is for a company in a National Party area in Mildura or in Portland in the western district.

I am very keen for us to start talking reality. There are half a dozen areas of Australia with the sort of magnificent natural resources that can match it with South-East Asia in attracting investment. We need to remove any impediments that would stop industries from assessing an area as having the economic and structural facilities necessary to attract their investment. And what sort of things are they looking at? Firstly, as the companies themselves tell us, gas, fuel and electricity prices are three of the major inputs to any very large manufacturing operation. Very large operators use a lot of power and energy and—in the case of the paper industry—a lot of gas. In our region, where we are only hundreds of yards from a natural resource—in fact, we have a power station sitting right on top of the natural resource—we are expected to pay for transmission costs to other parts of the nation. There is no competitive advantage with which our region can approach these large companies. When they do, they say, `Well, the problem is that there is no advantage in going to your area because you are still asking us to pay the same prices for your fuel'.

While this legislation is attempting to encourage people to come to Australia and to invest in very large projects, we still have to work through the issues which will make the difference in the final analysis. That difference will be the gas prices, petrol prices and labour costs that are available to industry in those regions. The federal government, through its OLMA committee, recently funded a detailed study by the Symes Business College of Monash University College Gippsland. It surveyed a large number of companies as to what they regarded as the main impediments to investing in our region, and the results were very interesting.

There are perceptual problems which we will have to work on. The major image problem is that the area is an old industrial area. For many years, the only publicity we got in the Melbourne newspapers was to do with industrial relations problems—something we have not heard of locally for three to five years now. That was the last time we had a dispute which cost any time in labour, but we have to get out and sell that message.

The other issues are there for both state and federal governments to deal with. There is a study being done right now on electricity pricing. That paper study is running into some problems with the conservative government in New South Wales. There are also some bad signals coming from Victoria to the effect that the very people who want to hide behind tariff walls—in this case it is not so much a tariff wall as a subsidy to another part of the state—are the same people who are starting to buck and kick. In other words, the National Party rump of the conservatives are saying to the Liberals, `You need our vote, so do not touch our subsidies'. That is a very detrimental policy for Australia today when we are in direct competition with some of the biggest investment areas of South-East Asia.

At a time when we want to make the best use of our forest resource, at a time when we want a $300 million or $400 million investment in the Latrobe Valley region, we cannot clinch the deal because gas and electricity prices are still reflecting those National Party subsidies across the nation. We need to work hard to remove them. In New South Wales, we have the Pacific Power situation, and a state minister in charge of energy who is having great difficulty because his National Party friends are pushing very hard to keep the status quo.

The political fight is not over in Australia, not by a long shot, butAustralia needs to become nationally and internationally competitive. We can talk all day about wages and labour costs, the things that everybody has focused on for the last 10 years—we have made great strides in those areas—but we now need to focus on the real issues of our basic resources, the advantage those resources give us, and how to pass on that advantage to investors so that they are not immediately asked to pass on a subsidy to somebody else. Those are not the sorts of costs that these industries can afford to carry. They are not the sorts of costs that we can afford to impose upon them if we want to attract investment into this nation because our competitors for this type of investment are not Australian, they are South-East Asian competitors. The half a dozen regions of Australia which have competitor advantage must get together, take full advantage of it and remove the impediments and the obstacles to investment.

Next week the Kelty report, the first of a number of major reports, will be coming down. The Industry Commission report will come down later, followed by employment committee discussions. All of these issues are important. Last Thursday in my area, I chaired a meeting attended by all the CEOs who work with me on the task force drawn from our local government, local industry, Monash Gippsland and our TAFE—two training bodies with a very large training operation in the area—to discuss this issue. It is our intention in the new year to initiate discussions with other areas across Australia that have natural resources. It is only by areas with natural resource benefits coming together and making them known to government, bureaucracy and the public in general that this debate will be won.

Restructuring has been going on for ten years, and I believe that this debate has been lost in that overall context. I also have one grave fear: in the last stages of the restructure, exploitation of the political process could stop us proceeding with the total process because enough so-called damage has been done. The last thing that I want to say—I impress this upon everybody—is that I have seen the 5,000 people in my area who have suffered from the restructure—I have seen them pay the price to this point in time—but I still have not seen industry coming in to replace the 5,000 jobs that were lost. We have not seen anything to indicate that we have a natural resource which can be exploited for the benefit of Australia as a whole.

We still have a tendency to think, `If we do this, if we start reflecting electricity prices truly, somebody else is going to have to pay somewhere else'. Maybe there are people out in the dairy industry or in some other industry in the rural sector—I am one of them; I have a dairy farm; I believe that those subsidy days are over—who think that we must reflect the true price of our natural resource. We could get away with it while we were sitting inside the comfy area of tariff walls of Australia, but we will no longer be able to get away with it in the future. I will take every opportunity I have to get on my feet and to push this element.

I can assure honourable members that after Christmas, early in the New Year, our region will be starting a campaign to solidly work with other regions of Australia which have a natural resource and which need to band together. We may have to go across political lines to do this. We are going to put the metal on some of the honourable members in those areas who, naturally, would see a benefit for their areas but, politically, will have a problem with the politics of their organisations which may perhaps have the numbers elsewhere to overrule them. I stress in this House again and again that this is a major issue. Let us not ask people to pay the price and then not go on with it and have the benefits relayed to countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia and others which are picking up the ball and running with it very strongly.

In conclusion, I make the comment that the Senate, in trying to remove the $50 million threshold for projects, is saying that the bias would be moved from large programs to small projects and to small projects in those two industries against small projects in other industries. There does not appear to be any good reason why small projects in those sectors should be favoured over small projects in other sectors.

In summary, the opposition amendments interfere with the fundamental design feature of the development allowance—the threshold. This significantly complicates the administration of the development allowance for no good purpose, would be an additional cost to the budget—in many cases for projects that have already commenced—and reduces the degree of targeting in the assistance provided. Against this, the amendment offers few benefits. Accordingly, the government will be moving an amendment to this bill to delete clause 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1993 is flawed legislation. This is the second set of amendments in just 12 months to what has been, arguably, another One Nation idea that did not make the grade. It is estimated that this set of amendments will cost $9 million in 1994-95, $11 million in 1995-96 and $14 million in 1996-97. While the coalition is not opposing this bill, there is little evidence that the development allowance has lifted the amount of private investment, although it may act to bring forward some expenditure. There was also no evidence that manufacturing employment has been boosted by the development allowance or by any other government promise.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the One Nation statement should really have been called the One Job statement. The development allowance was really aimed at trying to make the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his party look good in the lead-up to the March election. Sadly, that is one of the aims which the development allowance did apparently help to achieve. Who can forget the Prime Minister's boast? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So we have got the growth, we have got the investment sitting there, 130 billion, enormous, an absolute avalanche, and once it starts to go, the economy starts to move. That's what it's all about.
In the same extraordinary bout of campaign fever at a 4 March doorstop, he said:
. . . even if a modest proportion of them goes, it is going to be a huge avalanche of investment . . .
The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) was a bit close to the truth when he said:
Well I think I said earlier it won't be only a trickle, it will be a steady stream.

The investment we had sitting there, in reality, was $27 billion in capital value and nearly $22.5 billion in plant at the time of the DAA's fifth quarterly report. While that is a healthy figure, it is only a fraction of the amount that the Prime Minister was touting as a fait accompli in March. Honourable members should also note the view of the Australian Mining Industry Council Executive Director, Lauchlan McIntosh. He said that his industry was already investing $5 billion or $6 billion a year, which should add up to, in the long term, about the same amount likely to be spent on mining under the development allowance. In other words, the development allowance has done little to create investment that would not, under normal circumstances, have gone ahead in the mining industry anyway.

PARA.TAB: The development allowance has largely failed to stimulate private investment. Business investment this financial year is forecast to be only just above its 1989-90 level, after three years in the doldrums. The forecast for business investment growth for one-quarter of one per cent is not what we would call a robust recovery. It also means that the government's pump-priming attempt in February 1992 has had little effect. The Prime Minister's claim that Australia will benefit from an avalanche of investment looks very dubious when we consider that virtually every big Australian company with an eye for the commercial opportunity would have registered every possible project before the development allowance deadline. That means that at least some of the projects which are the subject of the DAA applications will never see the light of day.

The process involved in claiming the development allowance has basically been three steps. The first step is an application for registration. In the case of this amendment, application for the development allowance on certain projects in the motor vehicle and print media industries will be accepted until the 29th day after this bill has received royal assent. Step two of the process is for the Development Allowance Authority to satisfy itself that the projects meet the development allowance criteria and grant registration. Up to 30 September, some 121 projects had been registered—up to half of them on a conditional basis for reasons the DAA has not given. A total of 16 applications have been rejected for reasons including failure to meet the $50 million investment threshold.

That $50 million threshold seems strangely at odds with the feel-good exercise conducted by the government in the wake of the McKinsey report into emerging exporters. That report has been waved around by everyone in government—from the Prime Minister down—as if it were the saviour of Australian exporting. What the report actually found was that there were 700 small- to medium-sized firms emerging as exporters and that 6,200 similar firms did not export.

I am not knocking the achievement of the 10 per cent of firms which have succeeded in becoming exporters or knocking those among the 90 per cent which were working towards import replacement. What I am saying is that with all the opportunities that Australia has had over the last 10 years or so, it is a damning indictment of the government policies that there are not more than 700 small- to medium-sized firms succeeding in exporting. Even though the small- to medium-sized enterprises have been touted by the government as the future direction for Australian exporting, policies such as the development allowance do absolutely nothing for these businesses. The $50 million investment threshold was relaxed a little in the first round of amendments to the development allowance when changes were made to allow applicants to aggregate two or more joint venture projects or specified projects.

Just to recap, the first thing that is wrong with the development allowance is that it is expected to cost Australian taxpayers approximately $40 million in 1994-95 and $70 million in 1995-96. However, there is little evidence that this has been spent on investment which would not otherwise have taken place. The second thing that is wrong with the development allowance is the fact that it is directed solely at big business. It not only discriminates against the very businesses which are supposed to be providing Australia with the way out of the economic quagmire, but it also discriminates against particular industries.

The argument in the original, flawed Development Allowance Authority Act was that the allowance would apply to only those industries where there was an effective rate of assistance of 10 per cent or less. Yet we had the Prime Minister apparently suffering a rush of blood to the head during the election campaign and deciding that the allowance should be extended to the motor vehicle industry. Quite clearly, this industry has an effective rate of assistance of more than 10 per cent.

I am not arguing that the motor vehicle industry should not be included in the development allowance. I am saying that, if an exception is to be made for one industry, why not for all industries? This selective discrimination makes the Development Allowance Authority Act look more and more like it was thrown together at a pre-election brainstorming session than carefully constructed as a focused piece of industry policy. Another flaw in the government's approach to business investment is that it largely fails to achieve one of the supposed aims of the One Nation policy, which is jobs growth.

I earlier discussed the first two steps that projects must go through to obtain the 10 per cent deduction under the development allowance. The third step is for registered projects to obtain pre-qualifying certificates, which the businesses concerned can then present to the Australian Taxation Office as proof that they have satisfied the criteria for the development allowance.

In its September quarterly report, the Development Allowance Authority stated that it had issued four pre-qualifying certificates. Under the original terms of the DAA Act, projects must have begun by 30 June 1996. So either these projects are slow getting going and we will see the Prime Minister's avalanche of activity which should by then be a well established recovery or many of them will never take place.

The government is undoubtedly hoping there is a wave of activity in late 1995 and the first half of 1996, accompanied by a surge in employment. After all, the next federal election is due by March 1996. The result of this apparently very long lead-time is that, like other government promises, the development allowance has failed to make a dent in our unacceptably high unemployment levels.

In fact, since the `One Nation, One Job' statement was launched in February 1992, employment in manufacturing has fallen. What is more, business expectations published recently by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that manufacturers expect to continue shedding jobs in both the short term and medium term. Australia's investment and jobless situation are catastrophes for the people this government has forgotten.

While we do not oppose these amendments, it is patently clear that, if we ever see any benefit from the development allowance, it will be too late to save thousands of Australians from the pain and indignity of joining the growing queue of long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is aware of the history of the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill which amends the Development Allowance Authority Act—part of a commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the last federal election campaign.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the beginning of the development assistance scheme. On 26 February 1992, in its One Nation statement, the government came forward with a plan to supplement the accelerated depreciation allowance for plant and equipment. In its One Nation statement, the government said that the development assistance would be at the rate of 10 per cent and allowed when plant is first installed ready for use. It would be modelled broadly on the investment allowance that operated between 1976 and 1985; and to be eligible for this allowance projects must involve a total capital cost of $50 million or more and must be completed within a tight time frame. The government said that the allowance would be available only on the plant and equipment component of the investment.

In its One Nation policy, the government proposed an extension of the allowance because it felt somewhat threatened by the industry sensitive policies developed by the opposition. In order to stand squarely with industry, the government firstly introduced an acceleration of the appreciation allowance and then the development allowance to supplement what it thought would be increased investment and job opportunities in manufacturing industries.

The government went on in its One Nation statement to indicate that the first criteria intended to identify projects must relate to the absence of any substantial assistance or protection. Looking at the bill, the substantial assistance or protection criteria has been dumped completely. The government has chosen to support one of the highly protected industries in Australia, namely, the automobile industry. So other significant factors came into play during the election campaign.

The second criteria relates to the positive facilitation of projects by state and local governments as a way of locking people in. The third criteria is that employers and employees must be committed to management and industrial relations arrangements which promote the achievement of world best practice. The government has designated some queer criteria for the development allowance.

In its One Nation statement, the government said that Mr Bill Scales, chairperson, then Chief Executive, of the Automotive Industry Authority, would report to the government within 30 days, advising on how best to elaborate upon the criteria set out. In other words, the government had an idea which it did not know how to put into action, so it asked somebody else to look at it on its behalf. In the One Nation statement, the government said that Mr Bill Scales would determine the most appropriate institutional arrangements for administering the development allowance. So there was the rush of blood to the head—`We have a good idea which we do not know how to implement, and these are the industries to which the allowance will apply. Then we will consider the most appropriate institutional arrangements for getting the funds to those eligible businesses'.

The government claimed that the most likely industries to produce results for Australia were those which add value to our rich resource base. These included: the food fibre and mineral processing industries; the waste and environmental management technologies; scientific and medical equipment; health services; pulp and paper; and tourism and education. So the government looked across the spectrum of where it was encouraging industrial research and development and said, `Those are the types of industries that we think should have the advantage of the development allowance'.

So the government devised three criteria, appointed somebody to develop them and said, `These are the industries to which these criteria will apply'. That is a strange way for a government to make decisions—no investigation and proper designation of the benefits and, ultimately, the cost and advantage to the Australian community. It is wrong to throw money at industries in the hope of obtaining results. It is like the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) throwing money at sporting and community groups, hoping to produce results. It is exactly the same parallel and the purposes are exactly the same, nothing more and nothing less—to gain a political result. No economic objective and criteria were laid down to produce a measurable result. This bill is a purely political program, like the sports program administered by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.

Now Mr Bill Scales, the Chief Executive of the Automotive Industry Authority, is trying to dress up the development allowance and make it look good. Of course industry will accept this money. For the last three years things have been so desperate in manufacturing industries that those industries will rush for an opportunity for a little relief, for a little succour from this government which has constantly slammed these industries with increasing costs and increasingly anti-competitive decisions, foisted upon the industries in such a way that they have been the big losers of jobs.

So the Australian community has suffered. The government, in foisting bad news on manufacturing industries, has lost jobs in the economy. It now holds out a carrot of three dot points on a poorly enunciated criteria. The government will appoint somebody to elaborate on the criteria and will nominate the industries to which these criteria apply. That is a political program like the one that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories ran.

The cost to the Australian community of the development allowance is going to be $40 million in 1994-95 and about $70 million in 1995-96. This legislation extends from those original resource based industries with the criteria that there must be an absence of any substantial assistance or protection; that the projects must be facilitated by state and local governments; and employers and employees must be committed to management and industrial relation arrangements which promote the achievement of world best practice. Those criteria seem to have gone out of the window in the current legislation where the government moves to apply the same criteria to the automobile and print industries.

One can look at the recent figures of the Australian automobile manufacturers and component manufacturers and see that there is a fair bit of good news in the community—at least, that is what the manufacturers are saying. At a time when it appears that the automobile and component manufacturing industries are having a rather good time—and the November figures indicate that there is an increase in sales—the government is going to apply this little development incentive. It is just like the things that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has done. We do not know whether people want it or not, but the government is going to give it to them whether or not they deserve it. Maybe it has got more to do with statements over the last 12 or 18 months by people such as Bob Johnston of Toyota, who slammed the coalition's Fightback program. Perhaps that is the real criteria that is being used here to make these decisions. Maybe it has got a lot to do with the CEO of Ford who, at a critical time, made statements about whether or not the coalition's policies on protection and support for industry would actually work. Maybe that is what the government is about, because I notice that Mr Johnston has been appointed to a fairly prestigious position. That could also be part of the process of payback—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty outrageous allegation to make under privilege.

—It is not, when we consider that the industry now appears to be doing extremely well. The government quoted Holden figures today to prove that the economy is on the move, so the government is prepared to claim the credit for what is happening in the community. I refer to the Daily Commercial News of 11 November under the heading `Boom in Car Components'. The government is quick to claim that there is a recovery in the economy, but it then says that that recovery is unconnected with the appointment of senior executives of automobile companies who were supporting the government during the election campaign to senior positions.

PARA.TAB: Mr Johnston is good at his work, but he is also good at protecting his company from the sorts of things that we felt would be best for the Australian automobile industry. The automobile industry is still complaining about all the on-costs—the cost of payroll tax, the cost of fuel, the cost of the training guarantee levy, the cost of superannuation—that were its complaints in early 1992, but it is taking the government's handouts as well. The government is in the process of paying out some friends in the automobile and print industries for assistance during the election campaign. It is going to use $40 million to $70 million of taxpayers' funds. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories used $30 million. This is a posthumous payment for the election campaign.

I am fairly cynical about this legislation because no program has been properly designed to administer it where it would be most effective. I ask the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear): why is it not across all industries? Let us pick the best in Australia. If they have got projects all ready to run and they fit the government's criteria, why not the best in Australia? Why does the government have to narrow it down to two in this legislation? Is it because the newspapers so strongly supported the Australian Labor Party?

The criteria for eligibility under this legislation which the government applies to people in the print industry is very interesting. When we read the minister's speech we find that it includes not only the print equipment, but the airconditioning plant, the stuff that measures the ink—the whole box and dice. There is hardly a thing connected with this industry that the funds could not be applied to. The government is saying that people in the newspaper industry—Mr Black maybe, and some of those friends of the Australian Labor Party, or people who have been heavied by the Australian Labor Party—are going to be rewarded. On the other hand, the Housing Industry Association and others that opposed the government get the jackboot treatment.

Is this the way the government is going to do business in Australia? Is it going to make any sound judgments about whether people are doing their job well or not? Is the government going to make any real judgments about whether employees are better off or worse off? Is the government going to make any decisions about job creation and whether there is a world best practice, or is it going to make decisions according to who supported it during the election campaign and then pay them out by bankrolling them—as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories did?

Two industries receive favoured treatment in the legislation that we are debating today. I object to that. It is the wrong way to make decisions and to produce the results that the government claims it will achieve in Australia. Where does this finish? Those who supported the government before the election are to be bankrolled. Those who opposed the government are abused and attacked by the Prime Minister and get no consideration. That is a strange way of producing the best results for Australian industry. If this legislation were used properly it could be of benefit to all Australian manufacturing industries, but that has not happened; it is selective and poorly thought through. The beneficiaries are going to be those who spoke out in support of the government during the election campaign. On principle, this legislation should be opposed. The benefit is to important sections of Australian industry, but the criteria stink and the government should be conscious that this is not the way to get results in efficiency and world best practice in manufacturing industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It would suit the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) if I were to speak for only a couple of minutes as he could take it all in, but in winding up the debate I am going to speak for longer than that because there are a few things that have to be said about this bill. Unfortunately, I was not here to listen to all the speakers today, but I was here to listen to the very ungracious speech of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), and I will pick up some of the points that he made. He talked very disparagingly about Mr Bob Johnston of Toyota. He also mentioned the Ford company but did not name anyone. He said that they were in some sort of collusion with the government during the election campaign this year and therefore we were giving money to them for favours that were supposedly given. Anybody who believes that—
—It is outrageous.

—I think it is outrageous. I think that person has to be a couple of cents short. It does not happen in the real world. In the real world, do those opposite think that people like Mr Bob Johnston would sell out their principles for a couple of dollars for their industry? The fact is it does not happen. The automotive industry, like the people of Australia, made up its mind who it thought was better suited to lead the country for the next three years. I can understand a bit of sour grapes from those opposite. The opposition went into the election campaign with this huge tax slug it was going to put on everybody. The Australian people told them that they did not want the GST.

PARA.TAB: Everything that comes up now, whether grants or anything else, is thought to be a plot against the Liberal Party by so many players out there in private industry, who supposedly gave favours to the Labor Party during the election campaign. The honourable member for Mitchell says it is the payback for Fightback. But it just did not happen. He also talked about lost jobs. I do not know where he has been for the last three months, but an extra 100,000 jobs have been created, mainly in the private sector. The bad news for him, the Liberal Party and the National Party is that that will accelerate as the recovery gathers strength. The honourable member for Mitchell also talked about the print industry. I was concentrating on something else at the time, but my presumptions—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got a short memory span as well, have you?

—Not as short as the honourable member's. My impression was that he made the same accusation, that this was a pay-off to the print industry for supporting us during the election campaign. But as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) showed in question time recently, all the editorials in the major papers came out on the side of the conservatives. I would not call that a great success, even by his standards.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Mitchell talked about this government having jackboots. If he wants to see a government with jackboots, he has only to go to my home state of Western Australia, where Richard Court has guillotined through the parliament the industrial relations bill and the Mabo bill; and split up the city of Perth without consultation with anybody. That is using jackboots. We do not control the Senate. I do not know whether the honourable member for Mitchell realises that.

The Development Allowance Authority has received $130 billion worth of applications that have been notified. Of these, $27 billion has been registered. To meet the criteria of the bill, a deadline of June 1996 will have to be met for the expenditure of those moneys. The $27 billion is not the upper limit. Projects are still being evaluated. It is quite possible that the figure will be much higher. I thank all honourable members who took part in the debate on this bill and signal that we will not accept clause 6, which was introduced in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 5—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 6.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition amendment in the Senate inserted clause 6 into this bill. It would make eligible all expenditure on plant and equipment in the motor vehicle industry and the print production facilities of the print media, no matter how small, provided the other criteria were met and the expenditure related to a project.

PARA.TAB: This would significantly complicate the task of administering the scheme as a project is defined in part by whether expenditure passes the $50 million threshold test. The broad project definition, a discrete productive facility, becomes less clear without the threshold, particularly for upgrades and expansions.

The opposition argued that the existing allowance discriminates against small projects in favour of large ones. This is precisely the policy intent. The allowance was introduced as part of the One Nation statement, as a target incentive to encourage large, and internationally competitive, projects to help get the economy moving again. By removing the $50 million threshold for projects in the motor vehicle industry and the print production facilities in the print media, the bias would be moved from large versus small projects to small projects in these two industries as against small projects in other industries. There does not appear to be any good reason why small projects in these sectors should be favoured over small projects in all other sectors.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has indicated, there is a smell of rotten fish about this matter. In recent times we have seen reference to an understanding—if that is the right word—between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Conrad Black. Lo and behold, in the principal legislation, which the Senate has amended, there is reference to the print media and a threshold limit of $50 million on any firm in the print media seeking to take advantage of the allowance.

PARA.TAB: Not many print organisations in Australia can generate a project of $50 million, apart from the big spenders, including Mr Black—through the vehicle of the Fairfax press—and Mr Murdoch. They stand to be the big gainers. Whilst it might be true, as the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said, that those papers editorialised in favour of the coalition to some extent during the last election campaign, it can also be said that journalists—who, Mr Conrad Black is at pains to explain, are not directed by him; and Mr Murdoch says that on occasions also—were not necessarily quite as generous. The fact that editorials, which only politicians and the more erudite in the community read, might have gone one way means not a thing in the context of an election campaign. The closest that most of the population gets to reading the editorial pages is looking at the cartoons—political cartoons in particular.

The Senate amendment to this bill seeks to redress the move away from any egalitarianism. It is very selective. It can be of benefit only to the big operators. I would have thought our friends from the loony left on the other side might have been more vociferous in that matter. We hear quite regularly that they are worried about the concentration of media ownership, but they let something like this go. This bill serves to concentrate the spending power of the operators of the large print media in this country.

One aspect of what the government proposes to do in negativing the Senate amendment seems to have been lost on the Assistant Treasurer. Any applications which might benefit from the removal of the $50 million threshold for operators in the print media and the motor vehicle industry expire on 30 December 1993. I will tell the Assistant Treasurer—and anyone else who might be interested—that there is damn little time to get an application, without the $50 million threshold, in before 30 December. Why are we fiddling around?

A sort of craziness invades the mentality of the people opposite on the government benches. They think that because the Senate moves an amendment they had better negative it because it is not in line with their so-called principles. They are led by a Prime Minister who has all the sincerity of a cryptic crossword puzzle clue—and he is twice as devious. This is the man they follow—and they talk about principles!

One must suspect that the discussion on this amendment in the Senate has been deliberately delayed. If the legislation were to be rejected again by the Senate some time later this week and the government were forced to cave in, who would have time to put in a claim anyway? People have until 30 December. What are you fooling around with, George?

TALK.START.PARA: —They've all got them in.

—The government is only playing with the legislation. It has this `born to rule' syndrome—`If we say it's right, it's right' attitude to life. Why does the Assistant Treasurer not talk to the people in the Senate? Should the bill be enacted, not one person will have an opportunity to submit a claim. The government can delay enacting the blessed thing with this amendment in it until after 30 December when it will become meaningless.
—But they're all in.

—All in, my foot. The greater part of the print media will be disadvantaged by this legislation. In many of its products it is competing with the big operators. The print media is to be put at a cost disadvantage against the big operators—those who conceivably can best look after themselves—on a mere whim of this government. Or am I and the honourable member for Mitchell correct in detecting the smell of rotten fish?
—Never.

—Never, George. Well, God bless you. It is no wonder that this legislation is being viewed with suspicion by small operators, particularly in the print media. They will be sliced up and placed at a serious disadvantage by this legislation. The government is in the process of picking winners, but it is picking the people who are already winners to the disadvantage of the people who aspire to success. That is what is wrong with the concept of the development allowance in the first place when there is a $50 million threshold.

PARA.TAB: Apply it across the board—include the service industries where we have some expertise and some comparative advantage and include all operators in the economy—and there is an argument, but with the $50 million threshold there is no argument. The government is in the business of picking winners, and that involves discrimination against the smaller operators, the smaller business people of Australia, as against positive discrimination in favour of the big ticket operators.

That is what Labor has been reduced to after 10 or more years in government. It does not represent the small people of this country; it pretends to have egalitarian principles but it does not possess egalitarian principles any more. As I say, it is led by a Prime Minister who has all the sincerity of a cryptic crossword puzzle clue but is twice as devious.

The opposition maintains the amendment. It is a token gesture. The Assistant Treasurer is a supporter of this bill. He might fall into that category too, but I do not think he has ever done a cryptic crossword in his life—the answers might be a bit hard for him to arrive at.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a mate of mine; I'll let you go.

—I feel less than intimidated, I can assure him. This government has set out to entrench the newspaper and other print media in a position of comparative competitive advantage. It is to be deplored. It is little wonder that the coalition will oppose the negativing of the amendment proposed by our colleagues in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill, there are some points I would like to make in support of the government's adopting the recommendations of the coalition. There are two grounds why the government's decisions are objectionable: firstly, the $50 million limit for the level of investment and, secondly, the limitation on those industries which are eligible to apply.

PARA.TAB: I make it clear that I have no particular objection to incentives of a broad and general type. If it is the government's intention to do that, let it make a statement of the principles that are involved. Encouragement is needed on certain grounds for Australian manufacturing industries, but then incentives should be allowed to apply across the board. Businesses which are good enough to meet the criteria or to fit into the government's broad goals should be the winners.

In this case we have, firstly, a limitation in the original bill as to the industries which are eligible. Secondly, in the amendment before us today, we have just two industries—the automobile industry which manufactures vehicles and components and the print industry. Why does the government not open up across the board? Why does it not allow some of the tourist industries to have a go?

TALK.START.PARA: —The service industries are not involved.

—My colleague is right; the service industries are not involved. Why are we not developing our capacity in banking and finance to a higher degree? The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) will not answer that one. What about the other service industries we ought to be encouraging? The government is limiting the industries, but the hurdle which those industries have to jump over to be eligible is $50 million.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at those industries most likely to be eligible. The applications are in. I understand what the Assistant Treasurer says about that. I know that the applications are in. Over 100 applicants have tried to jump into the queue to say, `We will fit the criteria'. But those that are most likely to fit the criteria are those that have invested over $50 million.

In the print industry a very small number of people are truly eligible to fulfil the criteria. I ask the Assistant Treasurer: who are they run by? The opposition cannot be blamed for being suspicious. The government is prepared to bend the rules to allow a non-Australian, a former Australian—Rupert Murdoch—to have favoured treatment that no other person has ever had in the history of the control of Australia's print media. The government is prepared to bend all sorts of rules—in return for favours, one can only suspect—for Rupert Murdoch because he was formerly an Australian.

One of the most likely beneficiaries of this process is News Ltd. I do not mind if the rules apply across the board and the $50 million bar is removed so that those who are doing the best can get the money, but this does smack of favoured treatment. The whole nation has been enlightened by the discussions that took place between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Black on whether it was 15 per cent, 25 per cent, 30 per cent or 35 per cent, as Mr Black said. Mr Black said that he had a commitment for 35 per cent, but the Prime Minister said, `No, we just talked about that; it was not a commitment at all, but we had a commitment for 25 per cent'.

The government is prepared to deal with people who are not Australian nationals in this important industry and is prepared to give them all sorts of favoured treatment in the control of their enterprise but at the same time it is throwing taxpayers' dollars after them. I do not understand the way those in the government think. The great upstanding Labor Party is the great upholder of Australian traditions and the rights of the working men, but it does not care about them; all it wants is to see its name in print on the front page. That is the way the Prime Minister operates; he is a front page reader. He looks at the headlines and nothing else. That is the way he runs this nation. If he is winning in the headlines he is winning and that is all he thinks about. I do not think that that way of running the nation is good enough.

I really believe that government members have it completely wrong. The firms that will do well out of this process are not owned or managed by Australians. The fact of the matter is that in the print media Murdoch and Black will be the big winners. I will read to the chamber what the Assistant Treasurer said as I would like the community to understand what is implied here. As if it were not enough to apply it to the place of print, the Assistant Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is intended that the printing unit would include the facilities that control and operate the airconditioning plant in the building that houses the printing facility. This is a technical requirement of modern printing facilities. Additionally, the printing unit would typically include the system that manages the collection and disposal of waste material, as well as the system that determines the rate of ink flows, the speed of the presses, and the rostering of printing staff.

How broad do those opposite want to make it? Why do they not include the development allowance for the Harbour Bridge as well, just in case somebody from the printing industry walks over it? The government has made it as broad as it possibly can to include everything that opens and shuts. I think this is wrong. I have mentioned the fact that the government is prepared to favour non-Australians. I do not mind that. I do not mind competition. I like competition. But we should make it fair for everybody to have a go—Australians as well as non-Australians.

PARA.TAB: The final issue that I would like to look at is the automobile industry. I would like the Assistant Treasurer to answer this question because he knows about the applications or could gain access to them. It is widely spoken about in Australian manufacturing industries that, as a result of the huge, recent investment by the Toyota company in plant and equipment, it is likely to benefit by $20 million. Is that right? I want to know whether it is more or whether it is less. I do not need to know the exact figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to benefit—Toyota?

—Yes. I understand that is the degree to which that company will benefit by this particular development allowance. That is going to corner a lot of the original action. Toyota is one of the few firms that have been put right up front. It fits perfectly—just coincidentally—the criteria laid down by the government in this legislation. None of the others fit it.
—Not Bob Johnston's company.

—My colleague the honourable member for Aston mentions Mr Johnston. He and I visited that plant. We were impressed by the application of those Toyota executives to bettering the industry and bettering workplace relations. I think the difference between us and them was that we felt things should be moving along a bit quicker than they were. We were also worried about whether they had made a full appraisal of some of their on-costs and we were concerned that they were prepared to let things drift a bit.

PARA.TAB: Also in relation to the automobile industry, I have been very interested in the number of comments coming from non-nationals and visiting Japanese heads that the government seem to have given comfort to. Mr Toyoda was one of those people. I have met members of the Toyoda family and I understand the way they operate. They are businessmen and they will go for the best deal. For them to come to Australia and throw an iron into the fire of Australian politics and to have the Prime Minister, as an Australian leader, pick up comfort from a visiting Japanese businessman and say, `This is the way we need to go because this man says so; we do not need to follow our national ideas in this industry' is somewhat distasteful.

As for the prospect of Australian automobile companies gaining benefit from this special allowance which seems to be designed specifically to give them support in a way that will not be available to other sections of the industry, what about the component industry? What about the manufacturers of parts and components? What about those guys working in factories in the back blocks of Melbourne, Sydney or Adelaide who are now so much a part of this great and developing industry? The industry is changing and improving. I do not want to denigrate the industry, but how many of those manufacturers will be eligible for this development allowance? The answer is not one.

How many of those manufacturers are going to invest $50 million? For goodness sake, they are the heart and soul of this industry. It appears that the government is prepared to adopt all of the feudal landlord attitudes towards the component manufacturers as it screws them and their employees into the dust to meet targets set by the manufacturers. We want to encourage the process of meeting targets. Why can those component manufacturers not join that process? If they are good, why can they not participate as well? If we are going to encourage the manufacturing industry, it should be across the board and include every person involved in the automobile manufacturing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up a couple of points made by opposition speakers. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) said that applications have to be in by 30 December. That is wrong. Applicants have 28 days after royal assent to register their intention to apply, so there is plenty of time to do so under the DAA.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) picked up the point that firms with proposals under $50 million a year cannot participate in this scheme. The simple fact is that they can participate because this bill allows aggregation. So a number of related industries—it might be the automotive industry; it might be the print industry—can put forward a joint venture that can exceed $50 million and be eligible for the allowance. The honourable member for Mitchell also spoke about limited application. This bill does not give the development allowance to two industries but rather adds two industries to the mining, manufacturing and energy sectors, which are already covered by the original bill—in actual fact, the traded goods sector.

The honourable member went back to the print issue and was ungracious enough to say that Conrad Black and Mr Murdoch may have advantaged the Labor Party in the last federal election. All I can say is that the headlines and editorials—for anybody who wants to scan those written during that period—certainly did not favour the Labor Party. I noticed that he did not mention three papers—the West Australian, the Adelaide Advertiser and the Brisbane Courier-Mail. They come from the three states where the Labor Party lost seats. During the election campaign, those papers provided some of the worst journalism, some of the worst editorials and some of the worst layouts of papers one would ever come cross, but I notice he did not complain about those. They were absent from this wide, sweeping criticism of the print media being onside. The honourable member for Curtin would understand that the West Australian, in the two years leading up to the last election and since, has run a completely anti-government line. It never has a good word to say about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The cartoons and the editorials are always against him and always against the Labor Party. So it does not surprise me that he did not mention the West Australian, which would be eligible for this allowance, or the Adelaide Advertiser and the Brisbane Courier-Mail.

The honourable member for Mitchell talked about airconditioning being allowable under these provisions. Anybody who has had a look at the latest technology in printing would understand that, with the number of computers involved, airconditioning is a necessity and not an option. Airconditioning is necessary to make sure that these computerised printing presses work. So, naturally, we have included that. With those few words, I reiterate that the government will not accept the amendment from the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) is quite right—I am delighted that he listened closely to me—in saying that applications must be in by 30 December or within 28 days after the act receives royal assent. I am pleased that he is paying attention to legislation for a change. He is on a fast learning curve, and I congratulate him for that. Nevertheless, 28 days, should anyone be holding fire, is not very long. The time left until 30 December is negligible, as would be apparent to anyone. If the Assistant Treasurer is serious in his reference to aggregation and joint ventures being possible under this legislation, there is little time available for that to happen, even if we remove the $50 million threshold. That is the point I made earlier. Even if we removed it, people would not have time to get applications in. There are very good reasons for removing it. They have been well and truly canvassed in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: It is deplorable that the government seeks to ignore the good reasoning that was involved. To put it in another context, the print media and the motor vehicle industry were specifically excluded from the legislation which was brought down last year. Lo and behold, after an election they were included. It has the smell of rotten fish about it.

However we may judge the press coverage in the run-up to the last election—whether by editorial or in the body of newspapers—it is what happens in the future that will be important. It may be that, having burnt a few bridges in the run-up to the last election, the government—a la Senator Graham Richardson—looks to the future. Given a whole series of events, including the revelations by Mr Conrad Black to which the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and I referred earlier, it is a reasonable assumption to make. But there are other arguments and we do not rely entirely on our suspicions as to motive.

The Assistant Treasurer refers to the West Australian and the fact that the government got a bit of stick in the run-up to the most recent general election. It deserved that stick. The Assistant Treasurer knows what happened in Western Australia. The government had a holiday from the West Australian for eight years while its colleagues in the state, whom the Assistant Treasurer knows and refuses to acknowledge in this place, bled that state dry under the most reprehensible circumstances and with the connivance of the then Prime Minister.

The Assistant Treasurer knows what happened; it is well recorded. The Assistant Treasurer shakes his head, but he knows what happened. He has not been too quick to defend them over the years because he knows that what happened was reprehensible. The West Australian was making up for a bit of lost time. In those two years it still had that acolyte of the Prime Minister—the man the Assistant Treasurer entertained regularly in his office when he was government whip; that wonderful, unbiased journalist—Mr Peter Rees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he now?

—Where he should be—consigned to the nether lands. That is exactly where he should be. The Assistant Treasurer should not complain about the treatment the government received from the West Australian because the government had a press holiday for eight or nine years. In fairness to the West Australian, it is heaping it on the Court government. What seems apparent is that it made a decision to keep governments honest—the federal government and the state government in Western Australia, Labor and Liberal respectively. So the Assistant Treasurer should cop it sweet and stop grizzling. The Prime Minister has pulled that one and it does not work. In an earlier remark, the Assistant Treasurer had the ultimate gall to refer to the jackboot tactics of the Court government.
—The guillotine.

—It applied the guillotine in the Western Australian parliament—well, bless my soul! What examples did he give: industrial relations legislation and the Mabo bill. What happened in the people's house in Canberra not two or three weeks ago? Chop, chop—here comes the guillotine. Maxwell's silver hammer came down upon our heads. The Assistant Treasurer criticised the Western Australian government!

PARA.TAB: I have no time for the application of the guillotine in this parliament or any other parliament of the Westminster system. But those opposite love it. They love to apply it to not only the important Industrial Relations Reform Bill of that remarkable intellect the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton)—screwed by the ACTU with the support of the weaker members of the cabinet—but also the Mabo legislation. In this session 50 per cent of all legislation has gone through the people's house under the guillotine. The Assistant Treasurer grizzles about the fact that it might be applied in the Western Australian upper house as well as the lower house for two bills only! I do not accept that the reasons are good enough, but they are far more valid than any reasons advanced by the Assistant Treasurer for putting 50 per cent of the government's legislation under the guillotine this session.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Snow)—Order! The clause is fairly specific and I ask the honourable member to curb his remarks and speak to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was answering remarks made by the Assistant Treasurer in his response. I will cut them short. I wanted to take the Assistant Treasurer to task for the fatuous nonsense that he came out with—that feigned indignation about the guillotine. The Assistant Treasurer is not even a good actor. But I suppose it will read okay in black and white.

PARA.TAB: By negativing the Senate amendment, the government seeks to entrench the large operators in the newspaper and print industries by what is, in effect, positive discrimination in their favour. It talks about the need for world best practice and international competitiveness, but its very actions run contrary to its rhetoric. That fact should not be lost on anyone in this parliament. We have absolutely no truck with what the government proposes to do. As I have already indicated, we will certainly oppose the action foreshadowed by the Assistant Treasurer.
Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report—by leave—adopted.
Bill (on motion by Mr Gear)—by leave—read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now considering the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill, which goes to the core of the various trade mechanisms which relate to Australia's trading purpose, especially for smaller companies, through the export market development grants scheme. I always appeal in this place for the need to develop plain English drafting of legislation. This bill, which has a number of important functions which I will turn to in a moment, contains this clause:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the amount of grant payable in relation to the notional full-year claim were equal to the sum of the grant paid or payable in relation to the first-half claim and the grant paid or payable in relation to the balance-year claim; and . . .

That is clause 25 which relates to proposed new subsection (13)(b) of section 38. It is an example of how complex legislative drafting becomes in order to deliver its purpose. I believe that draftsmen need to be reminded from time to time of the need for as much plain English drafting as possible in the preparation of legislation for consideration by the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of these amendments is to introduce three new and welcome amendments. Firstly, the bill will exclude from eligibility for export market development grants claimants with criminal convictions under the Corporations Law or in respect of serious fraud. Secondly, it will exclude from the scheme those businesses the future viability of which is tenuous in terms of their solvency. Thirdly, it will permit businesses to lodge half-yearly claims as a method of assisting cash flows in the early stages of export development.

The first amendment seems to me to be overdue and, indeed, could well be considered a fault in the earlier drafting of the principal act. That nothing has been done until now to address this issue is almost negligent and one can but speculate on the number of claims paid that ought not to have been paid. For there not to have been a provision of the nature now proposed in my view represents an unacceptable level of risk management.

However, while accepting that the amendment now before us seeks to address the issue of fraud, I am suggesting that further elaboration and clarification are required. I refer specifically to proposed section 11YA(1)(a) and (b) in respect of the reference to convictions wherein it is implied that a claimant would be disqualified from making a claim if convicted of an offence committed overseas. There is no certainty, however, in the bill as to the mechanisms that will serve to guard against false claims made by claimants convicted of an offence overseas. In my opinion, grant applications should include a requirement for all applicants to declare whether they have corporate or other forms of commercial interests overseas and the nature of that interest. Passport details would also be appropriate so as to permit proper inquiry to be made and to ensure a false statement is not included in the application.

It is clear that the bill deals with claimants convicted of offences here in Australia, but I ask that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay), in summing up, address the question of the mechanisms in the bill relating to those who have committed offences overseas in terms of EMDG eligibility. In my view, protection against fraud should occupy a high profile and measures need to be included consistent with the provisions of privacy legislation to ensure that only fit and proper persons have access to the grant program.

On the second proposed amendment, that of disallowing insolvent firms from making claims, I have no objection. As with the first proposed amendment, the third is, in my view, a measure that ought to have been incorporated in the principal act from day one. That the government has decided only now to facilitate the entry of new firms into the export market by allowing claims to be made on a six monthly basis instead of annually is a real breakthrough and I welcome that breakthrough. However, after the events of the last week or so over the ineptitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the international arena that saw the potential for and an actual disruption to trade between Australia and Malaysia, a trade mostly conducted by the small business sector, we should hardly be surprised that this legislation has received only cursory attention as it passes its way through the parliament.

The Prime Minister is guilty on four counts in relation to causing a major breakdown in the relations between Australia and Malaysia: firstly, in making his public outburst in Seattle; secondly, in wearing as a badge of honour that he had gone out on a limb against Prime Minister Mahathir; thirdly, by sending a disastrous letter which did nothing to calm the dispute and lead to a solution; and, fourthly, by delaying providing an affirmation of regret through diplomatic channels to Malaysia until some 16 days after the original event. On all four counts, Prime Minister Keating jeopardised Australian trade with Malaysia—unnecessarily, in an unacceptable way and in a way which members of the government were severely embarrassed about. However, we perhaps should not have expected much different from a Prime Minister who loses control of his tongue. As I said at the time, the tongue of Keating created the problem and the tongue of Keating should have moved a whole lot more quickly to resolve the specific problem with Malaysia.

We need to work a great deal harder on building up a more comprehensive and in-depth bilateral relationship with Malaysia with a better understanding in both directions between Australia and Malaysia and, in the broad, between Australia and modern Asia. Frankly—not that I choose to dwell on this, but it is in part relevant to the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill—the Prime Minister is paying a price for not having made working visits more frequently to modern Asia over the years. Yes, he went to Europe, Russia and the Northern Hemisphere a great deal, but it is a matter of public record that he had to be dragged screaming to visit Japan by the then Prime Minister Bob Hawke and that he has made very few working visits to Asia compared to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who has visited just about every ASEAN country and many other Asian countries. I have now been on working visits to some 19 Asian countries, including places beyond the bright lights such as Bhutan, Bangladesh and Burma, all countries which Australia should have some knowledge of and some working relationship with.

It is apparent to me as well as to the small business community that the government has simply ignored the role that small business plays in the Australian economy to a large extent. It has ignored the centrality of the small business sector to Australia's export culture and, as a result, the small business sector has been dealt with badly by this government. For starters, the last budget hit the cost structure of the small business sector through ill-conceived increases in the fuel tax and sales tax areas.
Mr Braithwaite interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Dawson correctly points out, it has been kneecapped in many ways with its cost of transport to port for export of product from Australia, especially from inland Australia. Indeed, the fuel tax hike and sales tax hike are costing small business in all directions. I used to wonder how the government could justify on the one hand making grants to exporters by virtue of the raft of EMDG legislation that seeks to improve export opportunities while, on the other, turning around and contributing to increases in their business overheads.

PARA.TAB: Because Australian exporters continue to be constrained by questionable economic policies, the government feels incumbent to expiate the guilt it feels towards exporters through amendments of this kind and improvements with the EMDG scheme. It is, in my view, futile for the government to argue the significance of the act and its amendments over the last 20 years or so. It is futile because in other more relevant, more appropriate policy contexts the grants that are available would be unnecessary simply because the economic policies in place would satisfy many of the prerequisites to export competition. It is unbelievable that this country levies a tax on exports, by virtue of the structure of sales tax, of some $1 billion to $2 billion, placing our exporters at a disadvantage on the very unlevel international playing field even before the first container leaves the Australian port.

Export is about international competitiveness. It is true that the EMDG legislation provides assistance to exporters, but it is not the be-all and end-all.
