The policies of the former Treasurer, the current Prime Minister, which the present Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) clearly is under pressure to maintain, together with the inflexibility of Australian wages policy, have had an adverse impact on the competitiveness of Australia's export opportunities. The EMDG legislation, by its very existence, seeks to address the effect of these policy shortcomings but, clearly, in the face of current policy, any benefits that accrue to the exporter are submerged in the morass of failed government policy.

There is another more recent addition to the difficulties of competitiveness. Not only does small business have to confront the government's burdensome economic and infrastructure policies, but it also now has to grapple with the potential damage to overseas markets caused by those remarks of the Prime Minister which I referred to earlier. However, since there is a limited possibility of our witnessing a bolt of lightning on the road to Damascus in terms of innovative economic strategies that might redress these shortcomings, there is, in my view, a need for a major overhaul of this legislation in order to fulfil what it originally sought to accomplish and that is, in the words of Dr Jim Cairns, a former trade minister, to give `particular encouragement to small- and medium-sized firms to become involved in exporting'.

The coalition does not oppose the export market development grant amendments before the House. However, I do seek clarification on the particular question that, where a crime or fraud involving an Australian applicant occurs overseas, there be mechanisms in the bill to apply the same circumstance and criteria as would apply if the fraud or crime for which the person is convicted is committed here in Australia. I look forward to a response on that matter.

The House is considering this legislation at a very critical time for world trade. There is no such thing as a level playing field; I have said that categorically. The answer to the question of whether the playing field becomes more tilted or less tilted appears to be going right down to the wire as we approach the deadline of 15 December—which is 48 hours away our time, but on Washington time we have a few more hours on top of that. Yet, in the detailed endgame of the Uruguay Round, there has been a savage twist which will impact heavily on Australian grain growers and others.

That impact has been detailed in part by me and also in a statement made by the Grains Council of Australia. The statement by the Grains Council refers to the sabotaging of aspects of the Blair House accord to help accommodate an agreement between Europe and the United States—more particularly between France and the United States. Whilst some would argue that the core of the agreement is still in place, so savage is the adjustment that Australian grain growers face a good deal of agony arising from the outcome of the negotiation as it now stands, although there may be some further last-minute changes. I quote from the statement of the Grains Council of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: Changing the basis for commencing the volume and value cuts in wheat export subsidies from the original Blair House deal will mean that there will be an extra 8 and 7.5 MT of EC and US subsidised wheat which could be legitimately sold onto the market supported by an extra $US700 M—
for their EEP—
and 1.25 Bill ECU's—
for the Europeans—
over the life of the reduction commitments, i.e 1995 to 2001.

Under the revised proposal the `step-off' year will now be the average of the 1991 and 1992 years meaning that the program of cuts will commence from 20 million tonnes for the EC and 21 million tonnes for the US, instead of the Blair House deal of the 1986-90 base year levels of 17 and 17.77 for the EC and US respectively.
Similarly the value cuts which would have commenced under the Blair House deal from 1.783 Bill ECU's and $US531.9 will now `step-off' from $US850 M and 2.3 Bill ECU's for the US and EC respectively.
The Blair House Accord of volume and value cuts of 21 % and 36% respectively over six years from 1995, will remain—
that is significant—

and those cuts will be required to be made without flexibility, i.e. 3.5 % and 6 % respectively for each year of the schedule. The base period of 1986-90 will remain for the purposes of determining the final end point, i.e. 13.43 MT and 1.14 Bill ECU for the EC and 14.04 MT and $US340.4 M.

The Grains Council has charted part of the situation arising from the endgame of the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. It is chilling news for Australian grain growers that, as we head towards the finish line, they are going to see their markets subjected to more subsidised grain from the Northern Hemisphere—be it US or Europe—with disastrous consequences for some time.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the core aspects of Blair House cut in, and they represent welcome reductions in the level of subsidisation. On balance, there are benefits for Australia and Australian agriculture in reaching a proper agreement. Even if the Blair House accord goes forward, it is a great pity that to date the government has not been able to secure much in the way of increased market share to help counterbalance the high cost to Australia of adjustments to the Blair House accord.

The challenge certainly rests with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) to see that the so-called voluntary quotas and agreements restraining trading arrangements between Australia and the United States—for example, with beef—and between Australia and other countries are exposed for what they are: methods of backdoor protection on the edge of GATT. While in one sense they are legal, in another sense they beg the question of how fair dinkum some of the major trading countries in the Northern Hemisphere are about reaching free trade.

The Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill is some 19 pages of amendments accompanied by eight pages of blank paper—the bad luck of the binding. In the broad, it is legislation which heads in the right direction. It is legislation which tightens up certain critical aspects of the export market development grants scheme and which hopefully will eliminate any fraudulent application or any situation where applicants might not be fit and proper persons to succeed with an export market development grant.

It is an area of activity which needs to be rigorously monitored to ensure the performance of the program against its objectives. It is an area of activity which is legitimate and one which Australia, as it wrestles with the increasingly unlevel international playing field, has every entitlement to push in order to help our exporters in a practical, sensible and reasonable way and not in a way which would create its own set of problems if the wrong kind of assistance were given.

In looking at the whole thrust of Australian trade activity and policy we must also remind ourselves of the need for tough fair trade criteria. Not only are we entitled to have an export market development grants scheme which is focused and performs; we should also have absolutely adequate anti-dumping laws and labelling laws, an absolutely adequate system of quarantine inspection, a revamping of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to make sure it works more efficiently, with lower costs—and without the travel rorts exposed by Senator Brownhill, Senator O'Chee, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) and others referred to in the Australian today—and a National Food Authority with something more than the two inspectors, which it had up until recently, looking at the quality of food that is coming into Australia.

We are entitled to a set of tough, fair trade rules in this country, operating parallel with such things as the export market development grants scheme. Such tough fair trade rules should also be and can be GATT legal. We can tighten up the anti-dumping legislation, without offending against GATT, to provide legitimate fast-track methods for industries which are being dumped on quite professionally by certain countries and operators from overseas in a grossly unfair way. The coalition is therefore not opposed to the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill, but it does invite the response of the representing minister on the specific matter of fraud committed overseas and the mechanisms within this bill which will operate in relation to applicants who might be in that category.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill. This bill amends the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974, which established the export market development program. (Quorum formed) The purpose of this bill is to amend that act to do three things. It seeks to:

PARA.TAB: (a) exclude from eligibility persons with criminal convictions under the Corporations Law, or in respect of serious fraud, and certain claimants under schemes of arrangement.
(b) assist the cash flow of emerging exporters by providing them with the facility to lodge claims for grant on a half yearly basis.
(c) effect a number of "technical" amendments . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some comments in respect of the first two areas and then make some general comments in respect of Australia's export success in recent times. As I have said, one aspect of this bill seeks to exclude from eligibility persons with criminal convictions under the Corporations Law, or in respect of serious fraud, and certain claimants under schemes of arrangement.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) made the following comment in his second reading speech, which underlies the basis of this aspect of the legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: It is considered that the integrity of the scheme is at risk where it allows convicted persons access to public funds. The bill does not prevent persons with minor convictions from obtaining grants, only those who have been convicted of more serious offences under the Corporations Law, or in respect of fraud.

I think that is an appropriate basis on which to rest this particular aspect of an export market development regime. I draw the House's attention to the ineligibility period, which is outlined in clause 10 of the bill. That clause defines an ineligibility period and states that a person convicted of an offence is subsequently rendered eligible to apply after a period of five years. The ineligibility period, as defined in the clause, is the period starting when the person was convicted and ending five years after the conviction; or, if the person was sentenced to imprisonment, five years after the person's release from prison. Although not precisely analogous, it is consistent with the spirit of expunging criminal records which we have seen in various state enactments over recent years. It has the effect that a person who has fallen foul of the law is not rendered ineligible to make an application under the development grants program for ever and a day. I think that strikes a sensible balance.

PARA.TAB: The second area of amendment in this bill seeks to assist the cash flow of emerging exporters by providing them with the facility to lodge claims for grant on a half yearly basis. I refer again to the minister's second reading speech, where he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . half yearly claims lodgment is seen as a very practical method of assisting exporters' cash flow in the early stages of overseas market development. The scheme has operated very successfully for 19 years, with the only significant criticism being the delay between incurring expenditure by the exporter, and the payment of the grant. This bill provides for earlier payment of grants based on the provision to lodge half yearly claims in respect of exporters' first three full grant years . . . A great strength of the scheme is the freedom it affords exporters to make judgments as to the activities they wish to pursue, and the markets they wish to target.

I noticed before the dinner break that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) in his comments on this bill indicated the opposition's support for that particular measure. I am very pleased to hear it is supported, and I believe that this aspect of the amendment bill will ensure another government measure for emerging exporters, helping to ensure that our success as an exporting country continues to grow.

PARA.TAB: I move from those particular points to make some general comments about the way in which this government has given every assistance to our emerging exporters. In conjunction with this year's budget, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) and the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) provided a budget paper entitled Investing in our emerging exports. The amendment which we have before us today is but one of the measures provided for in the course of that budget to ensure that our emerging exporters are given every assistance to be successful.

In addition to the export market development grants amendments, there is a package of measures worth over $94 million over three years, which is worth drawing the House's attention to. The first initiative states:

SPEECH.PARA: Expanding the National Industry Extension Service to enable it to tailor information and consultancy services more closely to the needs of small and medium-sized firms
The second initiative states:
Building a network of First Stop Shops to give businesses fast and comprehensive access to specialised information and services on government assistance
Another initiative states:
Increasing funding for the International Trade Enhancement Scheme to make it available to smaller companies
A further initiative states:
Initiating the Market Australia Campaign to project an image of Australia and key markets as a technologically advanced and sophisticated economy
Finally, yet another initiative:
Increasing funding for the Development Import Finance Facility to further assist Australian firms in gaining access to development projects in the Asian region
All these measures, in their ambition and their scope, help to ensure that we continue to grow as an exporting country and that small- and medium-sized companies are given every assistance.

PARA.TAB: In that budget paper, there are a couple of interesting export growth tables which are worthy of drawing to the House's attention. Many honourable members would be aware of the McKinsey report on emerging exporters. In the course of that study, the McKinsey report predicts that the small- and medium-sized companies' exporting growth potential is from just over $4 billion in 1986-87 to just under $16 billion by 1995-96.

That export performance potential is, in no small measure, assisted by the measures I referred to. In addition to the growth in exports by the small- and medium-sized companies, there has been growth in the level of Australian manufactured exports. In 1982-83, according to Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade figures, our exports of simply transformed or elaborately transformed manufactures were in the order of $3.8 billion and, by 1991-92, were in the range of $13 billion and, as the McKinsey report makes clear, with every potential for increased growth.

In addition to that paper, budget related paper No. 6 refers to Australia's trade development program. There are a couple of passages in that budget related paper which summarise the government's policy objectives. Under the heading `Australia's future as a trading nation' this comment appears:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia must succeed in the international marketplace if it is to achieve the stronger economic growth that will underpin job creation. Improvement in our export performance is an important way to sustain higher growth in output and employment.

In that budget related paper, the Minister for Trade makes the point that the key policy objectives in trade are as follows: to accelerate the transition of Australia from an inward-looking to an internationally oriented economy; to encourage the emergence of fully open and fair markets globally and an inte

grated open market in the Asia-Pacific region; to strengthen Australia's position in existing markets; to deepen and broaden Australia's economic links with east Asian economies; to position Australia to realise emerging market opportunities; and to ensure international awareness of Australia as a technologically and managerially sophisticated economy, a culturally diverse and liberal society, and a producer of leading ideas and quality, high-value goods and services. In short, pursuing all these objectives will ensure that Australia can make its own way in the world as a modern trading and manufacturing country.

PARA.TAB: In that budget related paper, we have a summary of merchandise trade by broad category. To see and appreciate the growth in this area, I again refer to the area of elaborately transformed manufactures and simply transformed manufactures. In the calender year 1988 the figures record that the export of elaborately transformed manufactures stood at a value of just over $5.7 billion; in 1992 it was in the order of $10.9 billion. Over the corresponding period the export of simply transformed manufactures rose from $4.4 billion to $5.4 billion. That highlights the great advance in the export of our elaborately transformed manufactures—an increase from $5.7 billion in 1988 to $10.9 billion in 1992.

That increased performance and the potential for even further increase are greatly assisted by the measures in this bill. By assisting exporters to ensure a long-term, stable future we will secure jobs for Australia by increasing trade in our region and turning ourselves into a modern trading exporting country. However, these measures are much more assisted by the macro-economic policies the government has adopted since it came to office in 1983, opening Australia up as an internationally competitive country and ensuring that, through international competitiveness and assistance to exporters—particularly small- and medium-sized companies—this country becomes a strong, viable, modern, industrial trading and manufacturing country in this region. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974. As pointed out by my colleague the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), while the amendments are considerably overdue, the coalition does not oppose them and, indeed, welcomes them.

PARA.TAB: There are three amendments to the legislation: firstly, the bill excludes from eligibility claimants with criminal convictions under the Corporations Law or in respect to serious fraud; secondly, it will exclude from the scheme those businesses whose future viability is in doubt as a result of insolvency; and, thirdly, the bill will allow participants in the scheme to lodge half yearly claims as a means of assisting cash flows in the early stages of export development.

Rather than cover the same ground as the Leader of the National Party, who has already outlined in detail the few minor concerns the coalition has with these amendments, I would like to examine the export market development grants scheme in more general terms.

The scheme was set up in 1974 to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop new markets for Australian goods and services. It provides financial incentives in the form of taxable cash grants based on eligible expenditure on a range of overseas marketing activities promoting export sales. Export enhancement measures such as the EMDGS are provided by governments in recognition of the high risks and costs which firms would otherwise have to bear, particularly in the early stages of exporting.,

While there has been some past criticism of the scheme, questioning the scheme's impact on export growth and its cost effectiveness, it can be said to have had a role in the context of the government's failure to deal with the structural inefficiencies which harm Australian exports. It is important, however, not to consider the scheme in isolation. It must be examined in the context of the government's overall effort to enhance Australia's export performance and the need to push ahead with micro-economic reforms.

The bill is, in part, a direct response to the report, Investing in our emerging exporters, mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), produced recently by McKinsey and Co. for the Australian Manufacturing Council. A landmark report, Investing in our emerging exporters, was based on a survey of 700 high value-added manufacturing firms and provided an analysis of the challenges and opportunities Australia and Australian manufacturers face in integrating into a global economy and building an effective export culture.

The report identified a number of impediments to export activity including: the restricted availability of finance for small- to medium-sized enterprises; restricted access to key markets; a lack of management skills amongst those that run Australia's small- to medium-sized enterprises; problems of access to technology; and a lack of appropriate market information.

In response to these impediments, the report made several major policy recommendations, including changes to the scheme, that are covered in this bill. It seems, however, that the government has been slow to act on many of the report's recommendations. For example, it has ignored the report's call for a strategic vision of Australia's economic future, a vision that recognises the importance of exports—particularly exports based on innovation. And it has been less than comprehensive in addressing the need to streamline the delivery of the numerous government programs available to small- and medium-sized enterprises, access to which was described in the report as `complex and ad hoc'; the need for improved access to finance; and/or the need for comparisons between Australia and our east Asian trading partners.

One of the most salient points made in the report is that up to 90 per cent of Australian manufacturers do not export at all. One could have been excused for not realising this sobering fact after attending, as I did, the national export awards held here at Parliament House only recently. Organised each year by Austrade and the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the awards are an occasion for justifiable satisfaction and recognition of the success of Australian companies in the international marketplace. They should, however, be a bipartisan affair, and they should not be highjacked by a government determined to present a biased and misleading view of the nation's export performance.

The `politically correct' version of Australia's export performance—a version which differs dramatically from the reality—was pushed relentlessly throughout the awards ceremony, particularly by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook). It was indeed an evening which focused on political correctness. That theme was established right at the start of the evening with the singing of the national anthem during which the speaker's face on the video monitors obscured the Union Jack in the Australian flag. We knew where we were heading from that moment—it was clear that the evening was under tight political direction, and everything that followed simply confirmed that fact.

The official, politically correct version of Australia's export performance is that, as a result of the government's `reforms', Australia's companies are dramatically lifting their export performance—illustrated by the performance of the magnificent 700, identified by the McKinsey report. In the official version, Australian technology based manufacturing is now off and running and it is only a matter of time before the gap between exports and imports is closed. Government policies, according to this line, have succeeded. No-one would have left the award ceremony with the impression that the government believed that Australia had any significant policy challenges ahead or that a substantial reform agenda still remained to be completed.

The truth, however, is very different. Australia's export performance remains far below that which is necessary to correct our mounting foreign debt. As a nation, we are still living beyond our means on a grand scale. The current account deficit of $1.2 billion for October shows that Australia is plunging further into debt and underlines the fact that we are a long way short of exporting enough to pay for imports and to service our foreign debt. It is a sad fact that Australia's ranking amongst world exporters fell from 11th in 1956 to 22nd in 1990. Our relative decline as a world trading nation highlights the fact that under this government we remain uncompetitive in the global marketplace in too many areas. As Warren Haynes of ICI Australia pointed out to the recent Business Council of Australia conference on micro-economic reform, we are actually facing a widening gap on the merchandise balance of trade with imports of manufactured goods increasingly outstripping manufactured exports.

Australia's manufacturing effort remains one of the poorest in the OECD. The recession has seen manufacturing slump lower in 1991-92 than in 1982-83 or even 1974-75. Between 1985 and 1991, manufacturing output per head increased by an average of 10 per cent across the OECD countries while in Australia it rose by only one per cent—one of the weakest performances in the industrialised world. Despite all the talk about encouraging research and development and technology based exports, the fact is that Australia's relative ranking in business R&D is 17th out of 24 OECD countries and has not improved in the last decade. The impact of the 150 per cent tax concession in encouraging R&D pales into insignificance, to use the recent words of the Bureau of Industry Economics, when measured against the vast number of Australian enterprises which do not perform research and development.

World class education and training, which must be in the years ahead the foundation of Australia's international comparative advantage, have been driven by confused and inconsistent political agendas at great cost to scientific research and the ability to maintain international quality standards. The latest opinion of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) that Australia has too many universities and too few institutions focused on vocational education and training demonstrates the lack of a coherent strategy behind the upheaval of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) of recent years. To raise these issues in the context of this debate is not to poor mouth Australia, as the government bleats every time uncomfortable facts come to life. Rather, it is to be honest about the dimension of the task that this country faces.

As I have said, a whopping 90 per cent of Australian manufacturing businesses do not export, and the present policy mix is not encouraging them to do so. Australian enterprise is handicapped by major impediments to innovation which the government refuses to acknowledge. These impediments were well identified at the Business Council of Australia conference that I referred to earlier and in the report released this month Managing the innovative enterprise, as the outcome of a study commission chaired by Sir Roderick Carnegie. We hear a lot about the McKinsey report, but we have heard precious little so far—in fact, I wonder whether we have heard anything—from this government about this very important report of the Business Council of Australia on innovation. The reason we have heard so little about this report from the government can be readily seen when we look at the main recommendations of this report. This report called upon the government to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hasten the removal of the key regulatory impediments to improved enterprise performance by accelerating changes in the labour market that make it easier to achieve the positive employee relations that underpin the success of leading innovative businesses.

There was no mention of such a challenge at the export awards. The government's failure in this area strikes at the heart of the capacity of Australian business to undertake the kind of innovation, including innovation in technology, which is absolutely essential to build up our international competitiveness. The derailing of the process of industrial relations reform by the Brereton legislation is a body blow to hopes for an improved environment for business innovation and, therefore, improved exports.

PARA.TAB: In this morning's press, Mr Ian Salmon, chairman of the economic and finance panel of the Business Council of Australia, in criticising the government's industrial relations reform package, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a tragedy that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill has missed the opportunity to add to private sector recovery. To the contrary, we fear that it will entrench a resistance to changing inefficient and unproductive work organisation and will, consequently, retard investment and international competitiveness.

The reform which the government and the Prime Minister and his mate promote is seen by the major business enterprises of this country as positively retarding the movement of this country to international competitiveness. What a damning indictment of the government's proposed reforms in this vital area.

PARA.TAB: The Chairman of the Industry Commission, Mr Bill Scales, has also pointed out in recent weeks that, in addition to genuine progress towards enterprise bargaining, there must be a major effort made to reduce the costs to business from regulatory arrangements at different levels of government and to remove the impediments to the states undertaking reform of their government business enterprises, especially those providing energy and transport. It is not enough to compare the present performance of our electricity, rail, port or telecommunications utilities with their performance in the past. It is the international comparison which counts and, despite improvements, the comparative costs for loading times at Australian ports, for example, are still three times the cost in New Zealand.

Recent tax increases such as the fuel tax have undermined any benefits flowing from past changes and impact heavily on the mining industry and coastal shipping. The complete absence of any coherent strategy from the government on business taxation further undermines efforts to build up value added enterprise in Australia. At present the evidence is that the overhead costs of government business enterprises not exposed to competition are far too high and that by international benchmarks Australian infrastructure is a significant handicap to enterprise. Government business enterprises contribute some 10 per cent to GDP and their services comprise between 10 and 16 per cent of business costs. Much of the crucial reform in this area must be made by the states, and enhancing international competitiveness requires a major effort of federal-state cooperation.

Unfortunately, the culture of the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party has ill-equipped it for an effective effort at cooperative federalism. The Prime Minister clearly has no concept of this, as demonstrated by his successful assault on the previous Prime Minister's agenda in this area, because the Prime Minister, as we know, is a centralist.

The Prime Minister's strategy, exemplified by the way the whole Mabo policy development was handled, is to divide and conquer, not to develop a national strategy and cooperate with the states. If the Hilmer report is to be implemented successfully, cooperation between the Commonwealth and states will be essential. A proper sense of nationhood must be built on such cooperation, not on attempts to increasingly dictate from Canberra what happens.

In today's global economy, investment capital is highly mobile. We have to recognise that Australia is only one option and that unless the productivity of capital in Australia can be improved significantly by reforms in the key areas to which I have referred, investment will go elsewhere. With it will go the jobs and the hopes of literally millions of Australians.

The tragedy of the present situation is that Australia is experiencing a massive failure of national leadership. Instead of having a government prepared to tell people the truth about our nation's predicament and rally people to support the necessary change, we have one which is going out of its way to conceal the reality and convince people that all is well. In the end, political correctness will not conceal fundamental policy failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill which seeks to amend the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974. The amendments being proposed strike a fairly healthy balance between preserving the integrity of the export market development grants scheme and preserving the flexibility of the scheme. As mentioned by the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the thrust of the amendments is three-fold.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it excludes from eligibility persons with criminal convictions under the Corporations Law or in respect of serious fraud, and certain claimants under schemes of arrangement. Secondly, it seeks to assist the cash flow of emerging exporters by providing them with the facility to lodge grants and claims on a half-yearly basis. Thirdly, it will effect a number of technical amendments of an administrative nature, consistent with the tightening of ongoing risk management procedures which clarify the established intention of the legislation.

The financial impact of these measures is projected to be about $1 million for administration, there being no expected additional cost for grant payments. The overriding purpose of these amendments is to maintain the integrity of the EMDG scheme. Referring to the exclusion of persons with criminal convictions, the amendment relates to those serious criminal offences under Corporations Law. It does not apply to the more minor offences, but to convicted persons with a penalty of two years imprisonment or greater.

There may be some opposition to this provision on the basis that it acts retrospectively in a sense. But we have to accept the basic proposition in this case that non-payment in these circumstances is quite acceptable. If we do not do that, we will not preserve the integrity of the scheme. Once we accept that basic proposition, the action being proposed in this amendment can be accepted.

That provision of the act also provides an executive or a partner who is convicted of a serious offence—in that case the company or partnership claimants—to be ineligible to lodge a claim for a grant. The logic is that the whole provision is unworkable unless that situation exists.

As far as insolvency and schemes of arrangement are concerned, if a claimant is insolvent a grant will not be payable. If a partner becomes insolvent, the partnership is ineligible for grant assistance under this scheme. Once again, given the provisions as they exist in this amendment, it is the only way that we can preserve the integrity of this rather worthwhile scheme.

Criticism of the half-yearly claims lodgement procedures has been levelled in the past. There is a delay between firms incurring the expenditure from the exporter and the time they receive grant assistance from the scheme. I suppose this can be understood, given the degree of flexibility of the EMDG scheme and the need to contain the costs of the scheme. That cash flow problem has always been there for emerging exporters. The government has homed in on those exporters and has been quite reasonable in this provision by limiting it to exporters for the first three years, simply because the cash flow is more important to emerging exporters than to experienced exporters.

The export market development grants scheme has played a part in the ongoing development of Australia's export performance, not only over the last decade, but certainly in the years since its inception in 1974. It is but one of the components of the activities of Austrade. I will speak very briefly tonight on the performance of that organisation. In industry, some people have sought to avail themselves at times of the benefits of Austrade—and have not been too pleased with the support they have received. But it is fair to say that evidence suggests overwhelmingly that Austrade has lifted its game substantially and now is a very important support mechanism for Australia achieving in its export performance, as mentioned earlier by the honourable gentlemen opposite.

The 1992-93 annual report of Austrade is entitled Really making a difference. . . I suggest that all members of this House read the document. It suggests that Austrade has assisted exporters in achieving export sales of over $4 billion. Some people might question that figure but Austrade has conducted surveys that have been verified by private organisations. They seem to indicate that it has been invaluable for exports worth $300 million and deemed to be significant for exports worth $2.54 billion.

We can take heart from the fact that many people in the export ring are availing themselves of the services of this organisation and think fairly highly of its performance. Overlapping those statistics, but not included in them, are the 2,473 claimants in 1992-93 under the export market development grants scheme, with exports worth $3.59 billion—a claim value under the scheme of $181 million. In 1991-92 there were 2,000 claimants with a claim value of $143 million.

The statistics I have just given the House indicate the sort of growth that has occurred as more exporters have become aware of this scheme and have availed themselves of its provisions. The government has amended the scheme and extended it to make it more effective and efficient in delivering that export assistance.

The EMDG scheme was established in 1974 and has undergone significant modification since its inception. It is fair to say that the scheme has attracted a fair degree of criticism through the years, centred around the increasing cost of the scheme to the government and the administrative looseness in the past, which has caused a degree of rorting by unscrupulous firms in the export area.

The government has succeeded over the last decade in targeting assistance under this scheme more effectively and has managed to contain the cost of the scheme within reasonable budgetary limits to get a reasonable outcome. We now have a scheme that achieves its objectives. It has integrity, relevance and good performance.

I was interested in the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who made some fairly strong comments about Australia's export performance. I suppose we can tote out any sorts of figures that we like about Australia's performance in this area and be very critical of it. Where we are today is not where we were yesterday or a decade ago. The honourable member for Goldstein was in the House before I was. I throw this question out to him: to what extent did previous coalition governments address the fundamental issues that he enunciated to the House tonight? I suspect that, if he were honest in that appraisal and that evaluation, he would say that they did not do it very well at all.

In coming to government in 1983 we faced a very daunting task, a very urgent national task to literally transform the Australian economy from an inward-looking economy to an internationally oriented one. That involved a massive change to the business culture in Australia. Nobody ought to underestimate the dimensions of that particular task. To achieve a cultural change in any environment is a most time consuming, resource consuming and difficult undertaking. In this country we have engineered an enormous structural adjustment and, as far as its manufacturing capability is concerned, we have positioned Australia to take advantage not only of the new emerging opportunities in our region but those that will come with a more buoyant American economy and a more buoyant world economy.

As part of that national task we have sought to open up the international global markets. I commend the former ministers for trade and the present Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) for their persistence and their unswerving dedication to achieving a favourable GATT outcome for this country. We are on the verge of one of the most significant boosts over time to the Australian economy if this GATT round can be put to bed. We have also had developments such as APEC in our region, which simply mean a greater integration of the Australian economy with those of our near north. In the end, that translates into increased economic activity in Australia and more jobs for Australian workers.

The results of those activities over a decade have been quite staggering, despite what the honourable member for Goldstein might like to put to us here tonight. Over that period we have seen a virtual revolution in Australian export performance. We have refocused our exporting effort from simply focusing on the export of commodities to focus on the rich, value adding elaborately transformed manufactures.

Why has this taken place? It has not just taken place for nothing. There are reasons, and the reasons are these: the government has engineered a massive refocus on our Asian region. For too long we saw ourselves tied—

TALK.START.PARA: —Malaysia!

—Malaysia, as the honourable member says. The Malaysians have learned a pretty hard lesson in this experience, as has Australia. I see nothing but constructiveness coming from this temporary hiccup in our relationship. We have succeeded in refocusing on our near north and our export performance proves that. In addition to that, in our business enterprises we have succeeded in changing the attitude of the managers of these enterprises and have encouraged them to look outward into the region to sell their goods and services. Within their firms we have encouraged a greater emphasis on research and development expenditure and an emphasis on total quality management.

PARA.TAB: We have the macro settings right at the moment. Interest rates are the lowest that they have been for some 20 years, the inflation rate is the lowest that it has been for 20 years and the exchange rate settings are fairly favourable to Australian exporters.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) smiles, as he often does, when these sorts of positions are put to members of the opposition, but they are undeniable facts. The undeniable facts are that the macro settings are right for Australia to take advantage of the emerging world recovery. In micro settings within firms we have seen dramatic improvements in the culture and performance of firms.

The statistics are quite outstanding. Of the 700 smaller manufacturers that now have exports totalling $8.3 billion, those exports are growing at a rate of 13 per cent per annum and will rise to $16 billion by the year 1997. In 1991-92 total merchandising exports grew and in 1992-93 were up by 10.3 per cent. Manufactured exports grew in the same period by some 16 per cent and elaborately transformed exports grew by some 23 per cent to $12 billion.

I agree with the opposition member who preceded me, the honourable member for Goldstein, when he said that there is much left to be done. But I think he ought to realise that the government is not the exporter of goods and services; the government can only assist the process. We have in place a range of measures, including the export market development grants scheme, which really does encourage that process to take place.

In my concluding remarks, I would like to refer to the task that we face in regional areas such as mine in refocussing the business sector on the export area to achieve greater export performance in the region. I think it is fair to say that in the less cosmopolitan regions of the nation the cultural impediments to the sort of export performance that we would want are more pronounced than they perhaps are in city areas. The networks that the smaller and medium firms require to achieve the critical mass and the support are just not there in rural and regional areas.

We have to do several things. We have to place a greater emphasis on changing the culture of business in regional and country areas. I am pleased to say that that process is under way and will gather steam as we head towards the year 2000. We must ensure that small and medium exporters have access to the sort of finance that will enable them to mount an export effort. It is not easy for a small firm that has a commercialised product that can be exported to divert the resources from its cash flow to mount that export effort. It needs the support of government. We have in place a range of measures to assist those firms. The critical element in that equation is their access to finance to build their enterprise to achieve that critical mass and to get into the export ring.

At regional levels—I guess this applies throughout the nation—we must focus again on our educational institutions as vehicles for changing the culture or for encouraging the export culture. We must make our schools vehicles to press the total quality management agenda. We must press our schools to make sure that their courses reflect Australia's position in the region, we must ensure that those courses seek to imbue in our children an understanding of the cultures and we must encourage the use of the languages of those countries to our near north. We must ensure that the small and medium firms have access to appropriate networks and the support services, such as the export market development grants scheme, that will assist them to get into the export ring.

The opposition speaker who preceded me made several points which I want to take up in the time that is left to me. The honourable member for Goldstein said that the government lacks strategic vision. The evidence just does not support that statement. The macro settings are right. We have seen a significant improvement in Australia's manufactured export performance and, indeed, we are well on the way to establishing the sort of growth in exports that will meet the needs on the external account. He made the point that 90 per cent of manufacturers do not export. The simple reason that some of them do not export is that they do not have a product to export and they do not have particular competitive advantages in the production of those commodities to put them on the export markets. It is a nonsense proposition to drag out a 90 per cent statistic and then suggest that the government has failed in its policies.

The honourable member for Goldstein made the point—and I think this came from a report that he quoted—that we remain uncompetitive in international markets. If that is the case, then why do we have the growth in exports that we have at this particular time? Why do we have this massive growth in exports? The simple reason is that the micro-economic settings and the macro settings are correct. There is not a coalition speaker who gets on his or her feet in this House without mentioning labour market deregulation. The simple fact of the matter is that the coalition would like to see as its recipe for curing Australia's ills the total deregulation of Australia's labour market. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) is chafing at the bit to get up in this debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to rise tonight to add a few remarks in this debate on the Export Market Development Grants Legislation Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) had a number of courageous things to say when he talked about what a wonderful job this government was doing in terms of industry policy, how coordinated it was and how wrong the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) was. The honourable member for Goldstein said that this government lacked strategic direction. I have to say that that is correct. This government does lack strategic direction. It has a whole range of individual, discrete programs that delve into areas of industry policy, but without any concept of what it is all about.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons why I think that is true is that there are so few honourable members on the government side of the House, on the treasury bench in this House, who actually understand what industry is all about; who understand what it is to employ people; who understand what it is to develop products for the commercial market; and who understand what consumers want and what business needs in order to survive, to develop, to grow and to foster employment.

The honourable member for Corio also talked courageously about how oppositions in the past couple of decades have not really contributed much to Australia's performance. I remind the honourable member for Corio that at the beginning of the 1970s, as I recall, when Gough Whitlam and his merry men inherited the treasury bench, they took over at a time when the country virtually had no unemployment, where we had almost no national debt, where just about everyone had a family home, where families were the centre of our society, and where morals and community caring were important national attributes. One of the first things that good old Gough and his merry men did was to frighten the living life out of the manufacturing industry. If the manufacturing industry is now starting to recover, it is 25 years down the track from when Gough literally destroyed it.

The export market development grants scheme is an important part of whatever this government's industry policy is. But that policy is literally a hotchpotch of discrete bits and pieces without any cohesion and lacking, as I have said before, any strategic direction. We have a need to bring together the various elements of government policy, including taxation, industrial relations, industry policy, science and technology, and education as a cohesive haul to try to set the direction in which we want the nation to head. But that is not what has happened.

It just so happens that this grants scheme is one of the most important planks of the government's industry policy. That is sad, is it not? It says that we have to go out and offer firms money in order to encourage them to become exporters and to do marketing. I must say that one of the things I have always found to regret is that we, as a nation, have not addressed the issue of marketing in any strong sense. In recent days we have started to come to grips with the fact that we live in the Asian region—that we are not an island in the Northern Hemisphere; we are in the Southern Hemisphere. We have to learn to market our products and services, which are excellent products and very innovative services, to convince people around the world that what we have to offer, gives them an advantage—in terms of cost, quality and innovation. It is this issue of marketing that we address when we look to this bill.

One of our problems is the fact that small- and medium-sized companies have been encouraged by this government for some time now to export, export, export—and with good reason. If we look at our balance of payments problem, we will see that our net foreign debt is now up to $178 billion, as I recall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Net.

—That is the net figure—not gross—that is owed by us. I think it is $178.8 billion, but that could be slightly out. Our foreign debt is continuing to grow. Just paying the interest bill on that debt is assuming a very large slice of our national income. So of course we have to export.

PARA.TAB: But when I travel throughout my electorate and, indeed, throughout Australia and talk to owners and managers of small firms and medium-sized businesses that could fill niche markets and could drive to export, they say, `The government says export, export, export, but the government does nothing to help us; the government does not provide any major assistance that we can come to grips with'. I say to them, `But how about this program, that program and another program?'. They say, `What are those?'.

It seems to me that one of the problems we have is the fact that the government does not actually market the programs that it has. Do honourable members know that there are approximately 160 discrete programs that deal with assistance to industry in one form or another? We can buy a book for something like $155 that will tell us what each of these schemes is. The book is updated yearly to try to keep track of it all. In my office recently we tried to put together for our businesses a list of those more active programs that the government has at the moment. As we found, these programs included: the EMDG; the international trade enhancement scheme; the development import finance facility; the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation; the National Export Education Centre—did honourable members know about that one; that was a new one—enterprise development through the national industry extensions services; the small- and medium-enterprise development program; export access through DITARD, Austrade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

There is also an Asia-Pacific fellowship program and the Australian international management exchange program. The MTIA provides some valuable assistance for its members and others in the metals industry. There is a small business network, a project marketing loans facility, a national teaching company scheme—that is a new one that I did not know about—and tax incentives for research and development. That is an important initiative. There is the national procurement development program, a discretionary grants scheme, the advanced manufacturing technology development program, the generic technology grants scheme, the rural industries business extension service, business advisers for rural areas program, the innovative agricultural marketing program, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, and the Commonwealth Development Bank. Then there are a few specific programs which deal with the textile, clothing and footwear industry, shipbuilding and printing in terms of bounty assistance for those firms which have been particularly hurt by rapid falls in tariffs.

The point is that if we, as members of this place, want to tell the small businesses in our electorates what these programs are there is no single place where we can go to find a listing of them. The Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development cannot even tell us the range of major programs that are available to assist industry in a development sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are wrong.

—No, I am not wrong because I have tried to find out. I suggest to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney)—perhaps one of his advisers will read this speech—that such a listing ought to be a priority. We produced a listing, but that is not our job. We are in opposition; we are not in government. One would have thought that surely the bureaucracy could come together to produce a list and advertise the assistance that is available to companies which would like to export.

PARA.TAB: This bill addresses three significant issues, none of which the opposition has any particular problem with. The first says, essentially, that firms which are insolvent shall not participate in the scheme. That is fair enough—they should not. The second says that firm owners or principals of firms which have been convicted of a felony which is associated—particularly in a business sense—with business ventures are not the proper people to attract this grant. That is fair enough. The third issue brings forward payments for the scheme to a half yearly rather than a full yearly basis which does provide some assistance in the start-up years, particularly for small- and medium-sized firms. Those are the three things that this bill sets out to achieve. I actually applaud the minister for this further modification of the export market development grants scheme to include these proper initiatives.

But what does this bill fail to address? In my view, it fails to address two significant areas which it should take a look at. First, it is my understanding that approximately 25 per cent—perhaps higher—of participants in the scheme drop out after the second year and before the third year, which is the first year that the participants' actual export performance is tested.

There could be a number of reasons for that. It could be that many firms invest their money in marketing programs without any real idea of whether it will benefit them or not. They think, `Oh, well, if I get the grant, then I spent some money but I got the grant to help offset the costs. So what?'. I think that is a pretty short-sighted view. I think probably very few firms would set out to do that. In the first place, one needs to invest $30,000 before one can apply for a grant. That is not an inconsiderable sum when it is a cost for a firm to consider in making that effort.

It seems to be more likely that the firms drop out because they are unable, even through the extra marketing effort, to generate the extra income needed to meet the test. If that is the case, then the scheme—at least in the sense that in the third year it is attempting to find out the level of increased exports—is operating properly. But I think the department needs to have a good close look at what happens between year 2 and year 3. I would be pleased to hear from the minister, if he has received advice already, as to the reason for the high drop-out rate at that point.

The program is clearly designed to encourage people who have not exported in the past to export now. That is what we want to encourage. There will be a failure rate, as there is some rate of failure in all business from all entrepreneurial activity. That is a good reason for government to stay out of it, too, because it has always been the case that those who wish to try new ventures do so at a risk. The risk is either of gain or failure. Governments need not be about failure; they need to be about encouragement and direction and setting the parameters which will allow the private sector to operate.

The second item that this bill fails to address concerns a report which was brought down by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology earlier this year. That report was entitled Undersold overseas?. The members of that committee worked very hard at the beginning of this 37th Australian parliament to try to bring down this report—which deals with the export market development grants scheme with respect to the tourism industry—ahead of the budget so that the minister had the opportunity to consider our findings and bring in a bill at budget time to incorporate our recommendations.

Essentially, the tourism industry was eligible for grants under this scheme from 1978 to 1985, and then from 1985 to 1987 through a scheme parallel to the EMDGS. It was re-admitted to this EMDG scheme in a limited way in 1990. I say a limited way because those firms in the tourism industry that wished to participate in this scheme are restricted in the following manner. Tourism operators must supply at least three of the following amenities: transport of passengers by land, transport of passengers by water, transport of passengers by air, accommodation, tour escort, or admission to a tourist attraction. Because they have to supply at least three of those items it effectively restricts businesses applying for the scheme to only one sector—that is, those who offer package tours and in fact inbound tourist operators.

Our report found that, by restricting tourism operators to those sectors only, the scheme was inequitable in that respect. No other industry sector—not manufacturing, agriculture, defence or any other industry—had such restrictions applied to it. The tourism industry had demonstrated exceedingly well its ability to attract new tourists to Australia. It found that marketing programs, at least in a generic sense, had been very successful. We all recall the Paul Hogan `shrimp on the barby' ads that were shown in the United States and boosted our tourist income from that country quite markedly. So, in a generic sense, we know that marketing works.

This scheme is designed to allow individual people—whether they be hotel operators, small tourism operators, owners of an attraction park or theme park, people who have motels at places such as Kakadu or whatever—to produce brochures and offer particular attractions overseas to encourage more people to come to Australia for a specific purpose.

In effect, we made four recommendations. The first was that the scheme be extended to include all of the tourism industry. The second recommendation was that that part of the act that described joint ventures and consortia be amended to include tourism services so that several small operators in an area could act together. For instance, in the Dandenong Ranges in my electorate of La Trobe, several small tourism operators could get together in a consortium and apply for an export market development grant and attract more tourists to our local area. The third recommendation was that the extension of the scheme to the whole tourism industry should take place by 1 July 1993. That time has passed. The last recommendation was that there should be no decrease in funds for some other part of the tourism industry in order to accomplish this. I am disappointed, as was the committee, that the minister failed to take up our recommendations.

The last item I wish to address in the few seconds remaining to me is the fact that government purchasing policy as it operates at the moment actually operates in the opposite direction to that of the export market development grant. Government purchasing policy encourages overseas purchases, not Australian. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to honour a commitment to a small businessman in my electorate. I also take the opportunity, having listened to the speech by the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), to respond to a couple of comments he made. I thought he was very patronising in regard to rural and regional exporters when he talked about their lack of an export culture. As I understand it, 80 per cent of our exports come out of regional and rural Australia. One thing our opponents would not like to acknowledge is that Australia was founded on the great export industries of regional Australia. I found the comments of the honourable member for Corio particularly demeaning.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member mentioned the matter of access to finance. I note that the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, has made great play of the fact that banks must lend to small business. It is a great irony that this finance system, which the government says is a wonderful system, somehow is still unable to lend enough to small business. The honourable member went on to mention education, schools and some other matters. He then commented that the government does have a strategic vision about growth in exports, but he then said—and I acknowledge the comments made by my colleague the shadow minister in this regard—that 95 per cent of Australian companies do not export. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) quite rightly referred to our balance of payments and our debt crisis. Perhaps the word `crisis' is overused, but I do not think anyone would underestimate the need to manage the net debt of this country.

The remarks made by the honourable member for Corio give me an excellent opportunity to make a few comments in trying to defend my constituents. After all, my electorate produces 50 per cent of South Australia's exports. If I could be slightly partisan, under the new Brown government we should see the situation improve considerably.

I think it has been readily acknowledged in the debate that nobody is disputing the three main points of this legislation—the matter of illegal activities, et cetera. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, I wish to honour a commitment I made to a small businessman in my electorate about the fact that it is quite restrictive on the smaller exporter—50 per cent of eligible expenditure for at least $30,000 after the first $15,000. It may be that advisers have found all sorts of good reasons why the government cannot encourage these smaller businesses, but I am not convinced at this stage. I ask the minister to consider whether it is possible to encourage these smaller entrepreneurs. After all, they can only become large entrepreneurs if they get sufficient incentive originally.

I make a passing observation about the EMDG grants: I hope that many of us in this country do not get into the habit of camouflaging the reality of government policy. I cannot emphasise strongly enough the fact mentioned by the honourable member for Corio—the $4 billion in export earnings generated. That should be set alongside the $50 billion or so in export earnings per annum that is generated in this country without support. Of course, I support the EMDG grants; I think they have been in operation for 19 years. Nevertheless, they must be put in context.

It is my belief and the belief of those on this side of the House that enterprise is the ultimate generator of employment. It is the only thing that can destroy unemployment. Trade, as we in this place would all agree, is essential to our survival. Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that growth was the only real way to reduce unemployment. Let us not be tricked into thinking that a few million dollars in grant money is going to overcome our overwhelming problems.

To sum up, it is important that we look at the smallest exporters and that we try to find ways of encouraging those people. It is important to remember that 95 per cent of Australia's companies do not export. I believe employment can only come from increased growth. Much of that growth can only come from exports. Mention was made of the 700 smaller manufacturers whose combined export income is expected to increase from $8 billion to $16 billion by 1997. I wonder whether those figures were done before the August budget. The great irony of the August budget was its effect on exporters. It would be very interesting to do some kind of analysis of that.

As I said, I was disappointed to hear the honourable member for Corio talk about this less cosmopolitan, regional group of people. I know that they produce a very significant part of Australia's exports; I believe the figure to be 80 per cent. Much of the urban wealth of this country was built on the exports of regional Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate. A couple of matters were raised during the debate which require a response. During the contribution by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) he asked what mechanisms will be in place to prevent a person convicted of an offence overseas from receiving an export market development grant. I have been informed that in all cases claimants for grants are required to certify, on the official export market development grant claim form lodged with Austrade, that they have or have not been convicted of an offence as set down in the proposed amendments. Austrade is in the process of instituting a procedure to provide for random sampling of these statements. Selected claims will be referred to the Australian Federal Police for verification against records held by them and other agencies in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The AFP will, in a number of randomly selected cases, be further requested to make inquiries overseas through relevant agencies with which they have working relationships. It is not possible to list in this proposed legislation all of the equivalent convictions in all of the countries of the globe. The AFP will be asked to base its inquiries on its knowledge of what would be appropriate to the particular country of inquiry.

Austrade currently receives in excess of 3,000 claims per annum under the scheme. As the vast majority of claimants can be assumed to respond to this question in the negative—that is, not convicted of an offence—the task of verifying each and every claim is obviously beyond the resources of Austrade and out of touch with current risk management practice, which accepts random sampling as valid in these circumstances.

The second matter raised during the debate and to which I would like to respond concerns an expression of concern by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) about the drop-out rate under the scheme. I am advised that the scheme is currently being reviewed by Austrade and that the drop-out rate in the review is receiving particular attention.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third time.
