SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill amends a number of bounty acts. The coalition will not oppose the bill. Given this, and because of the substantial legislative program before the House, I do not propose to spend a great deal of time debating this piece of legislation. However, I would like to make some general comments on the nature of the key measures being proposed and outline the coalition's thoughts on each.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 and the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984. These amendments arise out of government policy decisions. Amendments to the Bounty and Capitalisation Grants (Textile Yarns) Act 1981 and the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985 are minor and of a technical nature.

As a signatory to the Florence agreement, Australia cannot impose tariffs on imported books which are of a scientific, educational or cultural nature. Accordingly, a bounty of 13.5 per cent is currently payable on the domestic production of such books. Tariffs are imposed on most other categories of imported books. Current bounty arrangements are due to expire on 31 December 1993.

In anticipation of this, the government directed the Industry Commission to inquire into the operation of the bounty and report on future provision of measures to support the industry. Apart from its key recommendations, the Industry Commission, in its report of 15 October 1992, made a number of very interesting observations. It suggests, for example, that Australia does not have a particular cost advantage in any of the principal inputs to book production, namely labour, capital and materials. The Industry Commission also found that most books marketed in Australia are typically part of a large production run undertaken overseas. Indeed, about half of the work commissioned by the Australian publishers is printed overseas principally in Hong Kong, Singapore and other parts of Asia.

According to the Industry Commission's research, higher labour costs and paper costs are largely responsible for eroding our competitiveness on the international book market. While labour costs in Hong Kong and Singapore have been rising, the commission suggests that many book producers are overcoming this by transferring their operations to other parts of Asia, such as China and Malaysia, to maintain their competitiveness. The Industry Commission found that Australian producers' prospects were further limited because of their tendency to supply specialised niche markets. This means that they cannot get the length in production runs to produce cheaply and competitively.

In its final report, the Industry Commission recommended that tariff rates on imported books remain within the phased reduction program to five per cent in 1996; the book bounty be extended but progressively reduced to 4.5 per cent from 1 January 1997; the present minimum $500 claim per title be replaced with a requirement of a minimum production run of $3,700, with effect from 1 January 1994; and the present arrangements under which a publisher or printer may claim bounty remain unchanged. In making these recommendations, the Industry Commission pointed out that continued reductions in bounty will lower the burden on taxpayers and increase pressure on the industry to maintain productivity, technology and other efficiency gains.

The government has accepted the Industry Commission's recommendations, and this bill puts them into effect. While supporting the recommendations, the coalition believes that neither the industry nor the government must rest on its laurels and that further reductions in tariffs and bounties must occur following completion of the current schedule. Of course, in doing this, the onus is on the government to accelerate the pace of micro-economic reform so that industry can achieve some cost benefits. It is only once the lower costs generated by micro-economic reform begin to flow through that industry will become more competitive on both the domestic and international markets.

I noted with interest the recent comments by the Industry Commission on micro-economic reform. I am sure the House would be aware that in its latest annual report the Industry Commission advised that much more remains to be done in the area of reform. Indeed, the commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The task of substantially increasing Australia's productivity growth is too important to allow opportunities for significant gains to pass.
It went on to say:
The pace of reform in some key areas has been frustratingly slow.

The government must also reduce the tax burden. Even though the House has heard many times about the proliferation of government taxes and charges placed on business, their impact is so severe and action has been so negligible that the message is worth repeating.

PARA.TAB: Taxes and charges, such as the superannuation levy, leave loading, the training levy, payroll tax and sales tax on business inputs, all impose a massive cost burden on our manufacturers. In fact, I would like to share with the House a comparison of the sorts of government charges which an Australian manufacturer faces in the area of the labour market alone. They show quite clearly just how these taxes undermine our competitiveness. In Australia, employees gain a total of 43 days leave per year, including public holidays and annual leave. In New Zealand, that figure is 35 days, while in the United States it is 25 days. Superannuation leave loading in Australia is five per cent; in New Zealand it is zero; and in the US it is three per cent. Workers compensation loadings here average eight per cent compared with 3.4 per cent in New Zealand and 1.5 per cent in the US. Payroll tax is between five and seven per cent in Australia, depending on the state and the size of one's work force. In New Zealand and the US it is zero.

To see the potential of Australian manufacturing, one needs only to recall figures prepared for the coalition which suggest that, if a range of taxes and charges were lifted from industry, an extra $50 billion of income per annum could be generated. My challenge to the government is, instead of taking the easy way out and extending the bounty, to lift the costs from business and free it from the onerous regulatory burden. The bottom line is that bounties and tariffs are necessary only because of all of the burdens which government imposes on industry. The bill also proposes to extend bounty eligibility to directories, other than telephone directories and timetables, where they contain less than 30 per cent advertising. Company prospectuses are specifically excluded from bounty eligibility on the grounds that they are similar to annual reports and shareholders reports, which are already excluded.

The second amendment of a substantive nature relates to the computer bounty. The computer bounty is currently payable on the development and production of most forms of computer equipment, including modems, printed circuit boards and microprocessors. The bounty is due to expire on 31 December 1995. This bill tightens the eligibility for bounty, and limits expenditure by clarifying the definition of `research and development'. New administrative procedures are also proposed.

The bill introduces a new definition of `research and development' modelled on the definition used in the Income Tax Assessment Act. It requires research and development to be a systematic, investigative or experimental activity aimed at the production of bountiable equipment. As such, the new definition ensures that bounty is only payable on the research and development leading to the production of new computer hardware and it specifically excludes the development of computer software. A second amendment ensures that the bounty is only payable on the production of computers which have application to more than one customer, thus excluding the manufacture of specialised computers for individual customers.

The coalition welcomes these amendments. We have long been concerned about the inefficient handling by the government of grants programs and other forms of assistance. We only need to recall the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the disgraceful sports rorts she administered to get some idea of the potential for misuse. Any measure which tightens administration, makes recipients more accountable and directs funding only to those who fall within strictly defined criteria is deserving of coalition support.

The bill also amends bounty administration procedures, allowing interstate manufacturers to lodge consolidated claims across state and territory borders and providing for more efficient substantiation of eligible expenditure. This measure should reduce the administrative burden on manufacturers. Again, any measure which reduces paperwork and frees up industry to make life a little easier is certainly welcome.

IBM is one recipient of the computer bounty. I recently had the pleasure of visiting its Wangaratta assembly plant and I would like to offer my congratulations on its achievements. In this financial year, the Wangaratta plant will produce about 140,000 units, of which approximately 60 per cent will be exported. Its revenue this year will be in the order of $400 million, of which $300 million will come from export sales. The plant has a unique labour market arrangement and has negotiated competitive deals with domestic packaging and transport companies.

The lesson of IBM is that Australian manufacturers can play a significant role in global manufacturing. Nevertheless, I ask honourable members to think about how much more of a force our manufacturers could become if all of the burdens imposed on them by this government were removed. I believe that the potential is unlimited. Unfortunately, in extending the bounty, the government has once again side-stepped the real issues and taken the easy way out. Although we are supportive of this bill, the coalition would be much happier if it were standing up here tonight supporting legislation which removes from industry these taxes, costs and other impediments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the opposition is supporting the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill—as indeed it should, for reasons which I will outline in a moment—and I was pleased to hear the expressions of support by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) in his response to the second reading debate. This bill passed the Senate on 26 October 1993 and was introduced in the House of Representatives on 27 October 1993.

PARA.TAB: Assistance by way of a bounty has been provided to both the book production and computer manufacturing industries for several years. In fact, bounty has been paid on certain Australian book productions since 1969, and it has been paid on the production of certain computer equipment since 1977. The aim of the bounty scheme in respect of books has been to assist the local book printing industry to compete with overseas printers. The aim of the bounty scheme in respect of computers has been to facilitate the development of an internationally competitive hardware manufacturing industry in Australia, and to improve the productivity and competitiveness of all industry sectors by encouraging the wider application of information technologies.

Since its introduction in 1969, the book bounty has been applied to the major proportion of the Australian book production industry. The rates of bounty have been lowered gradually from 33 1/3 per cent in 1973 to the current rate of 13.5 per cent. The local printing industry has managed to maintain its share of the market through productivity improvements, which have more than offset the reductions in assistance. The Australian industry has kept pace with technological developments and is currently equipped to world standards. The continued adoption of new technology, including the use of desk top publishing software, provides scope for further productivity gains which will influence the nature and scope of book manufacture.

The government consulted extensively with industry following the release of the Industry Commission's final report on book production late last year. Comments made by industry were taken into consideration by the government when it considered extending the bounty arrangements. The computer bounty scheme has had a major positive impact on the level of research and development and manufacturing undertaken by manufacturers of bountiable equipment and has contributed to the diffusion of information technology among the wider industry, with Australia being generally recognised as one of the highest users of computer based technologies among industrialised nations. Indeed, the Bureau of Industry Economics, in its program evaluation report No. 8 of February 1990 on the computer bounty scheme, highlighted the high proportion of research and development undertaken by manufacturers of bountiable equipment.

The sector was identified as a strong performer with an average research and development intensity of nine per cent. That is to say the ratio of research and development expenditure to turnover amounted to nine per cent, far exceeding the manufacturing average of only one per cent at that time. Investment in both research and development manufacturing in this sector has continued to increase with total bounty payments rising from $13.2 million in 1985-86 and $31.1 million in 1988-89 to $74.9 million in 1992-93.

The bill contains amendments to provide for a definition of research and development. The new definition clarifies which factory costs are to be included under the phrase. In particular, it expressly requires that the object of any research and development must be the manufacture of bountiable equipment within the bounty period. At present, there is no equivalent requirement in that respect. It has been possible to claim research and development costs on activities which might result only in the manufacture of bountiable equipment well past the expiration of the scheme—that is, 31 December 1995. So only research and development activity which is for the unique needs of an individual customer is excluded from eligibility. Any research and development which results in products saleable to more than one customer is still eligible.

Honourable members will be interested to learn that one of the main aims of the computer bounty has been to improve the productivity and the competitiveness of the wider Australian industry by encouraging the use of information technology. The absence of import duties on computer equipment has provided Australian industry with access to these technologies at close to world prices. At the same time, the computer bounty has ensured that Australian manufacturers of this equipment receive a similar level of assistance as that provided to general industry through tariff protection. In order to maintain this relative rate of assistance, the computer bounty is phasing down in line with reductions in general tariff assistance. These are important initiatives and will do a lot to assist both the computer manufacturing industry in this country and also the production of books.

The honourable member for Forrest mentioned a number of matters. He urged the government to adopt more micro-economic reform, which is a commendable suggestion. The government is proceeding along that path with responsibility and at respectable speed. Indeed, the honourable member for Forrest suggests that the government should forgo a number of taxes—wholesale sales taxes, the training levy, the superannuation guarantee levy and so forth. I do not know what he suggests should be put in place of those various taxes. Is he suggesting that we should have a goods and services tax? Does he agree with the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), for example, that the Fightback document—the document referred to by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) as a 700-page suicide note—should still contain the policies of the opposition? Is this the suggestion of the honourable member for Forrest?

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?
—Have you forgotten already?
—No, I didn't say that.

—The honourable member for Moncrieff said that in Adelaide recently. I also ask the honourable member for Forrest: does the opposition still persist with its pledge to cut $10 billion in expenditure per annum from our budget? What effect would that have on industry, particularly the computer industry and the book industry?

PARA.TAB: Since the honourable member for Forrest has been the shadow minister for manufacturing and service industries, across the field of havoc and politics he has performed in a reasonably responsible role. But many will understand my utter disappointment today when I read a media release allegedly issued by the honourable member for Forrest in relation to the announcement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) of the decision by Data General to have its regional headquarters here in Australia. The honourable member for Forrest, in his media release, states:

SPEECH.PARA: It would certainly be a lot more tangible than the rather warm and fuzzy idea of having 22 business people and unionists going around the world telling multinationals how beaut Australia is.

The 22 business people and unionists include Peter Bartels of Coles Myer, Tim Besley of the Commonwealth Bank, Philip Brass of Pacific Dunlop, John Foote of Du Pont Australia, Bob Joss of Westpac, Graeme McMahon of Ansett, Sir Arvi Parbo of Western Mining, John Prescott of BHP—and so the list goes on. These 22 business people and unionists have joined together to promote Australia as a regional headquarters location for overseas based corporations. The RHQ Leaders' Network, comprising these people, was launched today in Sydney. The network members will, according to their press release:
. . . harness their contacts and expertise to encourage US and European company decision makers to locate their RHQs in Australia.

I suggest to the honourable member for Forrest that that is the sort of thing that he, as the shadow minister for manufacturing and service industries, should be adopting and pursuing rather than issuing this rather snide, stupid statement which criticised these 22 business leaders of this country who recognise that the pursuit of regional headquarters in Australia means a lot to this country. The honourable member for Forrest would serve this country better and do a much greater service to the interests of the opposition by supporting the government in this particular area. I thought this comment was simply either a mistake by the honourable member's media officer or a misunderstanding by the honourable member himself. But then I read another media release dated 27 September 1993, in which he stated:

After all, when a company chooses a location for its Asia-Pacific operations, it will be doing so with the bottom line firmly in mind. If it's not a viable economic proposition, it's not going to matter how good the Australian lifestyle is.
He goes on:

Reducing burdens such as labour oncosts, the superannuation guarantee levy and the training levy, and addressing the often ridiculous complexity of our taxation system, would not only help attract multi-nationals to set up operations in Australia, it would also help our own companies become more competitive in world markets.

I say to the honourable member for Forrest that Data General does not agree with him. I am sure there must be hundreds of major corporations in the Asia-Pacific region simply bursting to locate here in Australia. As I did in my remarks earlier this evening, I ask the honourable member for Forrest: what taxes would he have this parliament revoke to meet the opposition requirements? Is it sales tax? Is it wholesale sales tax? Is it the training guarantee levy? Is it the superannuation levy? What taxes is the honourable member for Forrest seeking to wipe? Or is this just a subterfuge to try to get Fightback in and then say to us all after an election, `Now is the time to introduce a goods and services tax'.

PARA.TAB: I repeat—I have a lot of respect for the honourable member for Forrest and I still do—that this sort of stunt that he issued today in that release follows a consistent line of conduct from the media release he issued on 27 September. Those sorts of statements will not do his credibility any good in front of John Prescott, Sir Arvi Parbo, Tim Besley, Peter Bartels, Philip Brass, John Foote, Bob Johnston and the rest of them. I say to the honourable member for Forrest that he owes them an apology for what he said in his media release today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 was agreed to by the Senate on 22 October. The coalition does not oppose this bill and hopes that it achieves its objective of encouraging more responsible behaviour with respect to prescription drugs.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members would be aware that, as part of the 1993 budget, the federal government announced that it would be modifying the pharmaceutical benefits scheme arrangements for general patients. At present, there is a two-tier safety net limit which requires a general patient to pay $15.90 per PBS script up to a total of $309.90, referred to as the first threshold.

Thereafter, the patient pays $2.60 per PBS script until a second threshold of $361.50 is reached. Beyond this threshold, PBS drugs are provided free of charge. The scheme operates over a calendar year. As from New Year's Day each year, the patient reverts to paying $15.90 per PBS script until the first threshold is once again reached, and so on.

Passage of this bill will mean that from 1 January 1994 there will be a single threshold of $400 for general patients, that is, 25 PBS scripts at $16 each. The charge of $2.60 per PBS prescription will then apply for all further drugs, that is, free-of-charge prescriptions will no longer be available to general patients. The arrangements for pensioners and veterans and other recipients of drugs at a concessional rate are not affected. The increase in the threshold together with the removal of access to free prescription drugs are estimated to save $12.4 million in 1993-94, $32 million in 1994-95, $33.4 million in 1995-96 and $34.9 million in 1996-97.

With the ageing of our population and new drugs being developed, the cost to the community of operating the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is growing at an alarming rate. In 1992-93, its cost increased by 25 per cent to $1.5 billion. It is obvious that a major reason for this is stockpiling or hoarding of medicines by patients. Somehow, we must strike a balance between the right of patients' access to the full range of beneficial drugs available on the one hand, and the need for responsible disbursement of taxpayers' money on the other.

The significance of drug stockpiling is obvious: in 1992 more than 70 per cent of the annual prescriptions for general patients were supplied in the last two months of the year. The argument for a continuing co-payment beyond the $400 threshold is that it will reduce the consumer's incentive to stockpile.

As I said, the coalition does not oppose this bill. However, another matter which has come to light recently and which will affect the cost of prescription drugs is this year's budget's introduction of a 20 per cent sales tax on bottles and labels for medicines which are dispensed at the pharmacy. According to recent press reports, the 20 per cent tax now applies to previously exempt containers and labels as a result of recent rewording of tax laws. Apparently, bottles filled at the wholesale stage are not subject to the tax. While the cost is only a matter of cents per item, in the case of non-PBS prescriptions, pharmacists now have to face a decision as to whether they pass this cost on to consumers or absorb the cost themselves.

One really has to question whether the government knows what it is doing. Apparently it is possible that the amount collected will not actually cover the cost of administering the new tax. Consultants Ernst and Young have told the Pharmacy Guild that the increase in sales tax could lead to the government paying more in subsidies and administration than the $1.3 million it expects to collect in tax revenue. Further, the tens of millions of non-PBS prescriptions filled each year may increase in price, including popular cough mixtures, antihistamines and analgesics.

Another matter which I wish to raise is the problem that some elderly people face when handling their medical prescriptions. For example, I was recently contacted by a 70-year-old constituent who expressed his concern at the problems that elderly patients face when they are prescribed several medications or have their medication changed. He stated that he found the details were often very confusing.

This does not apply only to elderly people—although they are certainly the most affected. There was a tragic example recently in Queensland of a young, healthy woman who misunderstood ambiguous instructions for taking malaria prevention tablets. Taking them with the frequency she believed was in accordance with her doctor's instructions killed her. This is a prime example of the need for an objective examination of how prescription information is conveyed to patients, and of how the text on medicine bottles or packaging can read to the non-expert consumer.

When I read of this in the newspaper less than a fortnight ago, I actually had in my possession a bottle of the same tablets—tablets that had been prescribed for me when I was visiting a country where malaria was rife. I looked at the directions on the label that I had been provided with and, so far as I could make out, they were identical to the directions which were apparently prescribed to this other young woman. In other words, it is a standard description of how to take these particular tablets when they are prescribed. Whilst I had never taken them incorrectly, when I re-read that label I did understand how someone could make the mistake of taking daily the number of tablets that are meant to be taken weekly.

When people are ill, the risk increases. Perhaps the government, together with medical bodies, should seriously consider a campaign of education within its own ranks to avoid ambiguity at all costs so as to ensure that such tragic deaths do not occur.

During the debate on this bill in the Senate, Senator Newman, the Shadow Minister for the Family and Health, raised the important issue of the role of pharmacists in the prescription and supply of drugs. She stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Community pharmacists have traditionally been regarded merely as suppliers and dispensers of medication. It is pretty apparent to anyone in contact with the pharmacy profession that their training fits them with skills to make a wider contribution to community health.

The fourth issues paper of the national health strategy on pharmaceutical drug use in Australia and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs report entitled `Prescribed health' both made very important recommendations on the issue of the wider involvement of pharmacists in managing drug use.

We should be conscious, above all, that elderly people today are often faced with a bewildering array of drugs, and are particularly affected by both non-compliance with instructions and by overprescribing.

PARA.TAB: Speaking for myself, honourable members will know that I have a very large number of elderly people in my own electorate on the Gold Coast. The electorate of Moncrieff contains a very large number of nursing homes and aged persons hostels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there on Thursday.

—Lucky you; so was I. Over the years, many a nursing home matron has told me of elderly patients who had been admitted to a nursing home in their charge and who were in a very poor physical and mental state. After as little as one month of supervised diet and medication, it is not unusual for these patients to be transformed into active, alert citizens who certainly are no longer in need of nursing home care.

PARA.TAB: The wide array of drugs that the elderly are likely to have prescribed for them makes it very confusing indeed for them to keep clear in their minds what is required for each prescription. I am sure honourable members would agree that it is not only the elderly who can be affected in this way. All of us would understand how much more severely the matter of confusion with respect to prescription instructions would affect an elderly person, particularly if he or she were not used to having to take drugs.

However, the problem does not necessarily stop at the nursing home entrance. The shadow minister raised the issue of how both pharmacists and doctors could have available to them the full amount of information they really need with respect to a patient, if they are to take preventive action with respect to inadvertent overprescribing. Senator Newman raised the possibility of the development of computer software prescribing packages for doctors.

There are software packages for pharmacists available which include information regarding drugs dispensed to a patient over previous years. When a new prescription is entered into the computer, it can indicate whether there is likely to be a problem between this and previous prescriptions. If such software were also available to doctors in their surgeries at the time of prescribing, the job of the pharmacist would be much easier—for example, it would eliminate difficulty in reading scripts and the safety of the patient would therefore be enhanced. In addition, the doctor would have knowledge of the record of the patient's previously dispensed pharmaceuticals, and future prescribing could take this history into account. At the moment it is possible for pharmacists to detect some problems, but it is important that the prescribing doctor also know the relevant facts before writing further prescriptions.

In conclusion, I urge the government to seriously consider the matters raised in this debate and to look to action to ensure that health professionals are encouraged to work closely together in the issuing of prescription drugs, particularly to our elderly citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be following the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) in this debate on the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2). She has raised some important points—points I had not intended to raise—challenging those involved in pharmacy, medicine, education and government to streamline the prescribing and dispensing of medicine. She quite rightly said that directions need to be clear enough for people to understand them. In this day and age there is nothing to prevent all pharmacists giving detailed information. When Roslyn Snow and I opened a pharmacy in 1981, we gave detailed information to people through a computer system that was developed by a Mr Colin Trevena as a pharmacist in Boorowa. I do not know how busy Boorowa is, but he found the time to develop an outstanding system, which later enabled him to sell his pharmacy and move into writing and setting up programs for pharmacists. These programs not only told the patient, `Here is your bottle of medicine', but also gave details of side effects, the uses of the prescription, the reasons for the dosage prescribed, and other information. It also indicated incompatibilities. The computer was able to alert the pharmacist if the patient was already taking medicine which conflicted with the newly prescribed medicine.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Moncrieff said, there is no reason that such detailed information cannot be given. It is already being given by increasing numbers of pharmacists. I have said to the profession before, and I say again, that there should be more pharmacists who take the time to ensure that their patients are properly informed—and the same goes for the medical profession. The suggestion of the honourable member for Moncrieff for the use of software to assist in communication between pharmacists and doctors was an excellent one, and would help us to get away from some of the problems that exist at the moment because of poor communication. In my own experience, poor communication does create a lot of problems and can create errors, which is really inexcusable in this day and age.

A range of people in medicine, law, academe and almost every parliament throughout Australia—myself included—have formed a group on drug law reform. The honourable member's suggestion would fit in well with its proposal that presently illegal drugs, such as heroin, cocaine and amphetamines, be prescribed under a strict regime to people who are addicted. The idea is that this would distance the use of and addiction to illegal drugs from the element of organised crime and into a health model—a very important move.

In the late 1940s the Chifley government, with the former Senator McKenna as the then health minister, set up a model for what we know today as the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Menzies-Page scheme which followed really developed that scheme and got it running. Just as the Australian flag did not become official under Prime Minister Chifley, even though he was the one who legislated for it, the Chifley-McKenna pharmaceutical benefits scheme was pretty much the model for the Menzies-Page scheme, and that scheme has been the model for some time since. Although the drugs listed in it are different, the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits is not unlike the schedule to the original pharmaceutical benefits scheme of the early 50s, which was when I started in pharmacy.

In those days the cost of drugs was rarely at the level of today's high prices, where drugs can cost up to $2,000 and $3,000. For instance, the current schedule of benefits lists an amino acid formula that costs $1,989. When people receive it for $16 they do not realise the extent to which taxpayers are funding their prescription. Similarly, pensioners and other beneficiaries who receive a concession do not always realise how much the drugs that they are receiving cost. I pay full tribute to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett)—Australia's longest serving health minister—not only for the way in which he was able to introduce and develop Medicare, but also for the way in which he allowed the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to develop in the face of some very important challenges.

Today's high health costs really make us think about our philosophy, about what we are going to do with the booming cost of health—that includes the cost of pharmaceutical benefits—when we have a $1.5 billion budget. I have already mentioned the cost of some items. Other drugs in the current schedule of benefits include Alteplase, which costs $2,153.11; Albumaid XPXT, which costs $1,541.15; Interferon, $457.35; Goserelin, for carcinoma of the prostate, $431.81; and Epidubicin, for breast cancer, $778.02. These high prices are at present being paid not by the patients who require the items but by government.

We have to look at our philosophy. We are facing challenges from all directions. There are anti-carcinogenics, there are drugs for the treatment of narcolepsy, drugs for the treatment of the circulatory system and the respiratory system, the cost of which are very high. People come to see me about having an item, such as Ritalin, made available to them for the treatment of narcolepsy, a condition where people cannot stay awake. They genuinely say, `My child or I can be prescribed amphetamines'—which are addictive—`on the scheme, which are cheaper than Ritalin, but Ritalin suits us better'. Ritalin is also addictive.

I am pleased to be able to say that, following representations from me and, I am sure, from other honourable members, Ciba-Geigy has now agreed to apply for listing of the drug Ritalin. This will please many of the narcoleptic patients who fall asleep even during their working hours. It will make a lot of difference to the life of these people. I do not include honourable members, such as yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, who have to listen to speeches such as mine, as among the sufferers. There are other reasons for honourable members falling asleep in this place, especially when we are often here from 7 in the morning till 11 at night. Having given us all a plug, there are people who cannot work a working day—getting up at 8 a.m. and returning home at 5—and stay awake, because of this illness.

There are other pressures. People who suffer pain come to us and say, `I would like Doloxene to be more freely available. It definitely relieves my pain'. That compound is also addictive. We need to say to such people that successive governments have appointed a Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, comprised of doctors and pharmacists, to advise on the items that should be available—within the budget that government provides. If we do not say that then we are not being responsible to the taxpayers. We have a very high budget of $1.5 billion. We need to say to people, `You decide what should be included within that budget'.

This is what I frequently have to explain to people; I am sure that others do, too. In the end, it is not the minister we rely on to say what drugs should be listed. Even those of us who are pharmacists and doctors would not want to say whether a particular item should be listed. We are here as members of parliament. It is not our role to look at all the complexities and reasons for listing or de-listing benefits. Very often there are good reasons for that. I can recall when linctus morphine and some of the opiates were de-listed as benefits—for good reasons at that time.

The legislation specifically mentions the safety net which has been increased. Anyone who attacks the increase in the safety net forgets that it was introduced by the previous Minister for Health, who was concerned about people with chronic illnesses. He spoke to us and government policy committees frequently about his concern for these people who had chronic illnesses, had to purchase drugs continually and who would not be cured in a short time. They needed to take drugs to exist.

The enormous changes for people such as schizophrenics is borne out by the work that the former minister and other ministers have done on their behalf. Not so many years ago, schizophrenics had to be locked up in mental hospitals. They were institutionalised and often died at a young age. Today, because of the drugs that have been developed, these people can live in the community—outside institutions. As long as they take their medication they can cope with the social and working life outside institutions.

People who would have been institutionalised under dreadful conditions—they were pretty terrible conditions and still are not all that good—are able to take medicine. But they need to take the medicine all the time because there is a chemical thing going on in their minds which has to be changed, very often through chemicals. If we did not have the safety net, we would have to put up the price of the drugs to keep expenditure at $1.5 billion.

The safety net needs to be a price signal. This scheme has simplified the safety net for general patients by eliminating the free limit—that gives a price signal to people—and increasing the concessional limit to $400 a year indexed. Once this amount is recorded, patients will get medicines at the concessional rate of $2.60 for the remainder of that calendar year.

I pay tribute to our former colleague, Dr Dick Klugman, who talked about the importance of giving patients a price signal. That is what this legislation is doing; it is giving them a signal so that they know that their medicine is not free and that there is a basis for the charge. It does not hurt to point out to patients that often those costs are extremely high.

This system is replacing a more complex two-step safety net system under which a general patient qualified for concessional benefits after spending $312.30 on pharmaceutical benefits in a calendar year and for free benefits after spending a further $52 in that year. Now we have the limit at $400 per year. People then go onto a safety net scheme, where they pay a lower rate per prescription. This change is expected to reduce outlays by $113 million over the next four years. The government needs to be continually looking at the possibilities of savings. There is also a benefit for the taxpayer.

I am pleased to support the legislation. It is an extension of something that was started nearly 50 years ago, when it was born in the minds of members of parliament. I pay full tribute to the late Senator McKenna and the late Sir Earle Page for the way they developed the scheme. I pay special tribute to Australian's longest serving health minister, the honourable member for Bonython, for the way he developed the scheme. Senator Richardson and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) before him also helped develop the safety net proposal and the integrity of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) outlines modifications to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—the PBS. It provides the community with subsidised, cost-effective prescribed medications. The changes were outlined in the August federal budget and, as stated by the shadow health minister, Senator Newman, the coalition has not opposed this bill.

PARA.TAB: From 1 January, the safety net arrangements for general patients will change. Families will have to fill $400 in prescriptions, which is around 25 prescriptions at $16 each. Beyond this threshold there will be a fee of $2.60 for all scripts dispensed. At the moment, general patients reach a threshold of $309.90 and then pay $2.60 for scripts until they reach a second threshold of $361.50. After that, all further drugs are supplied free of charge.

Although pensioners and concession card holders retain their benefits, this legislation reflects the many wider issues facing health care in Australia. The Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) cites our ageing population, a tendency for people to hoard drugs and the development of new expensive drugs for the cost blow-outs in the operation of the PBS.

It was with reluctance that he told the Senate on 27 October that the federal government had to take this measure because, unless governments were prepared to keep the costs of pharmaceuticals under constant review and keep costs under control, universal access to drugs would be under threat. I agree. Middle Australia is bearing an extra cost for its subsidised medication, but the statistics leave us with no choice.
The number of prescriptions filled under the general safety net has doubled in past years and more than 70 per cent of the annual number of prescriptions is being supplied in

SPEECH.PARA: the last two months of the safety net period. By abolishing this second tier for general patients, the government expects to save approximately $110 million over four years.

PARA.TAB: The federal government's decision obviously was taken under pressure and against a backdrop of spiralling costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The scheme's 1993-94 budget is nearly $1.8 billion, which represents a 10 per cent increase from last year. However, it is substantially less than the 25 per cent increase in the scheme's cost between 1991-92 and 1992-93, but still significant when compared with the rate of inflation.

So while it is never easy to tell families that they have to pay more for their prescriptions, these changes are needed to help protect the scheme which has worked well for the past 40 years. But this bill does not provide scope for other methods to keep costs down for families affected by the legislation. It does not acknowledge all the wider forces at work, which share responsibility for the continued blow-out of costs within the PBS.

We must clearly identify these and set priorities and strategies. Only if we address these other issues can we ensure that we continue to protect those unfortunate enough to experience prolonged ill health. First, let us consider hoarding and the over-use of medication, especially among the elderly who are major consumers of prescribed drugs. We need to manage drug use and improve the quality and control of prescribing, even though I acknowledge that this bill, to some extent, will help. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a list of the prescriptions and costs of the 30 most frequently prescribed drug groups for 1991-92.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —For example, in 1991-92 the pharmaceutical benefits scheme's three most frequently prescribed drug groups were, in order: anti-asthmatics and antibronchitics; antihypertensives other than beta-blockers; and benzodiazepines, sedatives and hypnotics. Why were more than 6.2 million prescriptions written for benzodiazepines, sedatives and hypnotics that year? How many people in chronic pain or on our hospital waiting lists are being prescribed this medication as a stopgap measure while they await surgery?

PARA.TAB: Even on face value, the high use of benzodiazepines, sedatives and hypnotics tells me that something cannot be right. Some patients unnecessarily visit more than one doctor within a short period for prescriptions for sedatives. Given the addictive nature of this group of drugs, why are so many Australians taking them, and can we do something about it?

As the Minister for Health admitted on 27 October, there has to be a number of measures taken to educate patients, doctors and pharmacists about the proper use of medication. We need to look at our health system in the long term and educate consumers of medicine about their options.

The link between poverty and health is another factor which should be considered, especially when higher levels of subsidisation are necessary for this target group. Preventive health care is important, but people need to be encouraged to take constructive attitudes towards maintaining good health and to understand the consequences of the way they choose to live. Then there is the pressing issue of Australia's rapidly growing ageing population. If we do not anticipate and plan for the growing numbers of Australia's aged population, this proposed legislation will fail miserably to keep operating costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme under control.

The figures speak for themselves. Australia's pensioners, part-pensioners and concession card holders receive heavily subsidised medication. For example, antihypertensives are prescribed to treat high blood pressure, a common medical condition among the elderly. These drugs are Australia's second most frequently prescribed drug group, and the most money is spent on them. Fourteen per cent of all drug groups prescribed under the scheme come from this group at a cost of around $209 million. When we consider that in 1991 just over half the population of women aged over 60 and men aged over 65 received the age pension, and then look at the projections, we see that the case for preventive health measures becomes very obvious.

Although government policies could alter the percentage of our elderly who receive pensions in years to come, projections show that by the year 2001—honourable members should remember that is less than eight years away—there will be just over one million men aged over 65 and 1.7 million women aged over 60 in receipt of government benefits of some kind. We must do something now.

Let us take the issue of generic prescribing. Under this process doctors prescribe by the generic name of the drug or by the cheapest brand name. In light of the measures we are debating tonight, we should be underpinning the minimum pricing policy with legislation which will keep costs down even further for the consumer. That is important because we should remember that these changes mean that an individual or family filling one prescription a week for the duration of the next year will pay an extra $78 for the privilege. If they fill 60 prescriptions, they will pay an extra $104 and, for 70 prescriptions, $130.

On top of the indirect tax increases announced in the budget, it is easy to see why we must work harder and take a long-term approach to keeping pharmaceutical costs down. Closely related to generic prescribing is generic substitution. That is the situation whereby a pharmacist swaps a prescription for a cheaper generic brand, even though the doctor may have specified a particular brand name. Once again, this indicates a need for more education. Consumers need to know that they have choices, and doctors and pharmacists need to work together to educate themselves and their patients about different drugs.

While cost should not be the major factor in the choice of drugs, it is more important than ever that doctors consider their patients and their needs and keep up to date with pharmaceutical developments. Health Insurance Commission figures show that from June 1990 to June 1992 prescribing for premium priced brands decreased from 88 per cent to 77 per cent of the market. Prescribing for benchmark priced brands—that is, the lowest priced brands—increased from eight per cent to 13 per cent, and generic and unbranded prescribing increased from four per cent to nine per cent. I can only reiterate that we are making slow progress.

There are arguments for and against generic prescribing and/or substitution. The elderly may get confused if the appearance or name of their medication is changed. There is debate over bioequivalence standards, or whether the pharmaceutical industry could maintain current levels of research and development. Whatever the case, we need to sort them out and stop dragging our feet.

The government has been considering changes to the generic drug prescribing policy since 1987. I have noted that negotiations with the medical profession, state governments, pharmacists and the pharmaceutical industry are under way to change federal and state legislation. They must proceed at a faster pace.

A recent report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled Prescribing health made many recommendations in the areas I have been discussing tonight. Let us take just one of these recommendations. It was suggested that the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, as part of its health research activities, `dedicate resources to investigate overall savings to the community and the health system from the better usage of drugs'. The government said in its response to the report that these investigations are hampered by unreliable statistical health data.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare is now developing a national health information agreement so that Commonwealth, state and territory health and statistical authorities improve, maintain and share health information. Even though there have been some improvements to databases which gather information on drug usage, I would have thought that such an initiative would have been under way long ago.

It is the same with the suggestion that all prescription drugs carry labels with the generic name one point size larger than the brand name. The government supports this in principle, but it has decided it needs full consultation with the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which means more delays. The bottom line is that we must be smarter in our approach to health. Why simply chop here and there to cut costs as it is needed when long-term strategic planning can eliminate hardship further down the track?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak tonight about an issue which I believe is very important: the question of the contribution made by the Royal Australian Navy during the Vietnam War. Like I believe most members of this House—I would hope all—I have great admiration for those men who served Australia in that war and who finally got their recognition only a short time ago. The naval contribution very largely has not been made public.

PARA.TAB: The opportunity has now arisen for the inaugural Vietnam naval veterans reunion to be held in October next year. I am pleased to announce to the House that it will be held in Coffs Harbour from 1 October to 3 October. The organising committee believes it will probably have about 2,000 veterans from the various units associated with the naval participation in the Vietnam War from all over Australia. The activities at the reunion will include a civic reception, a special race meeting, a golf tournament, a commemorative march and wreath laying, a dinner-dance and, finally, a barbecue brunch. I think it is very fitting that, nearly 20 years later, Australian naval veterans should come together for this national reunion which is expected to be an annual event.

As I said, I want to pay particular tribute to the naval units and the men who were involved in them. I am talking about HMAS Hobart, HMAS Perth, HMAS Brisbane and HMAS Vendetta, which were the destroyers involved, and HMAS Sydney clearance diving team 3, the RAN helicopter flight Vietnam, RAN detachment 9 Squadron RAAF and Australian force logistic support. It is really quite surprising for most people to learn that the personnel strength of the Royal Australian Navy for Vietnam in January 1972 was 17,192. It is interesting, too, that those four destroyers steamed exactly 397,484 miles. In the course of their voyages they fired 102,546 rounds. They had replenishments at sea on 655 occasions and received enemy fire 17 times.

The contribution made by the RAN helicopter flight was also outstanding. From October 1967 to June 1971 it amassed something like 33,724 Royal Australian Navy pilot flying hours. Also, the navy detachment to 9 Squadron RAAF amassed, from February 1968 to May 1969, 4,908 pilot flying hours—a very substantial contribution indeed. I must mention too that the HMAS Sydney—although not all of these miles involved Vietnam—in that period steamed a total of 345,650 miles. It made 22 voyages; it carried 16,094 troops, cargo weighing a total of 5,753 tonnes and 2,375 vehicles. So it is quite obvious that without the Royal Australian Navy the efforts of our troops in that theatre would have been severely hampered, and probably the troops could not have existed at all. At the same time, the Jeparit made 42 voyages, steamed a total of 409,289 miles and carried 173,820 tonnes of cargo. The Boonaroo made two voyages, steamed 20,885 miles and carried 6,732 tonnes.

I invite all honourable members to advise veterans living in their area that this reunion will take place on the next October long weekend. They can contact either Mr John Martin of the local committee on (066) 524 131 or 522 932 at work, or the chairman of the national steering committee, Mr Peter Maher, on (02) 622 3546. It is an important reunion. It is the inaugural reunion of Vietnam naval veterans, and I commend its support to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The office of public prosecutor is an ancient and very honourable office. The public prosecutor within the English common law system has long been independent and is part of the separation of powers between our political and judicial systems. Yet in Victoria the Kennett government has examined a proposed bill—we do not know the determination of the cabinet—which would effectively castrate the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria and which would leave that office open to political control. One must ask—and I think this House should ask—why this is so. What is the background of the Victorian Liberal government's desire to take away the independence of the most important role of the Director of Public Prosecutions? I will be mentioning the name `Elliott' in this speech, but I advise the House that I am aware of the sub judice rule. I am aware that today in the Federal Court proceedings are taking place on that matter, and I will not breach that rule.

PARA.TAB: A very interesting point about this matter is to be found in the transcripts of the hearing in Melbourne before the Federal Court, and particularly the transcripts dated 4 November 1993. It has been disclosed in the press that solicitors acting for Mr Elliott wrote letters to the Victorian minister for police, Mr Pat McNamara, suggesting that the Victorian department of public prosecutions was not necessarily acting in the right way and, because it was a matter of grave public importance, he should intervene with the police. But what is not widely known, and what has not been reported in the media, is that not just one letter was written to the Victorian minister on behalf of Mr Elliott—three letters were written. That was revealed in the transcripts.

The transcripts revealed that on 27 September 1993 a solicitor, Mr Aarons, wrote a letter to the Attorney-General, Mrs Jan Wade, which was delivered by hand. On the same day we have public knowledge of the fact that Mr Aarons also wrote to the minister for police. What is not widely known is that on 28 November a further letter was written by Mr Aarons to Mr McNamara in his capacity as minister for police. In that letter Mr Aarons enclosed what I regard as a shonky legal opinion—shonky in the view of any lawyer who wants to read it—which calls for if not the removal then the suspension of the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Bongiorno.

I think anyone who has the administration of justice at heart must be very concerned that here we have a lawyer acting for a person who was seeking to avoid a potential prosecution writing to a state Attorney-General and to a state police minister to intervene against the Director of Public Prosecutions and enclosing a shonky legal opinion calling for the suspension or, worse, dismissal of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Then, very shortly after 28 November, the state cabinet of the Kennett government in Victoria considered a bill—and we do not know the determination of the cabinet on that bill—which would effectively take away the independence of the Director of Public Prosecutions. One can only ask, `Why?'. Who else, apart from solicitors acting on behalf of Mr Elliott, has written a letter or given any detail to the Kennett government, which has called for this action?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before mentioning a couple of items this evening, I add my support to what the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said about the reunion next year of the Vietnam veterans, particularly those serving in the Royal Australian Navy. As somebody who, as many honourable members in this House would know, served for three decades in that service, it gives me great pleasure to support that convention. I hope it will be the success that it deserves to be.

PARA.TAB: My first point tonight is on a naval matter. I refer the House to a program earlier this month which referred to the sinking of the cruiser HMAS Sydney during World War II. In the last few days, I received a letter from one of my constituents about that matter. I read into the Hansard record what that constituent said:

SPEECH.PARA: Last night on television there was a `Special', regarding HMAS SYDNEY. For many years now I have been interested in this matter, as has my father who was serving on HMAS SYDNEY until a `posting' immediately prior to the last voyage.
I know from my own Naval service and attending ANZAC DAY Reunions with my father, that the fate of the SYDNEY is still foremost in the minds of those who have served in her.

There is a lot of doubt regarding the circumstances surrounding the loss of the SYDNEY and of course the television show did nothing to remove any doubts. There were several matters raised which I feel do have merit and are the reason I have put pen to paper to my Member of Parliament for the first time.

The first matter is that of the unidentified body currently buried without a headstone. I, like the investigator, cannot understand why identification of the body cannot be carried out through dental records which the R.A.N still maintain, nor can I understand why the grave has never had a headstone. Surely we can arrange identification of the body and then arrange a correct burial with honours. At least one family will know what happened to their son/father.

The other matter is that of an estimated $750,000 it would cost to locate the SYDNEY in a matter of days. I believe that this is a small sum to pay and maybe we may be able to get some answers to questions which still linger. Damage may be able to show whether torpedoes were used and if there was more than one torpedo it may point to a submarine involved in the action.

I know that my father is still investigating the SYDNEY loss and recently travelled to Canberra and checked archives trying to find some answers. I also know that many other people are in the same situation, maybe now is the time to put this matter to rest.

Tomorrow I will be writing to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to ask that he investigate some of these matters. I hope that before long we can have some light thrown on the mystery of the sinking of that cruiser.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refer to a quite different subject. Last week in Toowoomba it was a pleasure for me to attend the launching, at the University of Southern Queensland, of an impact statement on the Toowoomba economy by that university. As I understand it, it is the first university—certainly the first provincial university—to issue such an economic impact statement. I congratulate Professor Barry Leal, Vice-Chancellor of that university, for the initiative. In the executive statement that was released, he commented:

SPEECH.PARA: A university is primarily an educational institution and its principal contribution to the community of which it is part relates to the excellence of its teaching and research.

However, the presence of a university in a region also brings considerable economic benefits. This fact is well recognised by most business people in Toowoomba, but the extent of the benefits brought to the city by the University of Southern Queensland has largely remained a matter of conjecture.

This Report, the result of an extended study by several members of the USQ staff, puts an end to such conjecture by identifying with considerable precision the nature of the economic contribution that USQ makes.

I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate Richard Temple-Smith of the faculty of business, Mr Norm Elvidge of the faculty of arts, and the research assistants for the great work that they have done. I intend to raise some of the detail of this impact statement with the appropriate ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to record my support for the government's initiatives to encourage people with disabilities to participate fully in all aspects of community activity—the world of work and the world of recreation. Since the introduction of the disability reform package in 1991, the government has continued to develop its strategy to overcome structural and attitudinal barriers in the community. The goals set in 1991 are on target: 4,500 places each year in the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service for disability support pensioners in 1993-94; 8,000 Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service places for sickness allowance recipients in 1992-93; 8,000 places through DEET in labour market programs each year; and 1,200 places for people with psychiatric disabilities.

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) in the last sitting reiterated the government's support for the effective reintegration of people with psychiatric disabilities following the Burdekin report. By 1993-94, 4,000 supported and competitive employment and training places will be created through the disability services program. The Commonwealth-state disability agreement—the focus of the Commonwealth's activity—separates employment creation from accommodation and other support services and will be the target of state governments.

More recently, the disability discrimination legislation of 1992 has provided national protection against discrimination on the grounds of disability. Last week the Disability Discrimination Commissioner, Elizabeth Hastings, visited Central Queensland. In her speech, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act makes it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of physical, intellectual, psychiatric, sensory, neurological and learning disability. It also makes it unlawful to discriminate against people because they have some physical disfigurement, or because of the presence in their bodies of an organism capable of causing disease. This provision includes, for example, people with HIV/AIDS.

It was pleasing to renew an acquaintance that went back over 20 years when we were both on campus at the University of Melbourne. Elizabeth made the point at a breakfast with members of the Rockhampton Chamber of Commerce that people with disabilities constitute 16 per cent of the population, and with family, friends and colleagues make up 25 per cent of the community. In this way, they are a sizeable market and meeting their needs makes good business sense.

PARA.TAB: Elizabeth visited the Mount Hay gemstone tourist park which recently received the Prime Minister's award as employer of the year for small business because of its contribution in employing people with a range of disabilities in its workshop. The workshop creates fine pewter statues for the tourist market and these little ornaments are in fact on sale here at the Parliament House shop. The managers were delighted to receive the award and told me that all their staff work together excellently as a team.

CCQ personnel and the Capricorn Tourism and Development Organisation were instrumental in developing the initiative, with CQ personnel providing the selection, training and backup support which has made this venture so successful. Of course, it was funded by the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services.

Another employer nominated for the award was ACME Fine Furniture—a Brisbane firm. It has been delighted with the positive contribution that its employees with disabilities have made both to its productivity and to good group feeling in the workplace. These two examples indicate the excellent contribution people with disabilities can make to the workplace once given the opportunity and the backup support.

Last Sunday, prior to flying to Canberra, I attended carols in the caves at Olsen's limestone caves just north of Rockhampton. This special event held each Christmas is arranged by Access Recreation. I was delighted to see the effort put in by Olsen's caves to provide access for people with physical disabilities. It was a pleasure to share with many people from Rockhampton the true Christmas spirit in a natural limestone cave.

Another event attended by Elizabeth was the renaming of Birribi, which is a residential care facility for people with profound physical and intellectual disabilities. It is very important that, as we reintegrate people with disabilities into the community, we do not forget those in our community who need special care on a 24-hour basis. I want to close by quoting again from what Elizabeth had to say in relation to the legislation. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: People with disabilities now have a piece of legislation designed to meet the reality of our experience as we try to lead ordinary lives; it is based on the principle of equality before the law and as human beings; it is not a welfare or service provision Act, but one which assumes the person with the disability is, and should expect to be, a full participant in the social, economic and political life of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently received a letter from a constituent about ex-prisoners of war and their efforts to obtain a special pension. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: There are only a few of us left these days, most of us approaching 80 years.

Frankly, it is a wonder that there are so many of these veterans still with us, considering the treatment and deprivation of even the most basic needs that were meted out to them in the vast majority of cases. There are in fact some 7,500 still living—4,800 or so were prisoners of the Japanese.

PARA.TAB: In 1952, the government set up a prisoner of war trust fund and paid up to #250 per person—or $5,100 at today's value—to those who had suffered exceptional hardship as POWs and who needed financial assistance. The fund was wound up in 1977, having disbursed almost $1 million. Not all POWs, therefore, received this payment or any other payment.

Between 1952 and 1963, prisoners of war of the Japanese received a total of #102 10s each—in today's money, worth around $2,080. The final outlay totalled the relatively token amount of about #2.2 million.

In the 1987-88 budget, 27 ex-POWs who had been held in Nazi concentration camps received a non-taxable lump sum of $10,000 each. All ex-POWs were provided with full treatment benefits for all medical conditions, including unlimited dental treatment, and in 1992 the war widows and widowers pensions were extended to cover the widows and widowers of ex-POWs. This extension entitled them to a range of benefits which they had not enjoyed previously.

In November 1992, the then minister announced that the current special arrangements for prisoners of war detained in Japan would be extended to those prisoners of war from the European and Korean theatres of war. There were no Australian prisoners of war from Vietnam. However, as we approach 1994—nearly 50 years after World War II and more than 40 years since Korea—it is long overdue that the government should adopt a consistent approach to ex-prisoners of war rather than these seemingly begrudging, ad hoc benefits that have been given.

While these benefits have been welcome, ex-prisoners of war do not feel that their sacrifices and deprivations have been fairly acknowledged. It is inconsistent, for example, that members of the armed forces were paid subsistence allowances when deprived of food and accommodation, and proficiency allowances, but that those allowances were denied to prisoners of war.

On 11 October last, the Ex-Prisoners of War Association of Australia held its federal conference, where it was resolved to make a submission to the government. Max Jagger, the national president, and Sid Marshall, the New South Wales president of the Ex-Prisoners of War Association, have advised me that they will be requesting an additional pension based on 50 per cent of the general rate for all prisoners of war except those already receiving the extreme disability allowance or the totally and permanently incapacitated allowance.

An extra pension based on 50 per cent of the general rate is an equitable request. Those already receiving the extreme disability allowance and TPI allowance are content to remain on their present pensions as they believe they are adequately compensated, but they fully support the claim of their fellow ex-prisoners of war to this special extra pension.

As June Healy, the dynamic national secretary of the RSL in Canberra, has said, returned service personnel are special people, but ex-prisoners of war are a special group within a group of special people. These veterans returned to Australia and got on with their lives but, as they are ageing, the extreme deprivation suffered through their often inhuman incarceration when they were just young men and women has begun to take its toll.

There is really no compensation adequate for their suffering. Their survival is quite miraculous. They are now elderly, their numbers are dwindling and the pension they now claim is not only a reasonable recognition of their bravery and endurance, but the proper payment of a long overdue debt owed to them by the Australian community.

It is true that these matters should have been addressed many years ago, but that is no excuse. This parliament must honour the promises made by previous governments and rectify what has been a major injustice. I therefore urge the government to grant the request contained in the forthcoming submission from the national body of the Ex-Prisoners of War Association and ask for the support of all honourable members.
