TALK.START.PARA: —With the increasing intensification of development and population along our coastline, the community has become aware that the Australian coast, although extremely large, is a finite resource. The explosion of tourist developments along our coast, particularly in North Queensland, and the sewage disposal problems facing the residents of our major metropolitan centre, Sydney, have heightened the concerns of Australians, and in particular the 80 per cent of Australians who live within 50 kilometres of the coastline.

PARA.TAB: These national concerns are consolidated by global issues of terrestrial warming, with the potential for rises in sea level and the devastation of major global oil spills. This public awareness is being marshalled into a concerted call for an overall national plan to coordinate the management of the coastal zone.

Coastal management is the process of implementing a plan designed to resolve conflicts among a variety of coastal users, to determine the most appropriate use of coastal resources and to allocate uses and resources among legitimate stakeholders. Public participation is of vital importance in this process of

SPEECH.PARA: planning and management. The purpose of the unified, national and integrated approach is to encourage well-planned economic development while balancing environmental protection and conservation needs to promote sustainable resource management.

PARA.TAB: The final report of the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the coastal zone, released to the public only today, has recommended the adoption of an integrated approach to coastal land management. The inquiry defined coastal zone integrated management as—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . management of the coastal zone as a whole in relation to local, regional, national and international environmental goals. It imposes a particular focus on the interaction between the various land use activities and between coastal zone activities and activities outside the coastal zone.

Against this background a major development is being proposed in my own electorate. I refer to the Fern Bay housing development. Tomorrow evening, the Port Stephens council will consider a rezoning application to allow a proposed development for 17,000 people to be established on a coastal dune formation. It will require the majority of the land to be cleared and levelled. The proposal contravenes the findings of the report I have already mentioned.

PARA.TAB: I am strongly of the view that consideration of this development is proceeding with far too much haste, with insufficient consultation with all existing land users and without due regard for the contemporary strategies of coastal land management; in particular, those recommended in the final report of the Resource Assessment Commission into coastal land management.

As I expressed previously, this report recommended a holistic and integrated approach. It identified the coastal zone as a resource for all, not just some. Land use decisions should be made on the basis of what is in the interests of the whole community, whether they live nearby, in the Hunter, in New South Wales or in the whole of Australia.

The decision makers on the Fern Bay development should be aware of one of the basic conclusions in this report, namely, that we must exercise greater vision than we have in the past. We can no longer afford the pretension that different governments, different arms of administration, can proceed in their own ways, and that the results will be good. Decisions should be made on the basis that the long view prevails over the short; that prudence should take the place of expediency; and that broad considerations should be the order of the day. It is imperative that the decision makers of this development take stock and address the strategies outlined in this report before proceeding to resolve this development application. Given the fragility of this zone, a national approach to its management is of critical importance. The development of a coastal park may be a more appropriate outcome for this delightful piece of coastline. The Port Stephens council should investigate this option through a consultative community process. I also remind the Port Stephens council that Port Stephens is already the No. 1 tourist destination in the Hunter and that this coastal park would only enhance its standing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some weeks ago I spoke about the rural community of Yarraman in the electorate of Fisher and the plight they faced with the Westpac Banking Corporation pulling out of the town and closing the town's only banking facility. Tonight I am pleased to announce that community cooperation and people power have prevailed. The Yarraman community successfully attracted a new financial institution to the district. The Ipswich and West Moreton Building Society has opened a full service facility in the town.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall that previously in Yarraman we had a situation where a rural community of 1,500 people serviced by 59 local businesses was going to be left without any bank at all. Although the Yarraman branch of Westpac was not in a loss-making situation, with more than 1,000 accounts on its books, the powers that be decided to pull the plug on Yarraman, claiming it was not a financially viable branch in the long term. That, of course, left local businesses and the wider community with no option but to travel for up to an hour each day to conduct financial transactions at the nearest Westpac banking facility.

The prosperity and future of the town were threatened by the bank's decision to abandon Yarraman. The business community was threatened, as was the development potential of the region. During that period I attended a large public meeting to voice support for the community and to protest against Westpac's decision. I called on Westpac to reconsider its decision to desert the people of Yarraman, but predictably, however, bank mandarins slammed the doors on the Yarraman people.

I offered my support and assistance to community members seeking to attract a new financial institution. With community pressure from residents, media support and the very effective negotiating skills of the locally established Yarraman action group, Ipswich and West Moreton has opened a branch there. I would like to publicly congratulate Ipswich and West Moreton on its new facility, and also the local community on the pledges of support they have given to Ipswich and West Moreton.

However, through no fault of their own, some residents had to change banking institutions and, indeed, have suffered financially. A Yarraman pensioner, Mrs Catharina Facer, contacted my office to voice her concern over the cost and inconvenience to Westpac clients with loans and mortgages. Some young families in the region had to pay stamp duty on re-financing their mortgages.

I would like to congratulate the community of Yarraman on the way they worked together to solve this crisis which confronted the town. Yarraman has been a part of Queensland's history since 1898. It has held its own against the odds time after time. In these times of economic crisis, particularly for rural communities, it is great to see what has happened.

asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why was the SBS logo changed.
(2) Was there any deficiency with the previous logo; if so, what was it.
(3) What improvement was achieved with the new logo.
(4) What was the total cost of changing logos.
(5) What advantage did the SBS gain by changing its logo.
(6) What is the meaning of the new logo and how is that meaning represented.
(7) What was the meaning of the old logo.
(8) Will any other bodies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility change their logos; if so, in each case, (a) which body, (b) what logo, (c) why and (d) at what estimated cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since SBS's inception first as a radio broadcaster, and then from 1980 as a radio and television broadcaster, its logo was never standard across the organisation. The logo was changed primarily to present a unified image to the public and to unify the radio and television operations under one banner. The logo change was also planned to mark the organisation's incorporation (which occurred on 23 December 1992) and to coincide with the move to new premises at Artarmon (during the first half of 1993) which in any case would have necessitated the production of new stationery.
(2) There were a number of major deficiencies with the old logo, including primarily:
the inconsistent development of style across the organisation;
its poor reproduction as a graphic design;
its inflexibility as a corporate image;
its poor market identity as a result of the inconsistency of its development over the years; and
its failure both to unify the whole organisation and to reflect the high quality image desired for the corporation.
(3) The improvements achieved with the new logo are:
a consistency in style and use across the organisation;
a new logo which unifies all branches and operations within the SBS;
a consistent and instantly recognisable image which provides a standard for use across all media; and
an image that is clean, crisp and strong, and which is consistent with the aims and objectives of the corporation.

(4) The design fee for the new logo was $70,000. All new stationery was changed to coincide with the move to the new SBS premises at Artarmon. All internal print is being phased in as old stocks run out. Considerable cost savings were made by employing bulk printing procedures at the time of the move.
(5) A consistency of identity and image across all SBS operations, which has helped merge the television and radio operations, and a strong visual standard, with better marketplace acceptance.

(6) The new logo is an abstraction of a cartographic representation of the world, segmented into five identical shapes, peeled out and laid flat, and tilted at 23.5 degrees to represent the actual angle of the earth's rotational axis; the blue colour of the logo represents the colour of the planet earth as viewed from outer space. The SBS logotype is especially styled and always appears in conjunction with the logo.

(7) The old logo represents the world as a globe with main latitude and longitude lines shown. It was shown in various forms across radio and television, and was shaded so as to appear three dimensional. The SBS letters appeared on or near the logo and in many cases only the letters were used as logotype. No consistent ruling was made for its use.
(8) The changes in Telstra have been described in the answer to Question No. 213 which was printed in Hansard on 30 September 1993, page 1598.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did she write to the NSW Minister for the Environment and Minister for Forests requesting (a) protection of the Nalbaugh State Forest's old growth and wilderness values in accordance with the Commonwealth's national forest policy statement, (b) exclusion of wood production from areas of the forest likely to have a high conservation value and (c) offering funds for the assessment of old growth forests and wilderness.

(2) Did the NSW Director of National Parks and Wildlife about January 1992 invoke powers under the State's endangered fauna legislation to stop wood production activities in compartment 1402 of Nalbaugh State Forest to protect old growth brown barrel forest from logging for woodchips.

(3) Did a report by the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service find that the proposed logging in compartment 1402 would have a significant impact on the environment of at least 84 protected species including 5 endangered species of fauna.

(4) Is compartment 1402 (a) part of the Coolangubra wilderness area, (b) on the Register of the National Estate and (c) considered by the Australian Museum to be an unlogged forest of paramount importance to the region.
(5) Did Premier Fahey sign the national forest policy statement on behalf of New South Wales.
(6) Is she allowing the logging for woodchips of compartment 1402 by the NSW Forestry Commission; if so, (a) why and (b) how can the logging be reconciled with the national forest policy statement.
(7) Will she act urgently to prevent logging in compartment 1402 using all available Commonwealth powers; if not, why not.
(8) Will she seek an immediate meeting with Premier Fahey on logging in compartment 1402; if not, why not.
(9) Has the Government abandoned commitment to the national forest policy statement; if so, (a) when, (b) why and (c) under what circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 22 December 1992 I wrote to both the Hon Garry West MP, the then NSW Minister for Forests and the Hon Chris Hartcher, NSW Minister for the Environment outlining action necessary to meet the conservation initiatives of the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS). I specifically mentioned the need to exclude wood production activities from areas that were likely to have a high conservation value pending assessment of these areas. I informed Mr Hartcher that my Portfolio has available funding for assessments of old growth forests and wilderness and requested advice on priorities for assessment in NSW. On 31 May 1993 I wrote to the Hon George Souris MP, NSW Minister for Land and Water Conservation, requesting support for old growth studies in NSW.
I have recently written again to Mr Hartcher, specifically requesting information and advice on the Nalbaugh Special Prescription Area.

(2) My Department has been advised that the NSW Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service invoked powers under Section 92E of the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 (as amended by the Endangered Fauna (Interim Protection) Act 1991), as an interim measure, to protect endangered fauna rather than to protect old growth brown barrel forest.
(3) The report referred to has not been publicly released. However, I understand that it refers to this number of species being "known or likely to occur" in compartment 1402.

(4)(a) Yes. Compartment 1402 formed part of the Coolungubra Wilderness nomination, under the NSW Wilderness Act. However, it is my understanding that the NSW Government has decided not to proceed with declaration of this area as wilderness.
(b) Yes.
(c) In 1991 the Australian Museum recommended that the Coolungubra Wilderness, due to its high conservation value, be added to the reserve system.
(5) Yes.
(6)(a) Logging operations in New South Wales are the responsibility of the relevant State Government agency.
(b) I have sought advice from the NSW Government on how their current forest management of this area serves to protect the high conservation values that have been identified.
(7) I am currently discussing this matter with my colleagues, including the Minister for Resources, who has responsibility for the issuing of export woodchip licences.
(8) No. As indicated above, I have been in contact with the relevant action Minister.
(9) The Commonwealth remains firmly committed to the NFPS.

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the reference at page 3.277 of Budget Paper No. 1 of 1993-94 to the Government's strategy for the sale of the uranium stockpile, what improvements have there been in uranium spot prices and longer term contract prices.

(6) Has his attention been drawn to any significant events relating to safeguards agreements and guidelines, occupational safety and health or environmental considerations which have arisen in the operation of Australian mines since 1970.

(8) How will the uranium stockpiles of nuclear power generating facilities affect demand for uranium produced in Australia to 2003.
(9) Will the demand for uranium oxide from all sources increase during the period to 2003.
(10) What is the potential volume of demand for uranium oxide.
(11) How many uranium mines are (a) operating in Australia and (b) allowed to operate under the Government's uranium mining policy.
(12) Has the Government allowed the supply of Australian-produced uranium oxide to France; if so, (a) when did it decide to do so and (b) how many tonnes have been sold to France since.
(13) What changes have been made to agreements between the USA and the Commonwealth of Independent States regarding uranium imports to the USA.
(14) What access arrangements do Canadian uranium producers have to the US market.
(15) What factors limits Australian access to the US market.
(16) What are the characteristics of a world class uranium ore deposit.
(17) Does Australia possess any world class uranium ore deposits; if so, is each being mined.

(24) Has he entered negotiations or consultations with local uranium producers concerning the sale of the stockpile; if so, what was the purpose of the negotiations or consultations.
(25) Will the Government make public the status of sales of uranium oxide.
(26) Will the North Ranger, formerly Jabiluka, mine be allowed to commence operation before 1995.
(27) What are the characteristics, including size of deposit and ore grade, of the (a) North Ranger and (b) Kintyre uranium mines.
(28) What requirements would need to be met before the (a) North Ranger and (b) Kintyre mines were able to operate.
(29) Will the Government allow uranium exports to Indonesian electricity authorities.
(30) Are there any restrictions against sales of Australian uranium to Indonesia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Spot uranium prices, as measured by the Nuexco Exchange Value (NEV), did not exceed $US8.05 per pound U(3)0(8) during the first eight months of 1992. They subsequently increased for sales in the United States of America and the European Community following government intervention to restrict uranium imports from the Commonwealth of Independent

ANSWER.PARA: States (CIS). Currently the spot price for uranium of non-CIS origin in these major spot markets is about $US10 per pound U(3)O(8).

PARA.TAB: Prices under longer term contracts vary between markets. Apart from the United States, where prices under longer-term contracts tend to be based on spot market levels and have increased accordingly, there has been no discernible improvement in prices.

(2) The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) has made projections of spot and longer-term contract prices using its economic model of the world uranium market. Spot prices (in 1992 dollars) were recently projected to increase to $US14 per pound U(3)O(8) in 1966 and $US30 per pound U(3)O(8) in 2000. In December 1992, the model projected contract prices (in 1992 dollars) to increase to $US21.05 per pound U(3)O(8) in 1997.

(3) Australian uranium producers are required to submit all uranium export sales contracts to me, as the responsible Commonwealth Minister, for approval. I have approved a number of such sales arrangements by Australian producers.
(4) Details of export sales by each mine are commercial-in-confidence.
(5) Australian Bureau of Statistics data show the total value of Australian uranium exports in the period 1980 to 1992 inclusive was $3.931 billion.
(6) No significant events have been brought to my attention.

(7) In the Northern Territory day-to-day regulation of occupational health and safety and environmental protection is undertaken by the NT under relevant Territory legislation. I am not aware of any serious occupational health and safety concerns arising from uranium mining operations. The Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region reports annually to Parliament on the impact on the environment of uranium mining operations in the Region. In his report for 1991-92, the latest available, the Supervising Scientist observed "that both the mines at Ranger and Nabarlek are well run and tightly regulated and the Supervising Scientist has consistently reported that, while some effects are detectable, the environment is not being harmed by these operations." (The Nabarlek mine is presently in the process of decommissioning and rehabilitation.)

The operation of the Olympic Dam mine in South Australia is regulated by State legislation. I am not aware of any serious occupational health and safety or environmental management concerns arising from its operation.

(8) Currently, uranium output from Western mines meets less than half of Western nuclear power reactor requirements, and part of the shortfall is being met by drawing down uranium stockpiles of nuclear power generating facilities. It is expected that these stockpiles will fall to minimum acceptable levels before 2003, thereby increasing world demand for mined uranium output.
(9) Yes.

(10) The 1991 "Red Book" on Uranium Resources. Production and Demand, jointly published by the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency and the International Atomic Energy Agency, projects annual world reactor requirements to increase from (69,236 tonnes of uranium oxide in 1993 to 84,026 tonnes in 2005, and 91,587 tonnes in 2010.
(11) (a) There are two mines presently operating in Australia. Ranger in the Northern Territory and Olympic Dam in South Australia. Nabarlek has ceased production and is undergoing decommissioning.
(b) The Government's uranium policy prevents the development of any mines other than Nabarlek, Ranger and Olympic Dam (Roxby Downs).

(a) The Government introduced an embargo on supplies of Australian uranium to France in 1983 which it subsequently lifted in 1986. However, since 1988 the Government has not permitted the negotiation of any new contracts for the export of uranium to France, nor the extension or acceptance of any option which existed in current contracts beyond those approved as at 15 February 1988.
(b) Details of sales of Australian uranium to France are provided to the Government on a commercial-in-confidence basis.

(13) On 16 October 1992 anti-dumping suspension agreements were signed by the United States Department of Commerce and CIS uranium producers to restrict access for CIS uranium to the United States market. There have been no changes to these agreements except that two republics, the Ukraine and Tajikistan, have subsequently withdrawn from the agreements.
(14) Canadian uranium producers have free access to the United States market.
(15) Australian uranium producers have free access to the United States market.

(16) According to the Bureau of Resource Sciences a "world class" uranium deposit can be considered to be one which has a large tonnage of contained uranium by world standards, and can support a profitable mining operation to produce relatively low cost uranium.
(17) Clearly the two existing operations are based on world class resources. Whether other deposits are regarded as world class would be a matter for commercial judgement.
(18) This would be speculation on my part.
(19) No, as the data available to me only relate to the period since 1982.
(a) In the period 1982 and 1992, Canada exported 91,473 tonnes of contained uranium of Canadian origin. This is equivalent to 107,865 tonnes of U(3)O(8).
(b) The estimated value of these exports was $A7.6 billion.
(20), (21), (22), (23), (24) & (25) These are commercial-in-confidence matters which are the responsibility of the Minister for Finance.
(26) The Government's uranium policy prevents the development of any mines other than Nabarlek, Ranger and Olympic Dam (Roxby Downs).

(27) Energy Resources of Australia Ltd has estimated that as at 30 June 1992, the total mineral resources of the North Ranger deposit (formerly Jabiluka No. 2) are 45.487 million tonnes ore with an average grade of 0.4% U(3)O(8) containing 181,600 tonnes U(3)O(8). Within the orebody there is a zone of gold mineralisation which was estimated at 2.392 million tonnes ore with an average grade of 3.7 grams/tonne gold.

Canning Resources Pty Ltd has estimated that the Kintyre deposit contains 24,500 tonnes U(3)O(8) in probable ore reserves plus an additional 11,500 tonnes U(3)O(8) in inferred and indicated resources. The average grade of these reserves and resources has not been published, however the company reported that these were calculated using a cut off grade of 0.05% U(3)O(8).
(28) The Government's uranium policy prevents the development of any mines other than Nabarlek, Ranger and Olympic Dam (Roxby Downs).

(29) & (30) There is no provision at present for uranium exports from Australia to Indonesian electricity authorities. Australia would not be able to sell uranium to Indonesia unless it concluded an appropriate nuclear transfers agreement with Indonesia. As has been stated in answer to previous parliamentary questions, such an agreement would have to incorporate all the requirements of Australia's uranium exports policy, including the application of stringent International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards.
Indonesia has no nuclear power reactors either operating or under construction. Any Indonesian nuclear power reactors that are built will not be operating before 2003 at the earliest.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any reason why a limited company whose shares are fully paid up should not be allowed to convert to a no liability company; if not, can this action be accomplished at present and if so, how.
(2) Would an amendment to section 167 of the Corporations Law facilitate the action referred to in part (1).
(3) Will the Government consider making the necessary amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There seems no reason in principle why the Corporations Law should not permit the conversion of limited companies to no liability companies, provided appropriate safeguards are put in place for creditors and members.

Section 167 already allows companies to change their status in certain ways (e.g. from a company with unlimited liability to a limited company). However, conversion from a company limited by shares to a no liability company is not one of the conversions allowed by s.167.

There have recently been a number of conflicting court decisions on whether such conversions might nevertheless be possible under the provisions in the Corporations Law which allow for companies to be restructured under a scheme of arrangement.

In May 1993, the High Court in Australian Securities Commission v Marlborough Gold Mines Ltd (1993) 10 ACSR 230 resolved these conflicting decisions by deciding that the Corporations Law does not allow such conversions. The High Court held that s. 167 of the Corporations Law makes comprehensive provision for changes of corporate status, and that a change in status from a limited to a no liability company is neither contemplated nor permitted by the Corporations Law.
(2) An appropriate amendment to section 167 of the Corporations Law would facilitate the conversion of a limited company to a no liability company.

(3) The Government has received a number of representations seeking an amendment to allow conversion by a limited company to a no liability company. In the light of these representations and the importance of such conversions for companies in the mining industry, I have asked my Department to consult with interested groups with a view to developing a precise legislative proposal for a suitable amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total cost of outpatient services provided to all patients in public hospitals in (a) Australia and (b) each State and Territory in (i) 1990-91, (ii) 1991-92 and (iii) 1992-93.
(2) How many outpatients were treated in public hospitals in each State and Territory in (a) 1990-91, (b) 1991-92 and (c) 1992-93.
(3) Is a review of outpatient services being conducted by the Commonwealth and State governments; if so, (a) what are the terms of reference and (b) why is the Commonwealth participating.

(4) Are practitioners paid under Medicare for services which the Commonwealth deems to be appropriate for delivery by public hospital outpatient facilities but which the practitioners perform outside those facilities; if so, (a) what sums are paid under Medicare for this servicing by (i) general practitioners, (ii) physiotherapists, (iii) other practitioners and (iv) specialists, (b) what is the difference in the cost to the Commonwealth of public hospitals providing the services instead of practitioners providing them other than in outpatient facilities and (c) what are the estimated additional costs to patients in direct charges not recoverable from Medicare or other insurance or benefits schemes for receiving services other than in public hospital outpatient facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)(i) & (ii) There is no uniform method for costing outpatient services in Australia. Several studies provide estimates of the cost of hospital-related ambulatory care. This means hospital care provided to non-admitted patients and includes outpatient clinic and Accident and Emergency Department services.
Costing methods are:
the Hospital and Allied Services Advisory Council (HASAC) formula which equates occasions of ambulatory service with inpatient costs;

the National Health Strategy (NHS 1992) and the National Ambulatory Casemix Project (NACP 1992) derived average costs for hospital related ambulatory care from a national sample of public hospitals; and

the Queensland Inpatient Fraction Study (IFRAC) estimated the fraction of total hospital expenditure directed to inpatient and non-inpatient care from a 1991-92 census of all Queensland public hospitals.
National estimates of the cost of ambulatory care in public hospitals based on these studies are:

(1) (a)(iii) and (b)(i—iii) 1992-93 data are currently not available from all State and Territory governments. The national cost estimates for hospital related ambulatory care in 1990-91 and 1991-92 cannot be reliably disaggregated to the State and Territory level.
(2) (a—c) States and Territories collect data on the occasions of ambulatory service not on the number of outpatients treated.
Occasions of service data are:
1992-93 data are currently not available from all State and Territory governments.

(3)(a)The July 1993 Australian Health Ministers' Conference (AHMC) endorsed a program of research and development activities which aim to identify and address issues concerning the organisation, delivery and funding of outpatient services.
The program objectives endorsed by AHMC are:
1. To develop an agreed conceptual framework for the operation of hospital-related ambulatory services which:
(i) takes account of the relationship between costs and services across inpatient, outpatient and community services;
(ii) promotes continuity of patient care by encouraging co-ordination of services over an episode;
(iii) safeguards teaching and research;
(iv) reduces incentives for under and over provision; and
(v) continues the tradition of convenient patient access to a broad range of services.
2. Within the agreed framework, undertake pilot projects for each State to gather essential information and test new approaches for counting, classifying and paying for hospital ambulatory services.

(b) The Commonwealth has an interest in ensuring there are nationally consistent and agreed mechanisms for counting, classifying and paying for non-inpatient care, just as it does for inpatient care under the Casemix Development Program.

(4) (a—c) There are a range of services which can be provided in either the community or by a hospital. The range and location of care is changing over time and reflects a number of factors including: changes in medical practice and technology; organisational efficiency and improved continuity of care; and a desire to shift costs to the Commonwealth. It is therefore difficult to isolate that component of the shift to community based services that results in increased costs to the Commonwealth. This is an issue which the Commonwealth is monitoring and will be the subject of discussion with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister of Health, upon notice, on 21 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has an audit of the Korean manufacturer of therapeutic goods listed as No. 43188 on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods been conducted; if so, (a) who conducted the audit, (b) where and when was it conducted, (c) what was the result of the audit and (d) do the goods meet Australian standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a), (b) and (c) Overseas manufacturers intending to supply therapeutic goods to Australia must demonstrate to my Department that their manufacturing standards are acceptable before supply is permitted. The Korean manufacturer referred to in the question was approved to supply condoms to Australia on the basis of a detailed evaluation of a plant master file, which is one of five options available for demonstrating acceptable manufacturing standards at overseas sites.
The plant master file option requires a subsequent on-site audit to confirm the acceptability of the manufacturing operations and procedures. This audit will take place early in 1994.

(d) Yes. Samples of the product have been tested by an approved testing laboratory and were found to comply with Therapeutic Goods Order (TGO) No. 39, which is the current Australian standard for condoms.

A condition of listing the product on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods is that the sponsor must arrange for every batch intended to be imported into Australia to be tested to demonstrate compliance with TGO No. 39, and for the test certificates to be available for inspection on request by an authorised officer of my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: Is the Industry Commission to investigate charitable organisations; if so, (a) will Dr David Pollard head the inquiry, (b) has Dr Pollard written critically of the work of charitable organisations, (c) how many staff will be employed on the inquiry, (d) will the inquiry include an extensive visit to the USA and the UK to be made in March 1994, (e) what sums have been allocated for (i) staff salaries, (ii) staff allowances, (iii) accommodation and associated costs for an office in Melbourne and (iv) travel and (f) what is the justification for this expenditure of Commonwealth funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: An inquiry into charitable organisations was one of a number of public inquiries foreshadowed in the Treasurer's 1992 announcement of the Industry Commission's forward work program. The inquiry will commence when the Government sends the terms of reference to the Commission. As with all public inquiries undertaken by the Commission, the nature, timetable and procedures for the inquiry will be widely publicised so as to encourage participation by interested parties. The Inquiry process will be transparent and will involve public hearings and the publication of a draft report on which anyone may comment.

(a) No. The inquiry will be headed in the usual way by a Commissioner of the Commission, supported by one or more part-time Associate Commissioners appointed by the Minister. The Chairperson of the Commission, Mr Bill Scales, has advised me that he is likely to be the Presiding Commissioner of this inquiry.

(b) The Chairperson of the Commission has advised me that he is satisfied that there is nothing in what Dr Pollard, or any other member of the support staff, has written or said which will prevent the Commissioners directing the inquiry from receiving the administrative and research support they will require.

(c), (d) and (e) This inquiry will be resourced in exactly the same way as any of the other ten or so public inquiries that the Commission has under way at any one time. The number of support staff may vary over the period of the inquiry, and may involve around ten staff initially. The Commission already has an office in Melbourne supporting a number of inquiries. The staff on this inquiry would be drawn from that office. Necessary expenditure on travel and other administrative costs for the inquiry will be controlled by Commissioners and met in the usual way from the Commission's budget appropriation. The need for overseas visits in order to answer the terms of reference is a matter for the Commissioners to consider.

(f) The Commission's principal function, as set out in the Industry Commission Act, is to hold public inquiries on matters referred to it by the Government. Appropriation is provided for that purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) To what extent does the disposition of Government jobs and services play a legitimate role in the development of regional areas.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to concerns expressed in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales that the closure of the area office of the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Lismore, NSW, would remove a valuable contribution to the region's economy; if so, (a) has he assessed the impact that the closure would have on the region's economy and (b) will he consult the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to ensure the office remains in Lismore.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government realises that the presence of Government jobs does provide a significant input to a region's economy. Moreover, the Government is aware of an increasing trend towards the regionalisation of program delivery functions in consultation with local communities.
However, there has been no recent quantitative assessment of the economic impact of the location of government departments and agencies in regional areas.

The need for increased deployment of Government jobs and services in regional areas was raised on a number of occasions with the Regional Development Taskforce in its regional consultations. The Government is currently awaiting receipt of the Taskforce report, which is expected to provide advice on this issue.

With respect to the future location of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) area office in Lismore, I am informed that DEET is undertaking an internal review of its organisational structures. As part of this review the location and structure of the Department's National, State, Regional and Area Offices will be considered.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training is aware of the concerns expressed over the possible closure of the Lismore Area Office, and these will be taken into consideration by DEET in its organisational review.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have expressions of interest been advertised for an architectural consultancy for the National Museum of Australia; if so, (a) is Australian Construction Services (ACS) acting as project manager, (b) is ACS vetting applications for the consultancy; and (c) what safeguards exist to prevent collusion between potential consultants and ACS technical and professional officers acting as reviewers.
(2) Was the sponsoring of a national architectural competition for the National Museum of Australia considered; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes
(a) No

(b) ACS reviewed all expressions of interest received, assessed these against technical criteria developed by ACS and the National Museum and confirmed following discussions with the president of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects.

(c) There was no contact between potential consultants and the ACS review team during the preparation, lodging or review of submissions. All enquiries from potential consultants were handled by ACS professional officers who were not part of the review team.
The final review of all expressions of interest was carried out by a Selection Advisory Committee appointed by the National Museum which did not include any ACS officers.

(2) The sponsoring of a national competition by the Australian National Museum was considered but was rejected because of the additional time required and the requirement for extensive interaction between the National Museum, the community and the architect and specialist consultants. It was considered it would have been difficult to adequately address this in the context of a competition.
The Royal Australian Institute of Architects was consulted about the selection process and advised that it had no problems with the process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 16 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What shareholding does the Government have in Qantas.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the use of a Hawaiian beach scene in Qantas advertisements promoting holidays in Australia.
(3) Was the Minister aware of the use of the scene before the advertisements were shown; if so, why did the Minister allow them to proceed.
(4) Has the Minister obtained an explanation of why the scene was used; if so, what is the explanation.
(5) Did Qantas use a US advertising agency to produce the advertisements; if so, why.
(6) What sum did Qantas pay to conduct the advertising campaign.
(7) Were any Australian companies involved; if so, (a) who and (b) what sum was each paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) 75 per cent.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. The day-to-day commercial and administrative operations of Qantas are matters for Qantas' management to decide, under the direction of the Company's Board.

(4) Yes. Qantas has advised that the presentation of the concept of the campaign given to Qantas' management provided no indication that the beach scene would be clearly identifiable as one in the Hawaiian Islands. It was assumed that the scene would be "anonymous", with the focal point to be the individual in the airline seat on the beach.

Qantas has further advised that the Hawaiian beach scene was primarily used for reasons of timing, convenience, and cost. The advertisement was needed quickly and a production crew happened to be in Hawaii at the time shooting another commercial. The savings in cost and time were therefore attractive.

(5) Yes. The advertising agency, DMB&B, San Francisco, is affiliated to the agency previously used by Qantas in Australia, DMB&B Weekes Morris Osborn. The US affiliate was used by Qantas to create the majority of its image and tactical advertising for use in North America.
(7) No Australian companies were involved.
